Revised−1 Report on the Algorithmic Language Orson

James B. Moen
July 31, 2018

Abstract

Orson is a general purpose programming language, designed for use by individuals and small groups. Its programs work in two phases, called transformation and execution. During the transformation phase, Orson applies forms to produce new expressions. Forms are similar to macros, but are expressed in a typed, lexically scoped applicative language that can perform arbitrary computations. During the execution phase, Orson evaluates the expressions that were produced during transformation. Orson compilers may be implemented so that transformation occurs at compile time, and execution occurs at run time. This allows writing with forms in an abstract and general way, while still producing efficient programs.

Copyright © 2018 James B. Moen. Permission is granted to copy, distribute and/or modify this document under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.3 or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation; with no Invariant Sections, no Front-Cover Texts, and no Back-Cover Texts. A copy of the license is included in the section entitled ‘‘GNU Free Documentation License.’’
      This document uses special characters. Without proper rendering support, you may see question marks, boxes, or other symbols in place of these characters. This document must be rendered in a font where a quote ‘ " ’, an italic quote ‘ " ’, and two apostrophes ‘ '' ’ all look different.

0. Introduction.

This is willy-nilly the age of teamwork. In another generation [...] cybernation will have advanced far enough that the solitary genius will come back into fashion—provided he can get a grant large enough to supply him with the battalions of self-programming computers he will need.

[DIS 1969]

Orson is a general purpose programming language. It is intended for programmers who work alone, or in small informal groups. As a result, it omits complex mechanisms for hiding and sharing information, like classes, modules, and packages. Orson also emphasizes efficiency, expressiveness, and extensibility instead of safety. However, it still allows writing programs that are both modular and safe.
      Orson’s design investigates alternatives to some aspects of object-oriented programming [SAL 1998]. It has been influenced by the designs of many other programming languages, including Algol 68 [VWI 1977], C [KER 1988], CLU [LIS 1981], Common Lisp [STE 1990], Pascal [JEN 1974], and Scheme [SPE 2007]. It may be significant that no languages of recent origin appear in this list.
      The name Orson is not an acronym, so it does not properly appear in upper case letters. (If it was an acronym, then it might be Objects Require Some Other Notions.) Orson is not named after any person, place, or thing.

0.1. Overview.

Orson programs are made up of expressions that are evaluated to return objects and to perform side effects. Objects are data to be manipulated. Side effects are changes to those objects. Each expression is evaluated in two phases: first transformation, then execution.
      During transformation, Orson appears to be a high-level applicative language like Scheme [SPE 2007], but with an algebraic syntax and an explicit type system. When an expression is transformed, it returns an object or another expression. It also returns a type that describes the object or expression. Depending on its type, the object or expression may be used in other transformations, and may also be executed later.
      Expressions are transformed primarily by applying forms. Forms are similar to the macros of languages like C [KER 1988] and Common Lisp [STE 1990]. However, forms differ from macros in the following ways.

  • Forms use the same notation as the rest of Orson.

  • Forms operate on expressions, not objects that denote expressions.

  • Forms are lexically scoped.

  • Forms transform their arguments when they are applied.

  • Forms obey the rules of Orson’s type system.

  • Forms can be applied recursively.

  • Forms can automatically inherit the behavior of other forms.

Because of these differences, forms can perform computations with objects during transformation. Forms can often be used as more efficient substitutes for procedures. Most operators are implemented as forms, so they can be redefined. Abstract data types can be implemented using forms that take types as arguments, and return types as results. Abstract control structures can be implemented using forms that take forms as arguments, and return forms as results.
      During execution, Orson appears to be a low-level imperative language like C, but with the same syntax and type system used during transformation. When an expression that results from transformation is executed, it returns an object, and may also perform side effects. For efficiency, it is possible to manipulate the internal representation of such an object.
      Orson’s transformation phase can affect its execution phase, but not the reverse: its execution phase cannot affect its transformation phase. As a result, an Orson compiler can be implemented to perform all transformations at compile time, and all executions at run time. This allows writing with forms in an abstract, high-level way, while still producing efficient, low-level programs.
      Orson consists of a kernel that provides sequential control structures, and a prelude that provides operators and types. The prelude is written in Orson, and many different preludes may be used with the same kernel. It is therefore possible to implement new versions of Orson simply by writing new preludes.

0.2. Organization.

This Report is not a tutorial. The reader is assumed to be familiar with at least one modern programming language. Some knowledge of C [KER 1988], Lisp [STE 1990], and formal models of type systems [CAR 1997] is helpful.
      The name of a concept is usually italicized where it is defined. Although formal notation is used to describe forms and types, most concepts are described in English. Examples are used only to explain potentially unfamiliar concepts. If a concept is described without examples, then it is either like similar concepts in other languages, or else examples of the concept appear other places in this Report.
      Most of this Report is divided into sections that correspond to Orson’s syntax. Although this is convenient for finding information on a specific topic, it is less convenient for reading this Report from start to finish, since early sections often refer to later ones. To make the Report easier to read, it is written in HTML [POW 2001], where the first reference in each section to another section appears as a link. This lets the reader enter the Report at any point and follow links whenever unfamiliar concepts are mentioned. It is regretted if this makes reading the Report like traversing a maze, as in the classic computer game Adventure [LEV 1984].

1. Terminology.

What do I mean by the word mean? What do I mean by the word word, what do I mean by what do I mean, what do I mean by do, and what do I do by mean?

[CHA 1989]

Much of this Report describes how expressions are evaluated by being transformed and then executed. The next few sections define words and phrases that have special meanings in these descriptions.

1.1. Abbreviate.

A phrase like A is an abbreviation for B means that whenever an expression A appears, it is automatically replaced by another (usually longer) expression B. This Report may use abbreviation to define some expressions in terms of others. When the meaning is clear from context, this Report may use the expression A to mean the expression B that it abbreviates.

1.2. Transform.

A phrase like A transforms to B and T means that when an expression A is transformed, it returns a new expression or object B and its type T. If T is uninteresting, or is obvious from context, then it is not mentioned. When the meaning is clear from context, this Report may use the expression A to mean the expression or object B to which it transforms.
      Sometimes explaining how an expression is transformed will completely describe it. This may be because it transforms to an object that is not subject to further transformations. Or it may be because it transforms to another expression that is described elsewhere.

1.3. Execute.

Suppose that B is an expression or object that results from transforming another expression. Then a phrase like B executes to C means that B returns an object C when it is executed. When the meaning is clear from context, thie Report may use the expression B to mean the object C to which it executes.

1.4. Evaluate.

A phrase like A evaluates to C and T means that an expression A first transforms to an expression or object B and its type T, then B executes to an object C. If B or T are uninteresting, or are obvious from context, then they are not mentioned. When the meaning is clear from context, this Report may use the expression A to mean the object C to which it evaluates.

1.5. Unspecified.

If a situation is unspecified, then an Orson program can respond to it in any way, provided that the response has harmless results. A phrase like X is done in an unspecified way means that X is done in a way not described in this Report. A phrase like an unspecified object of type T means an object of type T that is chosen in an unspecified way. Correct Orson programs can respond to situations in unspecified ways.

1.6. Undefined.

If a situation is undefined, then an Orson program can respond to it in any way, even if the response has harmful results. Correct Orson programs must not respond to situations in undefined ways.

1.7. Error.

If a situation is an error, or causes an error, then no correct Orson program will allow it to occur. If the error occurs during transformation, then Orson reports it in an unspecified way, perhaps by displaying a message. Orson then recovers from the error, also in an unspecified way, so that transformation can continue. However, errors occurring during transformation always prevent a program’s later execution. If the error occurs during execution, then the result is undefined, so Orson need not report the error, and need not recover from it.

1.8. Limit.

A phrase like there is a limit on the number of X’s means that it is an error for an Orson program to create a situation involving more than an unspecified maximum number of X’s. A phrase like there may be a limit on the number of X’s has the same meaning, but also suggests that the maximum number is large enough to be ignored. Limits may vary from one implementation of Orson to another.

1.9. Must.

If a situation must occur, then it is an error if it does not occur. Words like can, may, might, and should have their usual meanings, and are not synonyms for must.

2. Characters.

A mere reading of this list of characters in their various combinations is in itself highly suggestive to the trained imagination.

[COO 2011]

An Orson program resides on a series of one or more files. Each file is a series of zero or more lines. A line is a series of zero or more visible characters, ending with an unspecified series of one or more invisible characters called a newline. Except for newlines, invisible characters (like control characters and tabs) must not appear in Orson programs. A blank is considered to be a visible character. There may be limits on the number of files in a program, the number of characters in a file, the number of lines in a file, and the number of characters in a line.

2.1. Unicode.

Orson programs are written using a 31-bit character set. It includes the 21-bit Unicode character set [UNI 2006], which in turn includes the 7-bit ASCII character set [ANS 1986]. Characters not in the Unicode set are unspecified. Unicode specifies a nonnegative integer code and an official name for each of its characters. In this Report, codes are written as ‘U+’ followed by four or more radix 16 digits. Unicode does not specify notations, called glyphs, for its characters.
      Although any visible characters and newlines can appear in Orson programs, the language is defined using Unicode characters from the following table. The table shows a suggested glyph for each character, its code, and its official name. It also shows an unofficial name used by this Report, if it differs from the official name. For example, the glyph ‘α’ stands for the character whose code is U+03B1, whose official name is GREEK SMALL LETTER ALPHA, and whose unofficial name is Mathematical letter.

U+22A5

 UP TACK 

 Mathematical letter 

⋅

U+22C5

 DOT OPERATOR 

 

It is possible to write Orson programs using only visible ASCII characters (with codes between U+0020 and U+007E) and newlines, so Orson can be used on computers that do not support Unicode. Orson uses all visible ASCII characters except ‘%’ (U+0025 PERCENT SIGN) and ‘ ‘ ’ (U+0060 GRAVE ACCENT).
      This Report sometimes shows a blank as ‘␣’ to emphasize its presence. It always shows a quote ‘ " ’ in italics to avoid confusion with two apostrophes ‘ '' ’. To improve the appearance of Orson programs, this Report also shows Roman letters in boldface, in italics, and in ordinary type. However, these are considered to be identical, so that ‘x’, ‘x’, and ‘x’ are the same character.

2.2. Internationalization.

Some programming languages are intended to be international, so they are defined using letters from many different alphabets [GOS 1996]. However, Orson is defined using only the Roman letters of the English alphabet, and the Greek letters commonly used in mathematics [KNU 1986].
      Most programming languages (including Orson) use notations based on English words and phrases. They cannot be made international simply by letting them use letters from non-Roman alphabets. This would be possible only in programming languages like Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007] that are not based on English.
      English is perhaps the most widely spoken and written language [MCC 1987], and all programmers know some mathematics. Programs should therefore be written using English names and mathematical symbols. No chauvinism is intended: the present status of English is due to historical accidents, not to any inherent superiority.

2.3. Normalization.

In Unicode, a single glyph may be represented in many different ways. For example, the following table shows possible representations for the glyphs ‘Ω’, ‘Ë’ and ‘ḉ’.

 Glyph 

 Representation 

Ω

 U+03A9 GREEK CAPITAL LETTER OMEGA

Ω

 U+2126 OHM SIGN

Ë

 U+00CB LATIN CAPITAL LETTER E WITH DIAERESIS

Ë

 U+0045 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER E 
 U+0308 COMBINING DIAERESIS

ḉ

 U+1E09 LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CEDILLA AND ACUTE 

ḉ

 U+0063 LATIN SMALL LETTER C 
 U+0301 COMBINING ACUTE ACCENT 
 U+0327 COMBINING CEDILLA

ḉ

 U+0063 LATIN SMALL LETTER C 
 U+0327 COMBINING CEDILLA 
 U+0301 COMBINING ACUTE ACCENT

Unicode supports multiple representations like these to make it compatible with earlier character sets, such as extended versions of ASCII. Unfortunately, multiple representations can make reading Unicode files difficult. To avoid these difficulties, files can be normalized so that each glyph has a unique representation.
      There are algorithms that perform this normalization automatically [UNI 2006]. However, Orson does not normalize its program files. Although this simplifies the language, it also allows writing programs with ambiguous glyphs that look the same, but are represented differently. Orson programs should be written to avoid such glyphs unless they are intended.

3. Tokens.

I am sent in all haste to espy and to marke 
How our letters and tokens are likely to warke.

[UDA 1935]

Orson groups the characters of each line in a file into tokens. It considers a file to be a series of tokens, not a series of characters or a series of lines. If there is more than one way to group characters into a token, then Orson groups them to produce the token with the maximum number of characters. There is no limit on the number of characters in a token, but each token must fit on a single line.
      Tokens may be separated by zero or more blanks and newlines, called whitespace. Whitespace is ignored, so that Orson programs may be indented to reflect their logical structure. There are many ways to indent Orson programs. The way used in this Report is recommended, but not required.
      There are nine kinds of tokens, called comment tokens, name tokens, integer tokens, real tokens, character tokens, string tokens, hook tokens, symbol tokens, and other tokens. They are described in the next few sections of this Report.

3.1. Comment tokens.

Comments are ignored; they add explanatory text to a program. Each comment begins with an exclamation, is followed by zero or more unnormalized visible characters without newlines, and ends with a newline. For example:

! 
!! 
!  How commentators each dark passage shun—Edward Young (1683–1765). 
!  Alphabetize by doing an inorder traversal of the binary tree "木". 
!  Warning! This procedure will delete all your files.

A comment may appear anywhere that a newline may appear. Adding or removing a comment does not affect the evaluation of an Orson program in any way. As a result, Orson cannot use comments as pragmas [KER 1988] that advise how a program is to be evaluated.

3.2. Name tokens.

Names may be bound to expressions and objects, along with their types. Names may also appear as parts of some types. There are three kinds of names, called plain names, quoted names, and secret names.

3.2.1. Plain names.

A plain name starts with a lower case Roman letter or a mathematical letter. It is followed by zero or more apostrophes, digits, mathematical letters, Roman letters, and subscripts. In this Report, the Roman letters of plain names are written using italic type. For example, ∅, a, b₂, can't, Δ, equal, fiftySeven, g', henryThe8th, isLetter, and jump are plain names.

3.2.2. Quoted names.

A quoted name starts with a quote, is followed by zero or more unnormalized visible characters other than quotes, and ends with another quote. The quotes are considered to be part of the name. In this Report, the Roman letters of quoted names are written using ordinary type. For example, "", "a", "₂b", "can't", "Δ", "=", "57", "dg/dx", "Henry VIII", "это письмо?", and "狘" are quoted names. Quoted names should not be confused with character tokens or string tokens, which are written in similar (but different) ways.

3.2.3. Secret names.

A secret name starts with an upper case Roman letter. It is followed by zero or more apostrophes, digits, mathematical letters, Roman letters, and subscripts. In this Report, the Roman letters of secret names are written using italic type. For example, A, B₂, Can't, Delta, Equal, FiftySeven, G', HenryThe8th, IsLetter, and JUMP are secret names. The plain names ∀ and Ω are not secret names, because they do not start with upper case Roman letters. The quoted name "A" is not a secret name, because it starts with a quote.

3.2.4. Identical names.

Two names are identical if they have the same unnormalized characters, in the same order. Upper and lower case letters are considered to be different, and the quotes in a quoted name are considered to be part of the name. As a result, x, X, "x", and "X" are four different names.
      There are two exceptions to this rule. The first is that two or more adjacent blanks in a quoted name are treated as a single blank. This lets quoted names be easily distinguished without having to count their blanks. For example, "x␣y", "x␣␣y", and "x␣␣␣y" are identical, but "xy", "␣xy", "x␣y", and "xy␣" are different. The second exception is that otherwise identical secret names are treated as being different when they appear in different prog clauses. This lets each prog clause have its own secret names, different from those in any other prog clause.

3.2.5. Unique names.

Orson sometimes creates unique names that are not identical to any other names in a program. A unique name might consist of an unspecified character ‘¢’ that can appear only in names created by Orson, followed by a number. Whenever a new unique name is needed, the number is incremented, resulting in ¢0, ¢1, ¢2, etc. Unique names are similar to the gensyms of the programming language Common Lisp [STE 1990].

3.3. Integer tokens.

Integer tokens denote nonnegative integers. They can be written in any radix from 2 to 36. A radix 10 integer token starts with a digit, and is followed by zero or more additional digits. For example, 0, 11, 7734, and 0123456789 are all radix 10 integer tokens.
      An integer token can also start with one or more digits that denote its radix, followed by a sharp ‘#’, followed by one or more digits and Roman letters which denote an integer in that radix. Digits have the values 0 through 9, and Roman letters have the values 10 through 35, with upper and lower case letters considered identical. If an integer token starts with a sharp, then radix 16 is assumed. For example, the integer token 7734 may be written in radix 2 as 2#1111000110110, in radix 8 as 8#17066, in radix 10 as 7734 and 10#7734, or in radix 16 as 16#1E36, 16#1e36, #1E36, and #1e36.
      Integer tokens in any radix may include underlines ‘_’, which are ignored. For example, 123456789 may also be written as 123_456_789, and 2#1111000110110 may also be written as 2#0001_1110_0011_0110.

3.4. Real tokens.

Real tokens denote nonnegative real numbers. They can be written only in radix 10. A real token is a series of one or more digits, followed by a dot, followed by one or more additional digits. It may also include underlines ‘_’, which are ignored. For example, 0.5, 7734.40, and 3.141_592_654 are all real tokens.
      A real token can be followed by an optional scale factor. A scale factor starts with the Roman letter e or E, followed by an optional sign ‘+’, ‘-’, or ‘−’, followed by a series of one or more digits. The scale factor indicates multiplication by a power of 10. For example, the real token 100000.0 may also be written as 1.0E5, 1.0E+5, 1.0e5, and 1.0e+5. Similarly, the real token 0.00001 may also be written as 1.0E-5, 1.0E−5, 1.0e-5, and 1.0e−5.

3.5. Character tokens.

Character tokens denote characters. A character token starts with an apostrophe, followed by a single visible character other than an apostrophe, and ends with another apostrophe. For example, '␣', '!', '"', '+', '7', 'A', 'b', 'φ', and '字' are character tokens. A slashed character can appear between the apostrophes instead of an ordinary character. Character tokens should not be confused with quoted name tokens or with string tokens, which are written in similar (but different) ways.

3.6. String tokens.

String tokens denote strings. A string token starts with two apostrophes, followed by a series of zero or more unnormalized visible characters without two adjacent apostrophes, and ends with two more apostrophes. For example, '''', ''␣'', ''''', ''+'', ''7734'', ''A'', ''b₂'', ''characters'', ''Dogpack Asmodeus Bozart'', ''Enter "刅" to begin!'', ''Φ(2π)'', ''Georges'', ''George's'', ''Georges''', and ''письмена'' are string tokens. Any or all of the characters between the pairs of apostrophes can be slashed characters instead of ordinary characters. String tokens should not be confused with character tokens or with quoted name tokens, which are written in similar (but different) ways.

3.7. Slashed characters.

Any or all of the characters in character tokens and string tokens can be written as slashed characters. Slashed characters are often used to denote invisible characters that must not appear explicitly in Orson programs. There are two kinds of slashed characters. The first kind consists of a backslash followed by one of the characters shown in the table.

  Slashed  

  Code  

  Official Name  

  Unofficial Name  

\0

 U+0000 

 CONTROL 

 Null 

\A or \a

 U+0007 

 CONTROL 

 Alert 

\B or \b

 U+0008 

 CONTROL 

 Backspace 

\E or \e

 U+001B 

 CONTROL 

 Escape 

\F or \f

 U+000C 

 CONTROL 

 Formfeed 

\N or \n

 U+000A 

 CONTROL 

 Linefeed 

\R or \r

 U+000D 

 CONTROL 

 Return 

\T or \t

 U+0009 

 CONTROL 

 Horizontal tab 

\V or \v

 U+000B 

 CONTROL 

 Vertical tab 

\'

 U+0027 

 APOSTROPHE 

 

\\

 U+005C 

 REVERSE SOLIDUS 

 Backslash 

For example, the character tokens '\T' and '\t' both denote a horizontal tab, with the code U+0009. The character token '\'' denotes an apostrophe, with the code U+0027. The string token ''Hello␣world!\n'' contains a linefeed, with the code U+000A, and the string token ''\\'' contains a backslash, with the code U+005C.
      The second kind of slashed character starts with a backslash and a sharp, followed by a radix 16 integer code between 0 and 7FFFFFFF (2147483647). The code can contain underlines, which are ignored. For example, the character token '\#3B1' is equivalent to the character token 'α', with the code U+03B1. The string token ''Hello␣world!\#0A'' contains a linefeed character, with the code U+000A.
      A character code may be followed by a backslash and an underline. This is sometimes necessary in a string token to separate the code from other characters. For example, the string token ''\#7734'' has two characters: '\#7734' and '\0'. However, the string token ''\#77\_34'' has four characters: '\#77', '3', '4', and '\0'.

3.8. Hook tokens.

Hook tokens denote hooks. Each hook token starts with a question mark ‘?’, followed by a plain name. (Question marks are shaped like hooks.) For example, ?∅, ?a, ?b₂, ?equal, ?fiftySeven, ?g', ?henryThe8th, ?isLetter and ?jump are hook tokens.

3.9. Symbol tokens.

Symbol tokens denote symbol types. A symbol token starts with a dollar sign ‘$’, optionally followed by a name. (The first letter of the word symbol looks like a dollar sign.) For example, $, $∅, $A, $beeToo, $"=", $lvii, $G', $"Henry #1000", $IsLetter and $"狘" are symbol tokens.

3.10. Other tokens.

Orson uses various other tokens as delimiters, operators, and syntactic markers. Thirty of these, called keywords, are composed of lower case Roman letters, as shown below. In this Report, keywords appear in bold type.

also

    

do

    

in

    

or

    

then

alt

    

else

    

load

    

past

    

tuple

alts

    

for

    

mod

    

proc

    

type

and

    

form

    

none

    

prog

    

var

case

    

gen

    

not

    

ref

    

while

catch

    

if

    

of

    

row

    

with

Although keywords resemble plain names, they are not names, and should not be confused with them. For example, form is a keyword, but Form, FORM, form', and "form" are names. Some tokens are made up of ASCII mathematical and punctuation characters, as shown below.

(   

)   

[   

]   

{   

}   

    

    

    

    

<   

<=   

<>   

=   

>   

>=   

    

    

    

    

&   

⁎   

+   

-   

/   

<<   

>>   

|   

~

⁎=   

+=   

-=   

/=   

<<=   

>>=   

|=   

~=   

    

$   

,   

.   

:   

:-   

:=   

;   

?   

@   

^   

Also, some tokens contain Unicode mathematical and punctuation characters.

:−   

¬   

↑   

↓   

∧   

∨

⊕=   

⊖=   

⊗=   

⊘=   

⊙=   

    

    

    

    

∊   

∍   

≠   

≡   

≢   

≤   

≥   

≺   

≻   

≼   

≽   

⊂   

⊃   

⊆   

⊇   

⊏   

⊐   

⊑   

⊒   

A few ASCII tokens are synonyms for Unicode tokens. For example, the token ‘:-’ is a synonym for the token ‘:−’, the token and is a synonym for the token ‘∧’, and the token or is a synonym for the token ‘∨’. The standard prelude also defines the quoted names of some operators, like "<=" and "≤", to be synonyms.

4. Types.

The higher its type, always the seldomer doth a thing succeed.

[NIE 1954]

Objects are the data that are manipulated during evaluation to perform computations. A type is an object that may describe another object; an instance is an object that is not a type. An object described by a type is said to have the type, or to be of the type. If an expression evaluates to an object of some type, then that expression is also said to have the type, or to be of the type. Every object has a type, and most objects have many types. Since types are themselves objects, types also have types.

4.1. Objects.

Evaluation occurs in two phases: first transformation, then execution. Some objects can exist during only one of these phases; others can exist during both. Each object is also either a type or an instance.
      An object is a transformation object if it can exist during transformation, and an execution object if it can exist during execution. A transformation type is a type that can exist during transformation. A transformation instance is an instance that can exist during transformation. An execution type is a type that can exist during execution. An execution instance is an instance that can exist during execution.
      An object is a pure transformation object if it can exist only during transformation, and a pure execution object if it can exist only during execution. A pure transformation type is a type that can exist only during transformation. A pure transformation instance is an instance that can exist only during transformation. A pure execution type is a type that can exist only during execution. A pure execution instance is an instance that can exist only during execution.
      The following table shows whether each object is a transformation object (T), an execution object (E), or both. For example, an alternate form type is a pure transformation type. A character instance is both a transformation instance and an execution instance. The table also shows the section in this Report where each object is discussed.

 Section 

Object

 T 

 E

✓

 7.1.9. 

 The void type. 

✓

✓

 7.1.9. 

 The void instance skip.  

✓

✓

Transformation objects are often called constants, because they are analogous to constants in other programming languages. However, this analogy is not perfect. For example, a list of expressions that return variables is a constant, because it is a pure transformation object, but a procedure is not a constant, because it is a pure execution object.
      The results of transformation can affect execution, but the results of execution cannot affect transformation. As a result, all pure transformation objects vanish before execution, and no pure execution objects exist until after transformation. Attempting to create a pure execution object during transformation, or attempting to create a pure transformation object during execution, is an error.

4.2. Subtypes.

Suppose that l and r are types. Also suppose that in every situation where an expression or object of type r is required, an expression or object of type l can be provided instead, without error. Then l is said to be a subtype of r [LIS 1994]. For example, in the sum a + b, the operator ‘+’ may require a and b to have the joker type inj, which describes all integers. As a result, integers of type int may be provided for a and b, because int is a subtype of inj.
      Each type is a subtype of itself. It may also be a subtype of many other types. Orson uses the notation l ⊆ r to mean that the type l is a subtype of the type r. It suggests that a type is mathematically a set of the objects it describes. An object has the type if it is a member of the set. An expression has the type if the object to which it evaluates is a member of the set.

4.3. Cotypes.

Suppose that l and r are types, but l is not a subtype of r. If there is a situation where an expression or object of type r is required, then one of type l cannot be provided instead without error. Before it can be provided, the expression or object of type l must be converted to one whose type is a subtype of r. In some situations, Orson performs this conversion automatically. This is called coercion; the converted expression or object is said to be coerced.
      If an expression or object of type l can be coerced to one of type r, then l is said to be a cotype of r. Each type is a cotype of itself, and any other type of which it is a subtype. It may also be a cotype of other types. Orson uses the notation l ⊑ r to mean that the type l is a cotype of the type r. It is similar to the notation used for subtypes.
      Suppose that e is an expression or object of type l, and that l is a cotype of r. Then this Report also uses the notation e⦃r⦄ to mean the result of coercing the expression or object e so its type is a subtype of r. It is similar to Orson’s notation for casts. Orson computes e⦃r⦄ in two ways, called restrictive coercion and permissive coercion.

Restrictive coercion. Orson uses restrictive coercion in situations where the required type r is an execution type. In restrictive coercion, e⦃r⦄ is an expression or object that is computed from e, and whose type is exactly the type r. This kind of coercion is used in most other programming languages.
      For example, suppose that e has the integer type int0, so it is represented in one byte. Also suppose that e is coerced to the type int1, so it is represented in two bytes. Then e⦃int1⦄ is the same integer as e, but represented in two bytes, with exactly the type int1. Similarly, suppose that e is an integer variable of type var int1. Also suppose that e is coerced to the type int1. Then e⦃int1⦄ is an expression that returns the integer value of e, with exactly the type int1.

Permissive coercion. Orson uses permissive coercion when the required type r is not an execution type. In permissive coercion, e⦃r⦄ is an expression or object that is computed from e, and whose type is a subtype of r. This kind of coercion is not used in most other programming languages.
      For example, suppose that e has the integer type int0. Also suppose that e is coerced to the joker type inj, which describes all integers. Then e⦃inj⦄ is simply e unchanged, because its type int0 is a subtype of inj. Similarly, suppose that e is an integer variable of type var int1. Also suppose that e is coerced to the joker type inj. Then e⦃inj⦄ is an expression that returns the integer value of e, whose type int1 is a subtype of inj.

4.4. Compatibility.

Suppose that l and r are types. If l is a subtype of r, or l is a cotype of r, then l is said to be compatible with r. In this Report, formal rules decide if one type is compatible with another. There are at least two ways that such rules can be implemented in a programming language, called identifier compatibility and structure compatibility.
      In identifier compatibility, each type is given a unique identifier when it is created. Two types are then compatible if they have equal identifiers. One way to implement identifiers is to require that all types be given names, and then use the names as identifiers [JEN 1974]. Another way is to use the memory addresses of the objects that represent the types.
      In structure compatibility, a recursive algorithm decides if one type is compatible with another. If two types have no parts, then they are compatible if they are the same object, or if they satisfy some simple test. Otherwise, the types are compatible if each part of one type is compatible with some corresponding part of the other type.
      Identifier compatibility can be implemented very efficiently as an equality test on type identifiers. Unfortunately, if it is used, then apparently identical types created in different parts of a program cannot be compatible, because they will have different identifiers. As a result, each type has to be created exactly once, typically at the beginning of the program.
      Orson requires that apparently identical types behave the same way, no matter where they are created. It also requires that new types can be created anywhere in a program. In other words, it requires that types behave like all other objects. Orson therefore uses structure compatibility, although it also uses a kind of identifier compatibility with Skolem types.
      Under structure compatibility, binding a name to a type does not create a new type. It simply gives the type a new name. If a type has many names, then there may be conventions about how each name is used. For example, the standard prelude binds the names bool and int0 to the same integer type. As a result, bool and int0 could be used interchangeably. However, by convention, bool is used to describe objects that represent Booleans, and int0 is used to describe objects that represent integers.

4.5. Rules.

In this Report, compatibility rules for types are written in a formal notation similar to that used in type theory [CAR 1997], but simpler. If the p’s and q’s are logical statements about types, and r is an identifying number, then this is a rule.

p1, p2 ..., pj

 r

q1, q2 ..., qk

The q’s are called antecedents; the p’s are called consequents. The rule r says that if the q’s are true, then the p’s are also true.
      Some rules apply to all types. For example, rule 0 says that every type t is a subtype of itself. Rule 1 says that a type t is a cotype of a type T if t is a subtype of T.

t ⊆ t

 0

true

     

t ⊑ T

 1

t ⊆ T

Other rules apply only to specific types. For example, rule I says that an array type is a subtype of another array type if both types have the same length k, and the first type’s base type t is a subtype of the second type’s base type T. Rule II says that the integer type int0 is a subtype of the joker type inj. Rule III says that a variable type is a subtype of another variable type if the first type’s base type t is a subtype of the second type’s base type T.

[k] t ⊆ [k] T

 I

t ⊆ T

     

int0 ⊆ inj

 II

true

     

var t ⊆ var T

 III

t ⊆ T

Rules like these are used to construct proofs. The first step of a proof is a set of one or more statements to be proved. Suppose there is a rule whose consequents match some of these statements. Then the next step in the proof is deduced by replacing the matched statements with the rule’s corresponding antecedents, and deleting redundant statements. The rule is then said to have been applied. Repeatedly applying rules produces a tower of steps, with each step labeled by the number of the rule that deduced it, like this.

[10] var int0 ⊆ [10] var inj

  I

var int0 ⊆ var inj

  III

int0 ⊆ inj

  II

true

A statement is true if it is possible to construct a finite tower of steps in this way, starting with the statement on top, and ending with true on the bottom. If it is not possible to construct such a tower, then the statement is false.
      The following table summarizes all rules used in this Report. It shows the identifying number of each rule, the section of this Report in which it appears, and a brief description of what it does.

 Section 

 Rule 

 Description 

  4.5.

0

 Every type is a subtype of itself.

  4.5.

1

 A type is a cotype if it is a subtype.

4.6. Names as parts of types.

Some types are made up of smaller parts. For example, a tuple type like (tuple real re, real im) might describe a complex number. It has the type real and the names re and im as its parts. When Orson tests if one type is a subtype of another type, it compares all their parts, including their name parts. For example, (tuple real re, real im) is not a subtype of (tuple real ρ, real θ), because they have different names as parts.

4.6.1. Missing names.

Names can be omitted from some types in which they would otherwise appear as parts. A type with omitted names may describe an object with unused parts. For example, the tuple type (tuple real re, real) describes a tuple with two real parts, but the second real part is not used.
      When a name is omitted from a type, it is convenient to imagine that the missing name appears in its place. In this Report, the missing name sometimes appears as a dotted box ⬚ to emphasize its presence. For example, it is imagined that (tuple real re, real) is actually (tuple real re, real ⬚).

4.6.2. Subnames.

Suppose that l and r are names which are parts of types. If l is identical to r, or if r is the missing name ⬚, then l is a subname of r. Every name is therefore a subname of itself, and is also a subname of ⬚.
      When Orson tests if one type is a subtype of another type, it uses the subtype relation to compare their type parts, and the subname relation to compare their name parts. For example, the tuple type (tuple real re, real im) is a subtype of the tuple type (tuple real re, real ⬚), because the type real is a subtype of itself, the name re is a subname of itself, and the name im is a subname of ⬚.
      This Report uses symbol types to test if a name is a subname of another name. The name l is a subname of the name r if and only if the symbol type $l is a subtype of the symbol type $r.

4.6.3. Distinct names.

Two names are distinct if at least one of them is the missing name. If neither name is missing, then they are distinct if they are not identical. If a generic form type, a plain form type, a procedure type, or a tuple type has two or more names as parts, then each name must be distinct from all other names in that type.

4.7. Jokers.

A joker is a type that describes infinitely many objects, all of which share certain properties. A type is a subtype of a joker if all objects of that type have the properties described by the joker. For example, the joker inj describes all integers, so that any integer type is its subtype. Similarly, the joker rej describes all real numbers, so that any real type is its subtype.
      Any joker may have subtypes not described in this Report. As a result, if types are considered to be sets of objects, then no joker is necessarily the union of two or more other types. For example, the joker num describes all numbers, so that inj and rej are its subtypes. However, num is not necessarily the union of inj and rej, because Orson may also provide unspecified numeric types along with integer and real types.
      The name joker comes from card games [USP 1941] in which joker cards are said to be ‘‘wild,’’ so they match cards in somewhat the same way that jokers match types. Jokers, and all types that have jokers as parts, are pure transformation types.

4.8. Sizes.

Each type has a size. The size of an execution type is the number of bytes needed to represent an instance of that type in memory (it may be 0). The size of any other type is −1. If l and r are both execution types, and l is a subtype of r, then l and r have equal sizes. Orson uses the notation size(t) to mean the size of a type t.

5. Expressions.

Making useful objects is dreary work, but making them according to the mysterious laws of formal expression is halfway to happiness.

[BEL 1981]

Orson’s expressions are written with the infix, prefix, and postfix operators in the following table. Rows of the table are in order of increasing precedence, and operators in the same row have equal precedence. For example, the infix operators ‘+’ and ‘−’ have equal precedence, but both have higher precedence than the infix operator ‘ < ’. The table also includes notations like ‘ [ ] ’ that do not look like operators, but which are discussed along with them.

 Section 

Name

Place

Operators

 5.1.

 Sequence

 Infix

 also

 5.2.

 Subsequence 

 Infix

 ;

 5.3.

 Assignment

 Infix

 &=  ⁎=  /=  :=  <<=  >>=  +=  -=  |=  ~=  ×=  −= 
 ∘=  ∙=  ∩=  ∪=  ⊓=  ⊔=  ⊕=  ⊖=  ⊗=  ⊘=  ⊙=

 5.4.

 Disjunction

 Infix

 ∨  or

 5.5.

 Conjunction

 Infix

 ∧  and

 5.6.

 Comparison 

 Infix

 <  <=  <>  =  >  >=  ∊  ∍  ≠  ≡  ≢  ≤  ≥ 
 ≺  ≻  ≼  ≽  ⊂  ⊃  ⊆  ⊇  ⊏  ⊐  ⊑  ⊒

 5.7.

 Sum

 Infix

 +  -  |  ~  −  ∘  ∪  ⊔  ⊕  ⊖

 5.8.

 Product

 Infix

 &  ⁎  /  <<  >>  ←  →  ×  ∙  ∩  ⊓  ⊗  ⊘  ⊙  mod

 5.9.

 Term

 Prefix

 +  -  [ ]  { }  ~  −  ¬  ⊕  ⊖  not  ref  row  type  var 

 5.10.

 Unit

 Postfix 

 ( )  .  @  [ ]  ^  { }  ↑  ↓

Most expressions abbreviate calls to methods whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. For example, the sum l + r abbreviates the call "+"(l, r), the term − r abbreviates the call "−"(r), and the unit l ↑ abbreviates the call "↑"(l). Operators that abbreviate calls can be redefined by rebinding their names.
      Some expressions abbreviate calls to methods whose names are not bound by the standard prelude. They can be used only after their names are bound to methods. For example, binding "⊕" to an appropriate method allows using expressions like l ⊕ r and ⊕ r. They abbreviate the calls "⊕"(l, r) and "⊕"(r), respectively.
      The infix sequence operator, the assignment operators, and the comparison operators do not associate. All other infix operators associate to the left, so that l + m − r abbreviates (l + m) − r, which in turn abbreviates "−"("+"(l, m), r). All prefix operators associate to the right, so that ~ − r abbreviates ~ (− r), which in turn abbreviates "~"("−"(r)). All postfix operators associate to the left, so that l↑[] abbreviates (l↑)[], which in turn abbreviates "␣[]"("↑"(l)).

5.1. Sequences.

A sequence may be a subsequence. If l and r are subsequences, then l also r is a sequence as well. It abbreviates this with clause, where u is a unique name that appears nowhere else.

(with u :− (l) do r ; u)

As a result of the abbreviation, l also r first evaluates l, then evaluates r, and finally returns the object to which l evaluates. The type of the sequence is the type of l. Since r is evaluated only for its side effects during execution, it must have an execution type. For example, if v is an integer variable, then (v also v += 1) increments v and returns v’s previous value.
      To improve readability, a sequence with two or more also operators, like l also m also r, is prohibited. The prohibition can be avoided by using parentheses, but there is no need to do so, since an equivalent sequence can be written more clearly using only one also operator and a subsequence. For example, (l also m) also r and l also (m also r) can be written as (l also m ; r).

5.2. Subsequences.

A subsequence can be an assignment. If the e’s are two or more assignments, then the following is also a subsequence. An extra semicolon can appear after the last e.

e1 ; e2 ... ; ek

The subsequence evaluates its assignments, one at a time, in order of appearance. It returns the object to which its last assignment evaluates. The type of the subsequence is the type of its last assignment. For example, if v is an integer variable, then (v += 1 ; v) increments v and returns v’s new value.
      A subsequence transforms to a new subsequence that is made by transforming its assignments, one at a time, in order of appearance. All assignments but the last must have execution types, since they may be evaluated for their side effects during execution. If any assignment but the last transforms to an object, then it is omitted from the new subsequence. After transformation, if the new subsequence has exactly one assignment or object, then that assignment or object can have any type. If it has two or more, then the last must have an execution type.
      The transformed subsequence is executed by executing its assignments, one at a time, in order of appearance. It returns the object that results from executing its last assignment.

5.3. Assignments.

An assignment can be a disjunction. If l and r are disjunctions, then the expressions in the following table are also assignments. Some assignments abbreviate calls to forms whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. These forms are described in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

  Assignment  

Call

  7.3.4.

l &= r

"&="(l, r)

  7.3.6.

l ⁎= r

"⁎="(l, r)

  7.3.6.

l ×= r

"×="(l, r)

  7.3.8.

l += r

"+="(l, r)

  7.3.10.

l -= r

"-="(l, r)

  7.3.10.

l −= r

"−="(l, r)

  7.3.13.

l /= r

"/="(l, r)

  7.3.14.

l := r

":="(l, r)

  7.3.19.

l <<= r

"<<="(l, r)

  7.3.19.

l ←= r

"←="(l, r)

  7.3.29.

l >>= r

    ">>="(l, r)    

  7.3.29.

l →= r

"→="(l, r)

  7.3.37.

l |= r

"|="(l, r)

  7.3.39.

l ~= r

"~="(l, r)

 

l ∘= r

"∘="(l, r)

 

l ∙= r

"∙="(l, r)

 

l ∩= r

"∩="(l, r)

 

l ∪= r

"∪="(l, r)

 

l ⊓= r

"⊓="(l, r)

 

l ⊔= r

"⊔="(l, r)

 

l ⊕= r

"⊕="(l, r)

 

l ⊖= r

"⊖="(l, r)

 

l ⊗= r

"⊗="(l, r)

 

l ⊘= r

"⊘="(l, r)

 

l ⊙= r

"⊙="(l, r)

By convention, the names of assignment operators are bound to forms that change the values of variables as side effects. This Report also uses the word assignment to mean an expression that is not a sequence or a subsequence, even if it does not use an assignment operator. This is consistent with the terminology of Orson’s syntax.
      Assignment operators do not associate, so an assignment like l := m := r is prohibited. The prohibition may be avoided by using parentheses, as in l := (m := r). However, this is probably not useful, because the standard prelude binds the names of assignment operators to forms whose calls evaluate to skip.

5.4. Disjunctions.

A disjunction can be a conjunction. If the e’s are two or more conjunctions that evaluate to integers, then this expression is also a disjunction. The keyword or may appear instead of the symbol ‘∨’.

e1 ∨  e2 ... ∨ ek

The disjunction abbreviates the following nested with clauses and if clauses, in which u is a unique name that appears nowhere else. The with clauses ensure that each e is evaluated at most once.

(with inj u :− e1 
(do (if u  
(do (then u  
(do (else (with inj u :− e2 
(do (else (do (if u  
(do (else (do (then u  
(do (else (do (else ... (with inj u :− ek−1 
(do (else (do (else ... (do (if u  
(do (else (do (else ... (do (then u  
(do (else (do (else ... (do (else ek)) ... ))))

As a result of the abbreviation, the disjunction evaluates the e’s one at a time, in order of appearance. If some e evaluates to an integer other than 0, then the disjunction immediately evaluates to that integer, without evaluating the remaining e’s. If all the e’s evaluate to 0, then the disjunction also evaluates to 0.

5.5. Conjunctions.

A conjunction can be a comparison. If the e’s are two or more comparisons that evaluate to integers, then this expression is also a conjunction. The keyword and may appear instead of the symbol ‘∧’.

e1 ∧ e2 ... ∧ ek

The conjunction abbreviates this nested if clause.

(if e1 then (if e2 then ... (if ek−1 then ek else 0) ... else 0) else 0)

As a result of the abbreviation, the conjunction evaluates the e’s one at a time, in order of appearance. If some e evaluates to 0, then the conjunction immediately evaluates to 0, without evaluating the remaining e’s. If no e’s evaluate to 0, then the conjunction evaluates to the integer that is returned by the last e.

5.6. Comparisons.

A comparison can be a sum. If the e’s are two or more sums, and the ◇’s are one or more comparison operators ‘<’, ‘<=’, ‘<>’, ‘=’, ‘>’, ‘>=’, ‘∊’, ‘∍’, ‘≠’, ‘≡’, ‘≢’, ‘≤’, ‘≥’, ‘≺’, ‘≻’, ‘≼’, ‘≽’, ‘⊂’, ‘⊃’, ‘⊆’, ‘⊇’, ‘⊏’, ‘⊐’, ‘⊑’, or ‘⊒’, then this expression is also a comparison.

e1 ◇1 e2 ◇2 e3 ... ◇k−1 ek

The comparison abbreviates a call to a method whose quoted name is constructed by concatenating the names of the comparison operators, separated by blanks.

"◇1␣◇2 ... ␣◇k−1"(e1, e2, e3 ..., ek)

For example, l > r abbreviates ">"(l, r) and l < m ≤ r abbreviates "<␣≤"(l, m, r). The following table shows the comparison operators whose quoted names are bound to forms by the standard prelude. These forms are discussed in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

  Comparison  

  Call  

  7.3.15.

l < r

"<"(l, r)

  7.3.20.

l <= r

"<="(l, r)

  7.3.20.

l ≤ r

"≤"(l, r)

  7.3.23.

l <> r

"<>"(l, r)

  7.3.23.

l ≠ r

"≠"(l, r)

  7.3.24.

l = r

"="(l, r)

  7.3.25.

l > r

">"(l, r)

  7.3.30.

l >= r

">="(l, r)

  7.3.30.

l ≥ r

"≥"(l, r)

  7.3.16.

l < m < r

"<␣<"(l, m, r)

  7.3.17.

l < m <= r

"<␣<="(l, m, r)

  7.3.17.

l < m ≤ r

"<␣≤"(l, m, r)

  7.3.21.

l <= m < r

"<=␣<"(l, m, r)

  7.3.21.

l ≤ m < r

"≤␣<"(l, m, r)

  7.3.22.

l <= m <= r

"<=␣<="(l, m, r)

  7.3.22.

l ≤ m ≤ r

"≤␣≤"(l, m, r)

  7.3.26.

l > m > r

    ">␣>"(l, m, r)    

  7.3.27.

l > m >= r

">␣>="(l, m, r)

  7.3.27.

l > m ≥ r

">␣≥"(l, m, r)

  7.3.31.

l >= m > r

">=␣>"(l, m, r)

  7.3.31.

l ≥ m > r

"≥␣>"(l, m, r)

  7.3.32.

l >= m >= r

">=␣>="(l, m, r)

  7.3.32.

l ≥ m ≥ r

"≥␣≥"(l, m, r)

  7.3.74.

l ≼ r

"≼"(l, r)

  7.3.75.

l ⊆ r

"⊆"(l, r)

  7.3.64.

l ⊑ r

"⊑"(l, r)

5.7. Sums.

A sum can be a product. If l is a product and r is a sum, then the expressions in the following table are also sums. A few sums abbreviate calls to forms whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. These forms are described in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

    Sum    

     Call     

  7.3.7.

l + r

"+"(l, r)

  7.3.9.

l - r

"-"(l, r)

  7.3.9.

l − r

"−"(l, r)

  7.3.36.

l | r

"|"(l, r)

  7.3.38.

l ~ r

"~"(l, r)

 

l ∘ r

"∘"(l, r)

 

l ∪ r

"∪"(l, r)

 

l ⊔ r

"⊔"(l, r)

 

l ⊕ r

"⊕"(l, r)

 

l ⊖ r

"⊖"(l, r)

5.8. Products.

A product can be a term. If l is a term and r is a product, then the expressions in the following table are also products. Some products abbreviate calls to forms whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. These forms are described in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

    Product    

    Call    

  7.3.3.

  7.3.5.

  7.3.5.

  7.3.12.

  7.3.18.

  7.3.18.

5.9. Terms.

A term can be a unit. Suppose that the g’s are one or more terms, that the l’s are zero or more assignments, that the m’s are zero or more assignments, that the n’s are distinct names, that r is a term, that the t’s are zero or more terms, and that y is a term. Then the expressions in the following table are also terms. Some terms abbreviate calls to forms whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. These forms are described in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

Term

Call

  7.3.7.

+ r

"+"(r)

  7.3.9.

- r

"-"(r)

  7.3.9.

− r

"−"(r)

  7.3.34.

[l1, l2 ..., lj] r

"[]␣"(l1, l2 ..., lj, r)

 

[l1, l2 ..., lj : m1, m2 ..., mk] r

"[]␣"(l1, l2 ..., lj, (: m1, m2 ..., mk), r)

 

{l1, l2 ..., lj} r

"{}␣"(l1, l2 ..., lj, r)

 

{l1, l2 ..., lj : m1, m2 ..., mk} r

"{}␣"(l1, l2 ..., lj, (: m1, m2 ..., mk), r)

  7.3.38.

~ r

"~"(r)

  5.9.1.

form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y

 

  5.9.2.

gen (g11 n11, g12 n12 ..., g1j1 n1j1) 
gegen (g21 n21, g22 n22 ..., g2j2 n2j2) 
gege⋮ 
gegegen (gi1 ni1, gi2 ni2 ..., giji niji) 
gegegeform (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y

 

  5.9.4.

proc (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y

 

  7.3.43.

not r

"not"(r)

  7.3.43.

¬ r

"¬"(r)

  5.9.3.1.

ref r

 

  5.9.3.2.

row r

 

  5.9.5.

type r

 

  5.9.6.

var r

 

A colon lets some terms have the m’s as optional arguments. These arguments become the elements of a list, which in turn is passed as a single argument to a form. The form then obtains the optional arguments from the list.

5.9.1. Plain form types.

A plain form type is a term that transforms to the type of a plain form. A plain form itself is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Plain forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types. Each plain form type looks like this.

form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y

There are zero or more t n pairs in the plain form type, called parameters. They describe the arguments with which the plain form can be called. Each t is a term that transforms to a type called a parameter type, and each n is a name called a parameter name. The parameter names must be distinct from each other, and any or all of them may be missing. A parameter with the missing name ⬚ describes an unused argument. There may be a limit on the number of parameters in a plain form type. The term y transforms to a type called the yield type. It describes the expression or object to which the plain form call transforms.
      Rule 2 shows how a plain form type can be a subtype of another plain form type.

form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y ⊆ form (T1 N1, T2 N2 ..., Tk Nk) Y

 2

T1 ⊆ t1, $n1 ⊆ $N1, T2 ⊆ t2, $n2 ⊆ $N2 ..., Tk ⊆ tk, $nk ⊆ $Nk, y ⊆ Y

In the rule, both plain form types have the same number of parameters, k. Parameter types are compared in reverse [CAR 1997], so that each parameter type T on the right is a subtype of its corresponding parameter type t on the left. Each parameter name n on the left is a subname of its corresponding parameter name N on the right. The yield type y on the left is a subtype of the yield type Y on the right.
      For example, this proof shows that the plain form type form (inj l, var [] mut a) int is a subtype of the plain form type form (int, var [5] int) int. The proof uses array types, symbol types, the integer type int, the joker type inj, and the joker type mut.

form (inj l, var [] mut a) int ⊆ form (int ⬚, var [5] int ⬚) int

  2

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut, $a ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ int

  0

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut, $a ⊆ $⬚

  33

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut

  18

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, [5] int ⊆ [] mut

  74

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ mut

  54

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ sca

  66

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ num

  59

$l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ inj

  50

$l ⊆ $⬚

  33

true

A plain form type can also be a subtype of an alternate form type or a generic form type, and vice versa.

5.9.2. Generic form types.

A generic form type is a term that transforms to the type of a generic form. A generic form itself is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Generic forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types. Generic form types resemble plain form types, but they have one or more generic prefixes, each of which begins with the keyword gen.

gen (g11 n11, g12 n12 ..., g1j1 n1j1) 
gegen (g21 n21, g22 n22 ..., g2j2 n2j2) 
gege⋮ 
gegegen (gi1 ni1, gi2 ni2 ..., giji niji) 
gegegeform (t1 m1, t2 m2 ..., tk mk) y

Each generic prefix has one or more g n pairs, called generic parameters. Each g is a term that transforms to a type type called a generic type, and each n is a name called a generic name. None of the generic names may be missing. There may be limits on the number of generic prefixes and on the number of generic parameters in a generic form type.
      In the plain form type that follows the generic prefixes, there are zero or more t m pairs, called parameters. Each t is a term that transforms to a type called a parameter type, and each m is a name called a parameter name. Any or all of the parameter names may be missing. There may be a limit on the number of parameters in a generic form type. The term y transforms to a type called the yield type.
      Each generic prefix declares generic names that appear as units in the rest of the generic form type. The generic parameter g n declares that the generic name n has the generic type g. A generic name n may optionally appear as a unit in one or more generic types of the generic prefixes following the one that declares it. It must appear as a unit in one or more parameter types, and it may optionally appear as a unit in the yield type. All generic names and parameter names together in a generic form type must be distinct from each other.
      Just as in a plain form type, the parameters describe the arguments on which the generic form can be called, and the yield type describes the expression or object to which the call transforms. A parameter with the missing name describes an unused argument. Unlike a plain form type, however, the generic parameters describe relationships between parts of the arguments’ types. The generic form can be called only on arguments whose types have these relationships to each other.
      For example, the standard prelude binds the quoted name ":=" to a generic form that implements an assignment operator. Its type is equivalent to the following.

gen (type mut a) 
ggen (type a b) 
ggform (var a l, b r) void

When the generic form is called, the parameter name l must be bound to an expression or object of a variable type. The variable type’s base type a must have the type type mut, where the joker mut describes execution instances that can be the values of variables. In other words, the variable can have any base type. The parameter name r must be bound to an expression or object whose type b has the type type a. In other words, its type must be a subtype of the variable type’s base type. As a result, the generic form can be called with arguments of any compatible types, like var int and int. However, it is an error to call it with arguments of incompatible types, like var int and string.
      Unlike other types, generic form types contain unbound generic names, like a and b. Additional formal mechanisms are therefore needed to describe how generic form types are transformed, how they can be subtypes of other form types, how they can subsume other form types, and how their generic names can be bound. These mechanisms involve renaming, freedom, replacement, binders, and Skolemization, as described in the next few sections of this Report.

5.9.2.1. Renaming.

Suppose that two form types are compared to decide if one is a subtype of the other, or if one subsumes the other. Also suppose that at least one of the form types is a generic form type, or has a generic form type as a part. Then it is assumed that no two generic prefixes in those types declare identical generic names. If any generic names violate this assumption, then new unique names, appearing nowhere else, are temporarily substituted for them before the types are compared.
      For example, the following statement asserts that one generic form type is a subtype of another. Each type has a generic prefix that declares the same generic name t.

gen (type obj t) form (t n) t ⊆ gen (type mut t) form (t n) t

The simplest way to make sure that the types have no generic names in common is to substitute a unique name u for each generic name t, as shown below. Unique names are not substituted for parameter names like n.

gen (type obj u1) form (u1 n) u1 ⊆ gen (type mut u2) form (u2 n) u2

Orson automatically substitutes unique names for generic names whenever it is necessary, in an unspecified way. As a result, generic form types can use any generic names, regardless of how they may be compared.

5.9.2.2. Freedom.

An appearance of a name in a type is free if the name can be replaced by another type. Such replacement can occur during proofs and during transformations. Each appearance of a name is either free or not free. The following criteria determine if it is not free.
      Only names that appear as units can be free. As a result, the missing name is not free, the name in a hook is not free, and the name in a symbol type is not free. Generic names in a generic form type, parameter names in a generic form type, parameter names in a plain form type, parameter names in a procedure type, and slot names in a tuple type, are also not free.
      Suppose there is a generic form type with at least one generic prefix γ. Also suppose that γ has a generic parameter g n. Then the name n is not free where it appears as a unit in all generic prefixes that follow γ in the generic form type. It is also not free where it appears as a unit in the plain form type that follows the generic prefixes. For example, in the generic type gen (type a b) gen (type b c) form (a, b, c) d, the names a and d are free, but the names b and c are not free.

5.9.2.3. Replacement.

If the n’s are one or more distinct names, then this Report uses the following notation for a statement s in which each name appears free zero or more times.

s⟨n1, n2 ..., nk⟩

Also, this notation stands for a statement which is like s, except that free appearances of the n’s are simultaneously replaced by types, the t’s.

s⟨t1, t2 ..., tk⟩

For example, suppose that s⟨a, z⟩ is gen (type a z) form (z n) a ⊆ t, a statement about a generic form type. Then the name a appears free twice, so it can be replaced, but the name z appears free zero times, so it cannot be replaced. As a result, s⟨int, real⟩ is the new statement gen (type int z) form (z n) int ⊆ t, in which a is replaced by the type int, but z is not replaced by the type real.
      It is convenient to write a series of subscripted letters as a single bold letter, so the notations shown above can be written respectively as s⟨n⟩ and s⟨t⟩. The bold letter n stands for the n’s, and the bold letter t stands for the t’s.

5.9.2.4. Binders.

If n is a generic name and t is a type, then this Report uses the notation n ⇒ t to mean a binder. A binder is a statement asserting that a n will be bound to t, and that n’s type will be type t. The name n on the left side of the arrow is not free. However, names on the right side of the arrow, appearing as units in t, may be free. If they are free, then they may be replaced by types. For example, if b⟨n⟩ is the binder n ⇒ n, then b⟨int⟩ is the binder n ⇒ int, in which the free appearance of n is replaced by the type int.

5.9.2.5. Skolemization.

When a generic form type is transformed, or when it is proved to be a subtype of another type, its generic names may be temporarily replaced by Skolemized types. These are named for Thoralf Skolem (1887–1963), a Norwegian mathematician who showed how to replace certain variables of logical formulas in a similar way [END 1972]. Before describing Skolemized types, it is first necessary to describe Skolemizable types and Skolem types.

Skolemizable types. A type is Skolemizable if it has at least one subtype that is different from itself. For example, the joker type obj is Skolemizable, because it has infinitely many subtypes, all but one of which are different from itself. However, the integer type int0 is not Skolemizable, because its only subtype is itself.

Skolem types. If k is an integer, and t is a Skolemizable type, then this Report uses the notation ə(k, t) to mean a Skolem type. The integer k is called the Skolem type’s identifier, and the type t is called its base type. Each Skolem type denotes an arbitrary subtype of its base type. There is no need for a Skolem type whose base type is not Skolemizable, because it would be equivalent to its base type.
      Suppose that two Skolem types have the same base type. If they also have the same identifier, then they denote the same subtype of their base type. If they have different identifiers, then they may still denote the same subtype, or they may denote different subtypes. In either case, there is no way to tell exactly what subtypes they denote.
      Since a Skolem type denotes an arbitrary subtype of its base type, it is also a subtype of any other type for which its base type is a subtype, as in rule 3.

ə(k, t) ⊆ T

 3

t ⊆ T

Skolem types are themselves Skolemizable. This is because each Skolem type ə(k, t) has a subtype ə(j, ə(k, t)) that is different from itself, as shown in this proof.

ə(j, ə(k, t)) ⊆ ə(k, t)

  3

ə(k, t) ⊆ ə(k, t)

  0

true

If t is a transformation type, then ə(k, t) is also a transformation type; if t is an execution type, then ə(k, t) is also an execution type. The size of a Skolem type is the same as that of its base type: size(ə(k, t)) = size(t).
      Orson temporarily eliminates generic names from generic types by replacing them with new Skolem types. Each new Skolem type has an identifier which is different from that of any other Skolem type. Orson might create these identifiers by incrementing a hidden counter. As a result, each new Skolem type denotes a type which is potentially different from that denoted by any other Skolem type.

Skolemized types. Suppose that type θ T n is a generic parameter in a generic form type, where θ is a series of zero or more type prefixes, T is a type with no type prefixes, and n is a name. Also suppose that T contains no free generic names. Then appearances of n in the generic form type may be replaced by a Skolemized type S that is constructed from type θ T. If T is Skolemizable, then S is θ ə(k, T), with a new identifier k that appears in no other Skolem type. If T is not Skolemizable, then S is simply θ T.
      The Skolemized type S can replace the generic name n without error, because S has the same type as n. This is proved in the following way. An object e has a type t if and only if type e is a subtype of t. As a result, type S ought to be a subtype of n’s type, which is type θ T. This is true if S is θ ə(k, T), as shown on the left. It is also true if S is θ T, as shown on the right.

type θ ə(k, T) ⊆ type θ T

  17

⋮
ə(k, T) ⊆ T

  3

T ⊆ T

  0

true

     

type θ T ⊆ type θ T

  0

true

The three dots are meant to suggest that rule 17 is applied as many times as necessary to remove the type prefixes.
      When a generic type is Skolemized, its first type prefix is removed, and any remaining type prefixes in θ are left outside the resulting new Skolem type. For example, if the type t is Skolemizable, then the generic type type type t is Skolemized to type ə(k, t). Treating type prefixes in this way makes it easy to Skolemize a Skolemized type again. For example, if type ə(k, t) is Skolemized again, it results in ə(j, ə(k, t)).

5.9.2.6. Generic transformation.

Transforming a generic form type presents problems, because it contains unbound generic names that ordinarily could not be transformed without errors. These problems are avoided by temporarily binding each generic name to a Skolem type during transformation. Suppose that this is a generic form type, in which each g transforms to a generic type, each n is a generic name, and f is a plain form type.

gen (g11 n11, g12 n12 ..., g1j1 n1j1) 
gegen (g21 n21, g22 n22 ..., g2j2 n2j2) 
gege⋮ 
gegegen (gi1 ni1, gi2 ni2 ..., giji niji) f

Then the generic form type is transformed in the following way. First, a new scope is entered, and all generic names in the generic type are made unbound. Next, in the first generic prefix, each generic parameter g n is transformed to a new generic parameter G n, and the generic name n is bound to the type S that results from Skolemizing G. The first generic prefix is then removed. This process is repeated with the remaining generic prefixes, in order of appearance, until all are removed.
      Now suppose that a generic parameter g n appeared in one of the prefixes. Then either no free generic names appeared in g, or else all free generic names in g were bound to Skolemized types by earlier generic prefixes. As a result, when g was transformed to a new generic type G, all free generic names in g were replaced in G by the Skolemized types to which they were bound.
      After the generic prefixes have been removed, only the plain form type f remains. All free generic names in f were bound to Skolemized types by the generic prefixes. As a result, when f is transformed to a new plain form type F, all free generic names in f are replaced in F by the Skolemized types to which they were bound.
      Finally, the generic prefixes are restored to F along with their transformed generic types. Each Skolemized type that was introduced during transformation is replaced by the generic name which was bound to it. The scope that was entered at the start of transformation is then exited, restoring the generic names to their original bindings. The result is this transformed generic form type.

gen (G11 n11, G12 n12 ..., G1j1 n1j1) 
gegen (G21 n21, G22 n22 ..., G2j2 n2j2) 
gege⋮ 
gegegen (Gi1 ni1, Gi2 ni2 ..., Giji niji) F

In the transformed generic form type, each generic name must appear at least once as a unit in F’s parameter types. This ensures that all generic names can be bound if a generic form of this type is called.

Example. The standard prelude binds the quoted name ":=" to a generic form that implements an assignment operator. Its type is equivalent to the following.

gen (type mut a) 
ggen (type a b) 
ggform (var a l, b r) void

This generic form type is transformed in the following way. First, a new scope is entered, and the generic names a and b are made unbound. Suppose that the result of transforming the joker type mut is the hook ?mut. Then the generic type type mut is transformed to type ?mut, and the generic name a is bound to the type ə(0, ?mut) that results from Skolemizing it. The first generic prefix is then removed, leaving the following generic form type.

gen (type a b) 
gform (var a l, b r) void

Using the binding for a established by the previous generic prefix, the generic type type a is transformed to type ə(0, ?mut), and the generic name b is bound to the type ə(1, ə(0, ?mut)) that results from Skolemizing it. The second generic prefix is then removed, leaving the following plain form type.

form (var a l, b r) void

The plain form type is now transformed. As a result of transformation, a is replaced by its binding ə(0, ?mut), and b is replaced by its binding ə(1, ə(0, ?mut)). Suppose that the result of transforming the yield type void is written as the hook ?void. Then the plain form type looks like this.

form (var ə(0, ?mut) l, ə(1, ə(0, ?mut)) r) ?void

Now the generic prefixes are restored, along with their transformed generic parameter types.

gen (type ?mut a) 
ggen (type ə(0, ?mut) b) 
ggform (var ə(0, ?mut) l, ə(1, ə(0, ?mut)) r) ?void

Finally, each Skolemized type is replaced by the generic name that was bound to it, so ə(0, ?mut) is replaced by a, and ə(1, ə(0, ?mut)) is replaced by b. The generic form’s scope is then exited, restoring a and b to their original bindings. The transformed generic form type looks like this.

gen (type ?mut a) 
ggen (type a b) 
ggform (var a l, b r) ?void

Throughout this process, each generic name was bound to a Skolemized type before being transformed. The Skolemized type has properties like those of the actual type to which the name would be bound in a generic form call. This lets generic form types and parameter types be arbitrary terms in which generic names appear as units. In particular, they can be calls to forms that return types.

5.9.2.7. Generic rules.

To formally describe generic form types, the rules that are used elsewhere in this Report are extended so they can describe generic names. Suppose that the a’s, b’s, p’s, and q’s are statements about types, and that r is an identifying number. Then this is an extended rule.

a1, a2 ..., am | p1, p2 ..., pj

 r

b1, b2 ..., bn | q1, q2 ..., qk

The b’s and q’s are called antecedents; the a’s and p’s are called consequents. As in previous rules, the the extended rule r says that if the b’s and q’s are true, then the a’s and p’s are also true. However, statements on opposite sides of the separator ‘|’ play different roles in proofs. The p’s and q’s on the right of the separator can replace free generic names by types, but the a’s and b’s on the left of the separator cannot.
      If a proof step has a separator ‘|’, then an extended rule can be applied to both sides of the step at once. An unextended rule can be applied to statements on the right side of the separator, leaving those on the left side unchanged. It can also be applied to statements on the left side, leaving those on the right side unchanged, but only if the right side is true. As a result, statements on the left side can be proved only after those on the right have replaced all their free generic names by types.
      Extended and unextended rules may be applied together to prove statements about types. A statement is true if it is possible to construct a finite tower of steps in this way, starting with the statement on top, and ending with true, or with true | true, on the bottom. If it is not possible to construct such a tower, then the statement is false.

5.9.2.8. Generic subtyping.

Suppose that t and T are form types, at least one of which is a generic form type. Then the following extended rules are an algorithm that decides if t is a subtype of T. The algorithm assumes that t and T have no generic names in common.

Mark generic prefixes. In the first step of the algorithm, each generic prefix in t is marked with a superscript R, indicating that the generic names it declares will be replaced by parts of T’s parameter types. These generic prefixes are called replacing prefixes. Each generic prefix in T is marked with a superscript S, indicating that the generic names it declares will be replaced by Skolemized types. These generic prefixes are called Skolemizing prefixes.

Add a separator. The second step is to add a separator ‘|’, as in rule 4. This lets other rules add statements about generic names to the left side of the separator.

t ⊆ T

 4

true | t ⊆ T

Remove generic prefixes. In the third step, all generic prefixes are removed from t and T. Rules 5 and 6 each remove a replacing prefix and add equivalent statements about its generic names to the left side of the separator ‘|’. Initially, all replacing prefixes are on the left side of the subtype relation ⊆, but they might be moved to the right side by rule 2 if they appear as parts of parameter types.

a1, a2 ..., aj | genR (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f ⊆ T

 5

a1, a2 ..., aj, type n1 ⊆ g1, type n2 ⊆ g2 ..., type nk ⊆ gk | f ⊆ T

a1, a2 ..., aj | t ⊆ genR (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) F

 6

a1, a2 ..., aj, type n1 ⊆ g1, type n2 ⊆ g2 ..., type nk ⊆ gk | t ⊆ F

Similarly, rules 7 and 8 each remove a Skolemizing prefix, and replace free appearances of the generic names it declares by Skolemized types. Each s is the result of Skolemizing its corresponding generic type g. Initially, all Skolemizing prefixes are on the right side of the subtype relation ⊆, but they might be moved to the left side by rule 2 if they appear as parts of parameter types.

genS (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f⟨n1, n2 ..., nk⟩ ⊆ T

 7

f⟨s1, s2 ..., sk⟩ ⊆ T

t ⊆ genS (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) F⟨n1, n2 ..., nk⟩

 8

t ⊆ F⟨s1, s2 ..., sk⟩

Replace generic names. By the fourth step, only a statement about plain form types remains on the right side of the separator ‘|’. Rules defined elsewhere in this Report are now applied in an attempt to prove the statement. Suppose that as a result of applying these rules, a statement n ⊆ t or t ⊆ n appears on the right of the separator, where n is a generic name, and t is a type with no free generic names. Then n is replaced throughout by t, as in rules 9 and 10.

a1⟨n⟩, a2⟨n⟩ ..., aj⟨n⟩ | b1⟨n⟩, b2⟨n⟩ ..., bk⟨n⟩, n ⊆ t

 9

a1⟨t⟩, a2⟨t⟩ ..., aj⟨t⟩ | b1⟨t⟩, b2⟨t⟩ ..., bk⟨t⟩

a1⟨n⟩, a2⟨n⟩ ..., aj⟨n⟩ | b1⟨n⟩, b2⟨n⟩ ..., bk⟨n⟩, t ⊆ n

 10

a1⟨t⟩, a2⟨t⟩ ..., aj⟨t⟩ | b1⟨t⟩, b2⟨t⟩ ..., bk⟨t⟩

Generic form types as generic types. The algorithm needs an optional fifth step to deal with generic form types that appear as generic types. For example, the following generic form type describes a higher-order form whose argument is another form. The argument’s type is described by a generic form type (in parentheses).

gen (type (gen (type obj t) form (t) t) n) form (n a) void

When applied to this type, the rules discussed previously will place a statement about the generic form type gen (type obj t) form (t) t on the left side of the separator ‘|’. However, the rules assume that all statements about generic form types will appear on the right side, so their generic names can be replaced by types. The solution is to introduce rules 11 and 12 that moves statements about generic form types from the left side to the right side. The superscript P stands for either R or S.

a1, a2 ..., aj, genP (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f ⊆ T | true

 11

a1, a2 ..., aj | genP (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f ⊆ T

a1, a2 ..., aj, t ⊆ genP (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) F | true

 12

a1, a2 ..., aj | t ⊆ genP (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) F
