These rules cannot be applied to the left side until the right side has been proved true. At that point in the proof, all free generic names in generic form types on the left side will have been replaced. Once a generic form type appears on the right of the separator ‘|’, the rules of the subtype algorithm are applied to it again.

Example. The standard prelude binds the quoted name ":=" to a generic form that implements an assignment operator. Its type is equivalent to the following.

gen (type mut a) 
ggen (type a b) 
ggform (var a l, b r) void

When the generic form is called, its parameter l must be bound to an expression of some variable type. Its parameter r must be bound to an expression whose type is a subtype of the variable type’s base type. Now suppose that there is another version of this generic form which uses the joker type inj instead of mut, so it can assign values only to integer variables. It has this type.

gen (type inj c) 
ggen (type c d) 
ggform (var c l, d r) void

Since inj is (indirectly) a subtype of mut, it should always be possible to call a form of the first type with the same arguments as a form of the second type. As a result, the first type should be a subtype of the second type. This can be proved in the following way. (The two types have no generic names in common, so no renaming is needed.)

genR (type mut a) genR (type a b) form (var a l, b r) void ⊆
genS (type inj c) genS (type c d) form (var c l, d r) void

  4

true |
genR (type mut a) genR (type a b) form (var a l, b r) void ⊆
genS (type inj c) genS (type c d) form (var c l, d r) void

  5

type a ⊆ type mut |
genR (type a b) form (var a l, b r) void ⊆
genS (type inj c) genS (type c d) form (var c l, d r) void

  5

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
form (var a l, b r) void ⊆
genS (type inj c) genS (type c d) form (var c l, d r) void

  8

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
form (var a l, b r) void ⊆
genS (type ə(0, inj) d) form (var ə(0, inj) l, d r) void

  8

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
form (var a l, b r) void ⊆ form (var ə(0, inj) l, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) r) void

  2

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
var ə(0, inj) ⊆ var a, $l ⊆ $l, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b, $r ⊆ $r, void ⊆ void

  0

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
var ə(0, inj) ⊆ var a, $l ⊆ $l, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b, $r ⊆ $r

  0

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
var ə(0, inj) ⊆ var a, $l ⊆ $l, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b

  0

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
var ə(0, inj) ⊆ var a, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b

  18

type a ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type a |
ə(0, inj) ⊆ a, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b

  10

type ə(0, inj) ⊆ type mut, type b ⊆ type ə(0, inj) |
ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ b

  10

type ə(0, inj) ⊆ type mut, type ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ type ə(0, inj) | true

  17

ə(0, inj) ⊆ mut, type ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ type ə(0, inj) | true

  17

ə(0, inj) ⊆ mut, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ ə(0, inj) | true

  3

inj ⊆ mut, ə(1, ə(0, inj)) ⊆ ə(0, inj) | true

  3

inj ⊆ mut, ə(0, inj) ⊆ ə(0, inj) | true

  0

inj ⊆ mut | true

  54

inj ⊆ sca | true

  66

inj ⊆ num | true

  59

inj ⊆ inj | true

  0

true | true

Because the proof ends with true | true, the first generic type is indeed a subtype of the second.

5.9.2.9. Multiple generic names.

Suppose that it is necessary to test if a generic form type is a subtype of another form type. Also suppose that a generic name n appears many times in the generic form type’s parameter types, so it can be replaced in many ways. Then the generic form type may be a subtype of the other form type when n is replaced in some ways, but not in others. This is shown in the following example proof, which begins with these steps.

genR (type obj n) form (n ⬚, n ⬚) void ⊆ form (int ⬚, obj ⬚) void

  4

true | genR (type obj n) form (n ⬚, n ⬚) void ⊆ form (int ⬚, obj ⬚) void

  5

type n ⊆ type obj | form (n ⬚, n ⬚) void ⊆ form (int ⬚, obj ⬚) void

  2

type n ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ n, obj ⊆ n, $⬚ ⊆ $⬚, void ⊆ void

  0

type n ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ n, obj ⊆ n, $⬚ ⊆ $⬚

  0

type n ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ n, obj ⊆ n
⋮

At this point, the generic name n could be replaced either by the type int, or by the joker type obj. If n is replaced by int, then the proof fails, because obj is not a subtype of int.

⋮
type n ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ n, obj ⊆ n

  10

type int ⊆ type obj | obj ⊆ int

However, if n is replaced by obj instead, then the proof succeeds, because int is a subtype of obj.

⋮
type n ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ n, obj ⊆ n

  10

type obj ⊆ type obj | int ⊆ obj

  61

type obj ⊆ type obj | true

  0

true | true

Orson resolves this ambiguity by replacing generic names in the order that they appear in a generic form’s parameter types. As a result, the leftmost possible free appearance of a generic name in the parameter types determines how the name is replaced. In the example, the leftmost appearance of n is replaced by int, so the proof fails.
      This convention for replacing generic names might be changed in future versions of Orson. If possible, a generic form type should therefore be written so that each of its generic names appears exactly once in its parameter types. A generic name should appear more than once only if it does not matter which of its appearances is replaced first.

5.9.3. Pointer types.

A pointer type describes a pointer. A pointer itself is the address of an execution instance in memory. The instance’s type is called the pointer’s base type. The pointer is said to reference or point to the instance; the instance can be obtained by dereferencing the pointer. It is also possible for a pointer to reference no instance, or to reference an undefined instance, so that dereferencing it is an error.
      Suppose that a pointer references an instance. Then a pointer to a different instance, but of the same base type, may be obtained by adding an integer to the pointer, or by subtracting an integer from the pointer. Programs that use such pointer arithmetic are often efficient, but they may also erroneously create pointers which do not reference instances. Programs that do not use pointer arithmetic might therefore be safer than those that do.
      There are three kinds of pointers. Row pointers can reference instances, and can be computed by pointer arithmetic. Ref pointers can reference instances, but cannot be computed by pointer arithmetic. Null pointers cannot reference instances, and also cannot be computed by pointer arithmetic.
      All pointers are totally ordered. Suppose that l and r are pointers, possibly of different types. Then either l is less than r, l is equal to r, or l is greater than r. Orson might test the ordering of two pointers by first converting them to nonnegative integers, then comparing those integers.
      All pointer types have the same size, an unspecified small positive integer. A pointer type does not necessarily have the same size as any integer type, or the same size as any procedure type.

5.9.3.1. Ref types.

Suppose that the term t transforms to the type of an execution instance. Then the term ref t transforms to the type of a ref pointer whose base type is t. Orson tests if a ref type is a subtype of another ref type by comparing their base types, as in rule 13.

ref t ⊆ ref T

 13

t ⊆ T

Ref pointers are pure execution instances; their types are both transformation and execution types.

5.9.3.2. Row types.

Suppose that the term t transforms to the type of an execution instance. Then the term row t transforms to the type of a row pointer whose base type is t. Row pointers are so named because they can reference a row of elements in an array. Orson tests if a row type is a subtype of another row type by comparing their base types, as in rule 14.

row t ⊆ row T

 14

t ⊆ T

A ref type can also be a cotype of a row type, as in rule 15. As a result, if a parameter type of a method is a row type, then its corresponding argument can have a ref type or a row type.

ref t ⊑ T

 15

row t ⊆ T

However, a row type is not a cotype of a ref type. This is because a row pointer might be computed by pointer arithmetic, making it riskier to use than a ref pointer. Converting a row pointer to a ref pointer requires a cast to indicate acceptance of the risk.
      Most row pointers are pure execution instances. However, strings, which are row pointers that reference char0’s, are both transformation instances and execution instances. All row pointer types, including strings, are both transformation types and execution types.

5.9.3.3. Circular pointer types.

Suppose that the base type of a ref or row pointer type is an unbound name. Then the name must later be bound by an equate in the same prog clause or with clause in which the pointer type was created. This allows the pointer’s base type to be circularly defined in terms of itself. Linked data structures, like chains, trees, and graphs, may be described by such circular pointer types.
      For example, these two equates define a type link that describes a linear chain of tuples which contains int’s. The name node is unbound when it appears in the first equate, but it is bound by the second equate.

link

 :− 

ref node

node

 :− 

(tuple var int key, var link next)

A pointer type like link, whose base type is an unbound name, can be used without error only in situations where the name will not be examined. For example, its size may be computed, and it can be used as part of another type. However, it cannot be compared with another ref or row type, if that would require examining its base type. After the unbound name becomes bound, the pointer type can be used without such restrictions.

Infinite types. In the example, the type link appears to have an infinite base type, as if it was defined as follows. Orson might represent such a type as a finite graph with cycles, in an unspecified way.

link :− 
liref (tuple 
liref (tvar int key, 
liref (tvar ref (tuple 
liref (tvar ref (tvar int key, 
liref (tvar ref (tvar ref (tuple 
liref (tvar ref (tvar ref (tvar int key, 
liref (tvar ref (tvar ref (tvar ref ... )))

An infinite type can appear only as the base type of a ref or row type. Because the size of a pointer type is finite, infinite types can never be used to create instances of infinite size.
      Since link no longer mentions the name node, it can be used even in scopes where node is not bound. For example, a call to the plain form chain transforms to a circular pointer type that is computed by a with clause.

chain :− 
c(form (type mut base) type ref tup: 
c((with 
c((wlink :− ref node 
c((wnode :− (tuple var base key, var link next) 
c((do link))

The call chain(int) transforms to the infinite type shown above.

Infinite subtypes. Suppose that l and r are both ref types or both row types. Also suppose that a statement asserts l to be a subtype of r. Then the statement is true if l’s base type can be proved to be a subtype of r’s base type.
      Now suppose that during the proof, the original statement about l and r reappears. Then at least one of l and r are circular, so the proof might not terminate if it is continued. To avoid this, the reappearance of the original statement about l and r is assumed to be true and deleted, as in the following proof fragments.

a1, a2 ..., aj, ref t ⊆ ref T

  13

a1, a2 ..., aj, t ⊆ T

     

⋮
b1, b2 ..., bk, ref t ⊆ ref T

     

b1, b2 ..., bk

          

a1, a2 ..., aj, row t ⊆ row T

  14

a1, a2 ..., aj, t ⊆ T

     

⋮
b1, b2 ..., bk, row t ⊆ row T

     

b1, b2 ..., bk

When Orson compares ref and row types, it automatically detects circularities and escapes from them, in an unspecified way.

5.9.4. Procedure types.

A procedure type is a term that transforms to the type of a procedure. A procedure itself is a method whose call evaluates to an execution instance that is not a variable. Procedures are pure execution instances; their types are both transformation types and execution types. Each procedure type looks like this.

proc (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y

There are zero or more t n pairs in the procedure type, called parameters. They describe the arguments with which the procedure can be called. Each t is a term that transforms to the type of an execution instance called a parameter type, and each n is a name called a parameter name. The parameter names must be distinct from each other, and any or all of them may be missing. A parameter with the missing name ⬚ describes an unused argument. The term y transforms to the type of an execution instance, but not a variable type, called the yield type. It describes the execution instance to which the call evaluates.
      Rule 16 shows how a procedure type can be a subtype of another procedure type.

proc (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y ⊆ proc (T1 N1, T2 N2 ..., Tk Nk) Y

 16

T1 ⊆ t1, $n1 ⊆ $N1, T2 ⊆ t2, $n2 ⊆ $N2 ..., Tk ⊆ tk, $nk ⊆ $Nk, y ⊆ Y

In the rule, both procedure types have the same number of parameters, k. Parameter types are compared in reverse [CAR 1997], so that each parameter type T on the right is a subtype of its corresponding parameter type t on the left. Each parameter name n on the left is a subname of its corresponding parameter name N on the right. The yield type y on the left is a subtype of the yield type Y on the right.
      For example, this proof shows that the procedure type proc (inj l, var [] mut a) int is a subtype of the procedure type proc (int, var [5] int) int. The proof uses array types, symbol types, the integer type int, the joker type inj and the joker type mut.

proc (inj l, var [] mut a) int ⊆ proc (int ⬚, var [5] int ⬚) int

  16

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut, $a ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ int

  0

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut, $a ⊆ $⬚

  33

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, var [5] int ⊆ var [] mut

  18

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, [5] int ⊆ [] mut

  74

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ mut

  54

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ sca

  66

int ⊆ inj, $l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ num

  59

$l ⊆ $⬚, int ⊆ inj

  50

$l ⊆ $⬚

  33

true

The size of a procedure type is an unspecified small positive integer. A procedure might be represented as the address of its machine instructions in memory. If this representation is used, then the size of a procedure type might be the size of an address. However, a procedure type is not a pointer type. It does not necessarily have the same size as a pointer type, the same size as any integer type, or even the same size as a different procedure type.

5.9.5. Type types.

When an expression is transformed, it returns a new expression or an object, and its type. If e is a term, then the term type e transforms to the type returned by e. For example, type 0 transforms to int0, because the integer 0 has the type int0.
      Since all types are objects, and all objects have types, it follows that all types have types. As a result, if e transforms to a type, then type e also transforms to the type of e. For example, type int transforms to the type of int, type type int transforms to the type of the type of int, type type type int transforms to the type of the type of the type of int, etc. The type of a type is called a type type. Type types are pure transformation types. A type type can be a subtype of another type type, as in rule 17.

type t ⊆ type T

 17

t ⊆ T

A term e has the type t if and only if type e is a subtype of t. For example, 0 has the joker type inj because type 0 is int0, and int0 is a subtype of inj.

5.9.6. Variable types.

A variable type is a term that transforms to the type of a variable. A variable itself is a pure execution instance that acts as a container for another execution instance, called its value. Variable types are both transformation types and execution types.
      Suppose that the term t transforms to the type of an execution instance, but not to another variable type. Then the term var t transforms to the type of a variable whose value has the type t. The type t is called the variable type’s base type. Since the base type cannot be a variable type, a variable’s value cannot be another variable, but it can be an instance that has variables as parts.
      When a variable is created, it can be given an instance of its base type as an initial value. If it is not given an initial value, then its value is an unspecified instance of its base type. After a variable is created, its value can be repeatedly changed by calls to assignment forms.
      A variable type can be a subtype of another variable type, as in rule 18. An expression of a variable type can also be coerced to its value, as in rule 19, and its value can be coerced again.

var t ⊆ var T

 18

t ⊆ T

     

var t ⊑ T

 19

t ⊑ T

An expression of a variable type is almost always coerced to its value in this way. There are only five situations where it is not.

  • When the expression appears as an argument in a method call, and its type is a subtype of the method’s corresponding parameter type.

  • When the expression appears as the body of a plain or a generic form, and its type is a subtype of the form’s yield type.

  • When the expression appears in a list clause.

  • When the expression appears prefixed by the type operator.

  • When the expression appears as an argument in some hook calls.

A variable of type var t is represented in the same way as an instance of its base type t. As a result, the size of a variable type is the same as that of its base type: size(var t) = size(t).

5.10. Units.

A unit can be a clause, a literal, or a name. Suppose that l is a unit, that the m’s are zero or more assignments, that the r’s are zero or more assignments, and that n is a name. Then the expressions in the following table are also units. Some units abbreviate calls to forms whose quoted names are bound by the standard prelude. These forms are described in the indicated sections of this Report.

  Section  

Unit

Call

  5.10.1.

 l(r1, r2 ..., rk)

 

  5.10.1.

 l(m1, m2 ..., mj : r1, r2 ..., rk)

 l(m1, m2 ..., mj, (: r1, r2 ..., rk))

  7.3.1.

 l[r1, r2 ..., rj] 

 "␣[]"(l, r1, r2 ..., rj) 

 

 l[m1, m2 ..., mj : r1, r2 ..., rk] 

 "␣[]"(l, m1, m2 ..., mj, (: r1, r2 ..., rk)) 

  7.3.2.

 l{r1, r2 ..., rj} 

 "␣{}"(l, r1, r2 ..., rj) 

 

 l{m1, m2 ..., mj : r1, r2 ..., rk} 

 "␣{}"(l, m1, m2 ..., mj, (: r1, r2 ..., rk)) 

  5.10.6.

 $

 

  5.10.6.

 $n

 

  7.3.11.

 l . n 

 "."(l, $n) 

  5.10.3.

 ?n

 

  5.10.3.

 ?n(r1, r2 ..., rk)

 

  7.3.33.

 l@ 

 "@"(l) 

  7.3.33.

 l↓ 

 "↓"(l) 

  7.3.35.

 l^ 

 "^"(l) 

  7.3.35.

 l↑ 

 "↑"(l) 

A colon lets some units have the r’s as optional arguments. These arguments become the elements of a list, which in turn is passed to a form as its last argument. The form then obtains the optional arguments from the list.

5.10.1. Calls.

Suppose that m is a unit, and that the a’s are zero or more assignments separated by commas. Then the following unit is a call, in which m is a method, and the a’s are its arguments.

m(a1, a2 ..., ak)

The call is either a form call or a procedure call, depending on the object to which its method evaluates. The method and its arguments are evaluated in an unspecified order. There may be a limit on the number of arguments that can appear in a call.
      In a form call, the method transforms to an alternate form, a generic form, or a plain form. Each argument also transforms to an expression or an object. The form uses these expressions or objects, and their types, to compute a new expression or object. The call then transforms to the new expression or object, and its type. Form calls are described in more detail along with alt clauses, form clauses, and gen clauses.
      In a procedure call, the method evaluates to a procedure. Each argument must also evaluate to an execution instance. The procedure uses these instances to compute a new execution instance that is not a variable. The call then evaluates to the new instance. Procedure calls are described in more detail along with proc clauses.

Optional arguments. A form call can have zero or more optional arguments following a colon, like this.

m(a1, a2 ..., ak : ak+1, ak+2 ..., ak+l)

It abbreviates a call whose last argument is a list clause, like this.

m(a1, a2 ..., ak, (: ak+1, ak+2 ..., ak+l))

When the form call is transformed, the list clause transforms to a list, from which the form can obtain its optional arguments. Procedure calls cannot have optional arguments, because procedure arguments must be execution instances, and lists are pure transformation instances. However, procedure calls with optional arguments can often be simulated by form calls that transform to procedure calls.

5.10.1.1. Forwarding.

Suppose that there is a prog or with clause in which an equate binds the name a to a method. Also suppose that later, in the same prog or with clause, an equate binds the name b to another method. Then the method b can call the method a, because the name a is bound when the method b is evaluated. However, the method a can also call the method b, even though the name b is unbound when the method a is evaluated. The name b is said to be forwarded.
      Forwarding allows methods whose names are bound in the same prog or with clause to call each other freely. It also allows methods to call themselves. In the following example, the plain form a calls the procedure b, and vice versa. If the method writeln displays its argument on an output device, then the call a(3) will display the integers 3, 2, and 1.

(with 
(wa :− 
(wa(form (int k) void: 
(wa((if k > 0 
(wa((then writeln(k) 
(wa((then b(k − 1))) 
(wb :− 
(wb(proc (int k) void: 
(wb((if k > 0 
(wb((then writeln(k) 
(wb((then a(k − 1))) 
(do a(3))

Orson might implement forwarding by delaying the transformation of method bodies in an unspecified way. A form’s body is not transformed until the form is called. A procedure’s body might not be transformed until all the equates of the prog or with clause in which it appears are transformed. As a result, only the names of methods that are called in method bodies can be forwarded. Also, if a name is forwarded in a prog or with clause, then it must eventually be bound by an equate in the same prog or with clause.

5.10.1.2. Subsumption.

Suppose that a form of type t can always be called with the same arguments as another form of type T. Then the form of type t is said to be subsumed by the form of type T, and the form of type T is said to subsume the form of type t. Similarly, the type t is said to be subsumed by the type T, and the type T is said to subsume the type t. Orson uses the notation t ≼ T to mean that t is subsumed by T. It is similar to the notation used for subtypes.
      The following extended rules are an algorithm that decides if t is subsumed by T. It is a simplified version of the algorithm that decides if a form type is a subtype of another form type. The algorithm assumes that t and T have no generic names in common.

Remove alternate form types. In the first step of the algorithm, statements about alternate form types are replaced by equivalent statements about plain and generic form types. An alternate form type is subsumed by a type T if each member type t is also subsumed by T, as in rules 20 and 21. The joker type foj describes all form types.

 (alts) ≼ T 

 20

T ⊆ foj

     

(alts t1, t2 ..., tk) ≼ T

 21

t1 ≼ T, (alts t2 ..., tk) ≼ T

Rules 22 and 23 state that a type t is subsumed by an alternate form type if it is subsumed by at least one member type T.

t ≼ (alts T1, T2 ..., Tk)

 22

t ≼ T1

     

t ≼ (alts T1, T2 ..., Tk)

 23

t ≼ (alts T2 ..., Tk)

Because of these rules, an alternate form type can be subsumed by a generic or plain form type, and vice versa. Also, every form type subsumes (alts), but no form type is subsumed by (alts) except itself.

Mark generic prefixes. By the second step of the algorithm, only statements like t ≼ T remain, where t and T are generic form types or plain form types. Each generic prefix in t is marked with a superscript R, indicating that the generic names it declares will be replaced by parts of T’s parameter types. These generic prefixes are called replacing prefixes. Similarly, each generic prefix in T is marked with a superscript S, indicating that the generic names it declares will be replaced by Skolemized types. These generic prefixes are called Skolemizing prefixes.

Add a separator. The third step is to add a separator ‘|’, as in rule 24. This lets other rules add statements about generic names on the left side of the separator.

t ≼ T

 24

true | t ≼ T

Remove generic prefixes. The fourth step removes all generic prefixes. Rule 25 removes a replacing prefix and adds equivalent statements about its generic names on the left of the separator ‘|’.

a1, a2 ..., aj | genR (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f ≼ T

 25

a1, a2 ..., aj, type n1 ⊆ g1, type n2 ⊆ g2 ..., type nk ⊆ gk | f ≼ T

Rule 26 removes a Skolemizing prefix, replacing free appearances of the generic names it declares by Skolemized types. Each s is the type that results from Skolemizing its corresponding type g.

t ≼ genS (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) F⟨n1, n2 ..., nk⟩

 26

t ≼ F⟨s1, s2 ..., sk⟩

Subsumption. In the fifth step, only statements about plain form types remain on the right of the separator ‘|’. Rule 27 describes how a plain form type is subsumed by another plain form type.

form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) t ≼ form (T1 N1, T2 N2 ..., Tk Nk) T

 27

t1 ⊑ T1, t2 ⊑ T2 ..., tk ⊑ Tk

Just as in rule 2, both form types have the same number of parameters, k. However, in rule 27, parameter types are not compared in reverse. Each parameter type t on the left is a cotype of its corresponding parameter type T on the right. Parameter names and yield types are not compared at all.

Example. A form of type form (var int v) int subsumes a form of type form (int i) int. This can be proved in the following way.

form (var int v) void ≼ form (int i) int

  27

var int ⊑ int

  19

int ⊑ int

  1

int ⊆ int

  0

true

This example is discussed informally, but in more detail, along with alt clauses.

5.10.2. Clauses.

A clause appears between parentheses ‘ ( ’ and ’ ) ’. Most clauses are units, so they can appear as parts of expressions. They include alt clauses, alts clauses, case clauses, catch clauses, expression clauses, for clauses, form clauses, gen clauses, if clauses, list clauses, past clauses, proc clauses, tuple clauses, while clauses, and with clauses. However, load clauses and prog clauses are not units, so they can appear only as parts of programs.

5.10.2.1. Alt clauses.

An alternate form is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Alternate forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types. Each alternate form is written as an alt clause that has a series of zero or more forms as members. If the e’s are assignments that transform to such member forms, then this is an alt clause.

(alt e1, e2 ..., ek)

An alt clause with exactly one member form, (alt e), is equivalent to simply e. A nested alt clause, like this,

(alt e1, e2 ..., ej, (alt ej+1, ej+2 ..., ej+k), ej+k+1, ej+k+2 ..., ej+k+l)

is equivalent to one that is not nested, like this.

(alt e1, e2 ..., ej, ej+1, ej+2 ..., ej+k, ej+k+1, ej+k+2 ..., ej+k+l)

As a result of the equivalence, each member form is either a plain form or a generic form, not another alternate form. There may be a limit on the number of member forms in an alt clause.

Alternate form calls. When an alternate form is called, Orson tries to call each of its member forms, one at a time, in order of appearance. If calling a member would be an error because of inappropriate arguments, then Orson does not call it or report the error, but goes on to try the next member. Orson continues in this way until it finds the first member that can be called without error, and then calls it. The alternate form call finally transforms to the expression or object, and its type, that result from calling this member.
      For example, the following equate binds the name inc to an alternate form that increments an integer variable. It has two members. If u is an integer variable, then inc(u, 2) calls the first member, and inc(u) calls the second member.

inc :− 
i(alt 
i((form (var int v, int Δ) void: 
i((fv += Δ), 
i((form (var int v) void: 
i((fv += 1))

It is an error to call an alternate form with arguments for which no member can be called. For example, the call inc(2) is an error, because neither of inc’s members can be called with an integer as its only argument. It is always an error to call the alternate form (alt), because it has no members at all.

Subsumed member forms. It is also an error if an alternate form has a member form that can never be called. Suppose that it has a member a followed by another member b. If a can always be called with the same arguments as b, then b can never be called, because any attempt to call b will call a instead. The member b is said to be subsumed by the member a. It is an error for a member to be subsumed in this way.
      For example, suppose that a new first member is added to inc, so it looks like the following. The third member is now subsumed. If u is an integer variable, then inc(u) calls the first member, not the third, because u is coerced to an integer.

inc :− 
i(alt 
i((form (int i) int: 
i((fi + 1), 
i((form (var int v, int Δ) void: 
i((fv += Δ), 
i((form (var int v) void: 
i((fv += 1))

Subsumption errors can often be avoided by reordering an alt clause’s members. For example, inc can be reordered so the member that increments an integer variable appears before the member that increments an integer.

inc :− 
i(alt 
i((form (var int v) void: 
i((fv += 1), 
i((form (int i) int: 
i((fi + 1), 
i((form (var int v, int Δ) void: 
i((fv += Δ))

Now inc(u) calls the first member without coercing u, and inc(2) calls the second member. The third member is called in the same way as before.

5.10.2.2. Alts clauses.

An alts clause transforms to the type of an alternate form. An alternate form itself is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Alternate forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types.
      Suppose that the t’s are zero or more generic form types and plain form types. Also suppose that the s’s are zero or more expressions, so that this is an alt clause which transforms to an alternate form.

(alt (t1: s1), (t2: s2) ..., (tk: sk))

Then the following is an alts clause that transforms to the alternate form’s type. It has a series of zero or more member types, the types of the alternate form’s member forms. There may be a limit on the number of member types in an alts clause.

(alts t1, t2 ..., tk)

It is an error if a member type is subsumed by another member type that appears before it in the alts clause. It is also an error for a joker type or a Skolem type to appear as a member. As a result, it is an error for a generic name to appear as a member, because it will be replaced by a Skolem type when the alts clause is transformed. However, joker types, Skolem types, and generic names can appear as parts of members.
      An alts clause with exactly one member type, (alts t), is equivalent to simply t. A nested alts clause, like this,

(alts t1, t2 ..., tj, (alts tj+1, tj+2 ..., tj+k), tj+k+1, tj+k+2 ..., tj+k+l)

is equivalent to one that is not nested, like this.

(alts t1, t2 ..., tj, tj+1, tj+2 ..., tj+k, tj+k+1, tj+k+2 ..., tj+k+l)

As a result of the equivalence, each member type is either a plain form type or a generic form type, not another alternate form type.
      An alternate form type is a subtype of another type T if at least one of its member types is a subtype of T, as in rules 28 and 29. It is assumed that the t’s and T have no generic names in common.

(alts t1, t2 ..., tk) ⊆ T

 28

t1 ⊆ T

     

(alts t1, t2 ..., tk) ⊆ T

 29

(alts t2 ..., tk) ⊆ T

A type t is a subtype of an alternate form type if it is a subtype of each member type T, as in rules 30 and 31. It is assumed that t and the T’s have no generic names in common. The joker type foj describes all forms.

 t ⊆ (alts) 

 30

t ⊆ foj

     

t ⊆ (alts T1, T2 ..., Tk)

 31

t ⊆ T1, t ⊆ (alts T2 ..., Tk)

Because of these rules, an alternate form type can be a subtype of a generic form type or a plain form type, and vice versa. Also, every form type is a subtype of (alts), but (alts) is not a subtype of any form type except itself.

5.10.2.3. Case clauses.

A case clause first evaluates an expression to an integer. It then uses the integer to select and evaluate one of many assignments. Each case clause looks like the following. There may be an extra semicolon after the last e.

(case s of l1: e1 ; l2: e2 ... ; lk: ek ; none: ek+1)

Here s is an expression that evaluates to an integer, and the e’s are one or more assignments. The l’s are also one or more assignments, called labels. Each label must transform to an integer, and it is an error if two or more labels in a case clause transform to the same integer. (Because of coercion, characters may be used instead of integers.) The labeled assignments, including the one labeled by none, may appear in any order. There may be limits on the number of labeled assignments, and on the range of labels, in a case clause.
      The case clause (case s of none: e), with only one e, is equivalent to e itself. A case clause with two or more e’s acts like an abbreviation for the following if clause inside a with clause. Here u is a unique name that appears nowhere else, and the comparison operator ‘=’ tests if integers are equal.

(with inj u :− (s)  
(do (if u = l1 
(do (then e1 
(do (else if u = l2 
(do (else then e2 
(do (else else ... if u = lk  
(do (else else ... then ek 
(do (else else ... else ek+1))

As a result of the abbreviation, the case clause first evaluates the expression s to an integer. It then evaluates the assignment e whose label l equals that integer. If there is no assignment with such a label, then the case clause evaluates the assignment whose label is none instead. Also, if s transforms to an integer, then the case clause transforms to the expression or object that results from transforming the selected assignment.
      Orson does not necessarily implement a case clause in exactly this way, which selects the jth assignment in time proportional to j. Instead, it is implemented in an unspecified way that selects each assignment in a small, constant amount of time during execution. For example, it might use a jump table [PAT 2005]. Case clauses are therefore almost always faster than their equivalent if clauses.

Abbreviations. Case clauses may be abbreviated as shown in the following table. Suppose that a case clause has an assignment with two or more labels separated by commas. Then it abbreviates a case clause in which the assignment appears two or more times, each with a different label. However, the assignment is still transformed only once.

Abbreviated

Unabbreviated

 (case s of ...  l1, l2 ..., lj : e  ...) 

 (case s of ...  l1 : e ; l2 : e ... ; lj : e  ...) 

 (case s of l1: e1 ; l2: e2 ... ; lk: ek) 

 (case s of l1: e1 ; l2: e2 ... ; lk: ek ; none: skip) 

Suppose that a case clause has no assignment labeled by none. Then it abbreviates a case clause in which skip is labeled by none. Such a case clause always evaluates to skip, so it should be used only for its side effects.

5.10.2.4. Catch clauses.

A catch clause terminates the evaluation of an expression during its execution. If s is an expression with an execution type, then (catch s) is a catch clause. It abbreviates the call "catch"((s)). The standard prelude binds the quoted name "catch" to a plain form like this.

"catch" :− 
"c(form (exe s) int: 
"c(f?catch(s))

The standard prelude also binds the plain names rethrow, throw, and thrown to forms that are used with catch clauses. This Report shows them as defined by hooks.

rethrow :− 
r(form () void: 
r(fthrow(thrown())) 
r
throw :− 
t(alt 
t((form () void: 
t((fthrow(0)), 
t((form (int r) void: 
t((f?throw(r))) 
t
thrown :− 
t(form () int: 
t(f?thrown())

Catching and throwing. Ordinarily, the catch clause (catch s) evaluates the expression s and returns the integer 0. However, suppose that s evaluates the call throw(r), where r evaluates to an integer. Then, immediately after the call’s execution, all scopes established by s are exited, the catch clause is terminated, and it returns r instead. The call to throw need not appear as a unit in s, but may be evaluated as an indirect result of evaluating s. For example, s might call a procedure that calls throw.
      Now suppose that two or more catch clauses are executing when throw(r) is evaluated. This can occur if s evaluates another catch clause. Then the catch clause whose execution began most recently is terminated, and returns r. If no catch clauses are executing, then throw(r) terminates the execution of the entire program instead, as if exit was called with r. During transformation, throw(r) is treated as if it will evaluate to skip. However, it actually evaluates to no object, because it terminates the execution of the expression in which it appears.
      By convention, catch and throw respond to unusual situations that occur during execution. If (catch s) returns 0, then no unusual situations occurred during the execution of s: either throw was never called, or else it was called with the argument 0. (The call throw() is equivalent to the call throw(0).) If the catch clause returns a nonzero integer, then an unusual situation occurred, and throw was called in response. The integer can then be used to identify the situation.

Exceptions and handlers. A nonzero integer returned by a catch clause is called an exception. It is often used to select and evaluate an expression called a handler. The handler responds somehow to the situation that terminated the catch clause. The following case clause shows one way to select handlers (an if clause might be used instead). The e’s transform to exceptions, and the h’s are assignments that act as handlers.

(case (catch s) of 0 : h0 ; e1 : h1 ; e2 : h2 ... ; ek : hk ; none: hk+1)

If the catch clause evaluates to 0, indicating that no unusual situation has occurred, then the handler labeled 0 is evaluated. If the catch clause evaluates to an exception which is one of the e’s, indicating that an unusual situation has occurred, then the handler labeled by that exception is executed. Otherwise a default handler, labeled none, is evaluated instead.
      The call thrown() evaluates to the most recently thrown exception. If no exception has ever been thrown, then it evaluates to 0. A handler can call thrown to obtain the exception that caused it to be selected. This exception can be passed to a handler associated with another catch clause by the call rethrow(), which is equivalent to throw(thrown()).

5.10.2.5. Expression clauses.

An expression clause is simply an expression e in parentheses, (e). It is evaluated in the same way as e. Expression clauses let parentheses be used as grouping symbols.

5.10.2.6. For clauses.

For clauses abbreviate certain expressions that involve calls to higher-order forms. Such forms may take forms as their arguments, and may return forms as their results. Suppose that the t’s are one or more terms which transform to types, and that the n’s are one or more distinct names, any or all of which may be missing. Also suppose that the e’s are one or more assignments, and that s is an expression. Then the following table shows for clauses and the form calls that they abbreviate.

For clause

Call

 (for t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tj nj in e1, e2 ..., ek do s) 

 "for"((form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tj nj) obj: s), e1, e2 ..., ek) 

 (for t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tj nj do s) 

 "for"((form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tj nj) obj: s)) 

 (in e1 e2 ..., ek do s) 

 "for"((form () obj: s), e1, e2 ..., ek) 

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "for" to the following alternate form. Its first four members are plain forms that implement counting loops. They use if clauses, past clauses, while clauses, and with clauses. The fifth member is a generic form that implements wrappers and iterators. It uses the joker foj and a form call.

"for" :− 
"f(alt 
"f((form (form (int) obj body, int b, int e, int s) void: 
"f(((with 
"f(((wint e :− (past e) 
"f(((wint s :− (past s) 
"f(((wvar int k :− b 
"f(((do (while (if s ≥ 0 then k ≤ e else k ≥ e) 
"f(((do (do body(k) 
"f(((do (do k += s))), 
"f((form (form (int) obj body, int b, int e) void: 
"f((f"for"(body, b, e, 1)), 
"f((form (form (int) obj body, int e) void: 
"f((f"for"(body, 0, e − 1, 1)), 
"f((form (form () obj body, int e) void: 
"f(((with var int e :− (past e) 
"f(((do (while e > 0 
"f(((do (do body() 
"f(((do (do e −= 1))), 
"f((gen (type foj bodyType) 
"f((ggen (type form (bodyType) obj wrapType) 
"f((ggform (bodyType body, wrapType wrap) obj: 
"f((ggfwrap(body)))

Counting loops. A counting loop transforms to an expression that repeatedly executes another expression on a succession of integers. Suppose that n is a name, that b, e, and s are assignments which evaluate to int’s, and that d is an expression. Then the for clause (for int n in b, e, s do d) executes d for bindings of n beginning with b and ending with e, in steps of s. Similarly, the for clause (for int n in b, e do d) executes d for bindings of n from b to e, in steps of 1. The for clause (for int n in e do d) executes d for bindings of n from 0 to e − 1, in steps of 1. (These are the indexes of an array whose length is e.) For example, if the method writeln displays its argument on an output device, then each of the following for clauses displays 0 through 9.

(for int m in 0, 9, 1 do writeln(m)) 
(for int m in 0, 9 do writeln(m)) 
(for int m in 10 do writeln(m))

If e evaluates to an integer greater than 0, then the for clause (in e do d) simply executes d a total of e times. If e evaluates to an integer less than or equal to 0, then the for clause does nothing. All four counting loops evaluate to skip.

Wrappers. Suppose that the t’s are zero or more terms which transform to types, and that the n’s are zero or more distinct names, any or all of which may be missing. Also suppose that w is an expression which transforms to a form, and that d is an expression. Then a for clause that looks like this:

(for t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk in w do d)

is equivalent to a call to w that looks like this.

w((form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) obj: d))

The form w is a wrapper. A wrapper is a higher-order form whose argument f is another form. A call to the wrapper transforms to a new expression in which a call to f may appear as a unit. In effect, the call to f is ‘‘wrapped’’ in the new expression.
      A wrapper is usually created by calling yet another form. This form often binds names that are inherited by the wrapper; the wrapper saves their bindings as a result of closure. For example, the following form roots returns a wrapper that solves a quadratic equation with real coefficients a, b, and c, where a is not zero. It uses the familiar formula from elementary algebra.

roots :− 
r(form (real a, real b, real c) foj: 
r((form (form (real, real) obj body) void: 
r(((with 
r(((wreal a :− (past a) 
r(((wreal b :− (past b) 
r(((wreal d :− b × b − 4.0 × a × c 
r(((do (if d ≥ 0.0 
r(((do (then (with 
r(((do (then (wreal s :− sqrt(d) 
r(((do (then (wreal u :− 2.0 × a 
r(((do (then (wreal p :− (− b + s) / u 
r(((do (then (wreal n :− (− b − s) / u 
r(((do (then (do body(p, n))))))

In the wrapper returned by roots, the method sqrt returns the square root of a nonnegative real number. This method might be obtained by loading a library program. The wrapper calls the form body with the two real roots of the equation, then returns skip. If the equation has no real roots, then the wrapper does not call body at all.
      The following for clause uses the form roots to solve the quadratic equation x² + 3x + 2 = 0. It binds the names r₀ and r₁ to the equation’s roots, then calls the method writeln to display them on an output device.

(for real r₀, real r₁ in roots(1.0, 3.0, 2.0) 
(do writeln(r₀) 
(do writeln(r₁))

In this for clause, roots is called with literal arguments that transform to real numbers. Now suppose that the call to sqrt also transforms to a real number. Then all arithmetic in the wrapper form is performed during transformation, and the entire for clause transforms to two writeln calls whose arguments are real numbers.

Iterators. An iterator is a wrapper that systematically visits parts of an object. The word iterator is borrowed from the programming language CLU [LIS 1981]. Like other wrappers, iterators are usually created by calling forms. For example, the form chars takes as its argument a string p that is the pathname of a file. It returns an iterator that reads successive characters from the file, and calls body on each one.

chars :− 
c(form (string p) foj: 
c((form (form (char) obj body) void: 
c(((with 
c(((wvar char c 
c(((wstream s :− open(p) 
c(((do (while 
c(((do (wc := read(s) 
c(((do (wc ≠ eos 
c(((do (do body(c)) 
c(((do close(s))))

In the iterator returned by chars, the method open returns a stream s that is associated with the file named p. The method read reads the next character c from s and returns it. If there are no more characters in s, then read returns eos instead. The method close severs the association between s and the file. These methods might be obtained by loading a library program.
      The following expression uses the form chars to count the blanks in a file whose pathname is ''text''. It calls the method writeln to display the total b on an output device.

(with var int b :− 0 
(do (for char c in chars(''text'') 
(do (do (if c = '␣' 
(do (do (then b += 1)) 
(do writeln(b))

Most forms that return wrappers and iterators hide how they are implemented, so they may be used by abstract data structures.

5.10.2.7. Form clauses.

A form clause transforms to a plain form. A plain form itself is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Plain forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types. Each form clause looks like this. It consists of a plain form type, followed by a colon, followed in turn by an expression s called the body.

(form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y: s)

In the plain form type, there are zero or more t n pairs called parameters. They describe the arguments with which the plain form can be called. Each t is a term that transforms to a type called a parameter type, and each n is a name called a parameter name. Any or all of the parameter names may be missing, and all the parameter names must be distinct from each other. A parameter with the missing name describes an unused argument. There may be a limit on the number of parameters in a plain form type. The term y transforms to a type called the yield type. It describes the expression or object to which the call transforms.

Transforming a form clause. When a form clause is transformed, the type that appears on the left side of the colon is also transformed. Each parameter type t transforms to a corresponding type T, and the yield type y transforms to a type Y. The body s is not transformed.
      The form clause then transforms to a plain form whose type is the transformed form type. The plain form contains the transformed parameter types, the parameter names, the transformed yield type, and the untransformed body. It also contains a copy of the current scope, called its defining scope, which is used when the plain form is called.

Plain form calls. A plain form call looks like this, where f is a unit that transforms to a plain form F, and the a’s are zero or more assignments that transform to F’s arguments. The form and its arguments are transformed in an unspecified order.

f(a1, a2 ..., ak)

Each assignment a transforms to a corresponding expression or object A, and its type A′. The call must have as many arguments as F has parameters, so that each argument A and its type A′ correspond to a parameter T n, where A′ must be a cotype of T.
      After all the arguments are transformed, F’s defining scope is entered. Each parameter name n is bound to its corresponding coerced argument A⦃T⦄ and its type, which is a subtype of T. The body s is then transformed to a new expression or object S and its type S′. If S is an expression, then the parameter names that appear as units in s may be replaced in S by the coerced arguments to which they were bound. The defining scope of F is then exited, restoring the parameter names to their previous bindings.
      If the type S′ is a cotype of the yield type Y, then S is coerced to S⦃Y⦄ and its type, a subtype of Y. The plain form call then transforms to S⦃Y⦄ and its type. This occurs in a plain form that is intended to return an expression or object computed by its body. However, if Y is the type void, and S′ is an execution type other than void, then the plain form call transforms to the subsequence (S ; skip), whose type is void. This occurs in a plain form that is intended only to perform side effects. It is an error if neither alternative is possible.

Example. The following equate binds the name abs to a plain form that uses an if clause to compute the absolute value of an integer r. (The standard prelude binds the name abs to a more general version of this form.) The with clause ensures that r is evaluated only once.

abs :− 
a(form (inj r) inj: 
a((with inj a :− r 
a((do (if a < 0 
a((do (then − a 
a((do (else a)))

In the call abs(v), suppose that v evaluates to an integer variable of type var int. The variable v is first coerced to the parameter type inj, a joker that describes all integers. The result is an unspecified expression v⦃inj⦄ that returns the value of v, whose type is int. The defining scope of abs is then entered, and the parameter name r is bound to this expression and its type. Next, the form’s body is transformed to an expression that is equivalent to the following.

(with int a :− v⦃inj⦄ 
(do (if a < 0 
(do (then − a 
(do (else a))

When the with clause in the form’s body is transformed, the joker inj in the equate is replaced by r’s type int, and r itself is replaced by the coerced argument v⦃inj⦄. Since a’s type is int, the if clause also has the type int, and so does the with clause. After the scope of abs is exited, the with clause is coerced to the yield type inj, but since int is already a subtype of inj, this has no effect. As a result, the call transforms to an expression that is equivalent to the with clause shown above, whose type is int.
      In a real Orson program, the type int transforms to a hook. The expressions that involve the less form "<" and the minus form "−" transform to hook calls. The coercion transforms to a hook call that implements a cast. These were omitted to simplify the example.

Example. The previous example showed how a form call can transform to an expression. A form call can also transform to an object such as an integer. This occurs in the call abs(−1), which transforms to 1.
      First, −1 is coerced to the parameter type inj. Since −1 has the type int0, which is already a subtype of inj, this coercion has no effect. The defining scope of abs is then entered, and the parameter name r is bound to −1 and its type int0. Next, the form’s body is transformed, substituting −1 for the parameter name r:

(with inj a :− −1 
(do (if a < 0 
(do (then − a 
(do (else a))

When the resulting with clause is transformed, the name a is bound to −1 and its type int0. The if clause is then transformed to a new if clause (if −1 < 0 then −(−1) else −1). The new if clause, in turn, transforms to 1, whose type is int0. After the scope of abs is exited, 1 is coerced to the yield type inj, but since int0 is already a subtype of inj, this coercion has no effect either. As a result, the call transforms to 1, whose type is int0.
      In a real Orson program, the type inj transforms to a hook. The expressions that involve the forms "<" and "−" result in additional form calls which transform to integers. These were omitted to simplify the example.

5.10.2.8. Gen clauses.

A gen clause transforms to a generic form. A generic form itself is a method whose call transforms to an expression or an object, and its type. Generic forms are pure transformation instances; their types are pure transformation types. Each gen clause looks like this. It consists of a generic form type, followed by a colon, followed in turn by an expression s called the body.

(gen (g11 n11, g12 n12 ..., g1j1 n1j1) 
(gegen (g21 n21, g22 n22 ..., g2j2 n2j2) 
(gege⋮ 
(gegegen (gi1 ni1, gi2 ni2 ..., giji niji) 
(gegegeform (t1 m1, t2 m2 ..., tk mk) y: s)

The generic form type looks like a plain form type, but it has one or more generic prefixes, each of which begins with the keyword gen. Each generic prefix has one or more g n pairs, called generic parameters. Each g is a term that transforms to a type type called a generic type, and each n is a name called a generic name. None of the generic names may be missing. There may be limits on the number of generic prefixes and on the number of generic parameters in a generic form type.
      In the plain form type that follows the generic prefixes, there are zero or more t m pairs, called parameters. Each t is a term that transforms to a type called a parameter type, and each m is a name called a parameter name. Any or all of the parameter names may be missing. There may be a limit on the number of parameters in a generic form type. The term y transforms to a type called the yield type.
      Each generic prefix declares generic names that appear as units in the rest of the generic form type. The generic parameter g n declares that the generic name n has the generic type g. A generic name n may optionally appear as a unit in one or more generic types of the generic prefixes following the one that declares it. It must also appear as a unit in one or more parameter types, and it may optionally appear as a unit in the yield type. All generic names and parameter names together in a generic form type must be distinct from each other.
      Just as in a form clause, the parameters describe the arguments with which the generic form can be called. A parameter with the missing name describes an unused argument. The yield type describes the expression or object to which the call transforms. However, unlike a form clause, the generic parameters describe parts of the arguments’ types, and the relationships that must hold between them.

Transforming a gen clause. When a gen clause is transformed, the generic form type that appears on the left side of the colon is also transformed. Suppose that n abbreviates all the generic names declared by the gen clause. Then each generic type g transforms to a corresponding type G⟨n⟩, each parameter type t transforms to a corresponding type T⟨n⟩, and the yield type y transforms to the type Y⟨n⟩. The body s is not transformed.
      The gen clause transforms to a generic form that contains the transformed generic types, the generic names, the transformed parameter types, the parameter names, the transformed yield type, and the untransformed body. It also contains a copy of the current scope, called its defining scope, which is used when the generic form is called. The generic form’s type is the transformed generic form type on the left of the colon.

Generic form calls. Each generic form call looks like the following, where f is a unit that transforms to a generic form F, and the a’s are zero or more assignments that transform to F’s arguments. The form and its arguments are transformed in an unspecified order.

f(a1, a2 ..., ak)

Each assignment a transforms to an expression or object A, and its type A′. The call must have as many arguments as F has parameters, so that each argument A and its type A′ correspond to a parameter T⟨n⟩ m.
      Calling a generic form is similar to calling a plain form. However, in addition to binding its parameter names to the arguments, a generic form also binds its generic names to parts of the argument types. Binding generic names is formally described by mechanisms similar to those that describe generic form subtypes. Suppose that the generic names abbreviated as n are bound respectively to parts of argument types abbreviated as B. Then the bindings must satisfy these two criteria.

  • Suppose that n is declared to have the generic type G⟨n⟩ by a generic prefix. Then B, the type to which n is bound, must have the type G⟨B⟩. In other words, each generic name must be bound to a type that is compatible with the way in which all other generic names are bound.

  • Suppose that an argument A corresponds to a parameter T⟨n⟩ m. Then the argument’s type A′ must be a cotype of T⟨B⟩. In other words, the generic names must be bound to types in a way that lets the argument types coerce to their corresponding parameter types.

Both criteria are expressed by the following statements. The type n ⊆ G⟨n⟩ statements express the first criterion. The A′ ⊑ T⟨n⟩ statements express the second criterion. The n ⇒ n binders record how generic names are bound to types that satisfy the criteria.

type n11 ⊆ G11⟨n⟩, type n12 ⊆ G12⟨n⟩ ..., type n1j1 ⊆ G1j1⟨n⟩,
type n21 ⊆ G21⟨n⟩, type n22 ⊆ G22⟨n⟩ ..., type n2j2 ⊆ G2j2⟨n⟩,
 ⋮,
type ni1 ⊆ Gi1⟨n⟩, type ni2 ⊆ Gi2⟨n⟩ ..., type niji ⊆ Giji⟨n⟩,
n11 ⇒ n11, n12 ⇒ n12 ..., n1j1 ⇒ n1j1,
n21 ⇒ n21, n22 ⇒ n22 ..., n2j2 ⇒ n2j2
 ⋮,
ni1 ⇒ ni1, ni2 ⇒ ni2 ..., niji ⇒ niji |
A′1 ⊑ T1⟨n⟩, A′2 ⊑ T2⟨n⟩ ..., A′k ⊑ Tk⟨n⟩

 

⋮

Now suppose that rules are applied to prove these statements. Also suppose that the proof ends like this, in which the B’s are parts of the argument types.

⋮
true,
n11 ⇒ B11, n12 ⇒ B12 ..., n1j1 ⇒ B1j1,
n21 ⇒ B21, n22 ⇒ B22 ..., n2j2 ⇒ B2j2
 ⋮,
ni1 ⇒ Bi1, ni2 ⇒ Bi2 ..., niji ⇒ Biji |
true

Then each binder n ⇒ B asserts that the generic name n will be bound to B, whose type is type B. The appearances of true indicate that the bindings satisfy the two criteria described previously. If it is not possible to construct a proof that ends with statements like these, then the generic form call is in error.
      By convention, if a generic name appears free multiple times in the parameter types, then the leftmost possible appearance of that name in the parameter types determines its binding. This convention may be changed in future versions of Orson. As a result, a generic form should be written so that each of its generic names appears exactly once in its parameter types. A generic name should appear more than once only if it does not matter which of its appearances is bound first.
      Suppose that the generic names can be bound to satisfy the criteria. Then F’s defining scope is entered. The generic names abbreviated as n are bound to their corresponding types abbreviated as B. Each parameter name m is also bound to its corresponding coerced argument A⦃T⟨B⟩⦄. Next, the generic form’s body s is transformed to a new expression or object S and its type S′. If S is an expression, then the generic names that appear as units in s may be replaced in S by the types to which they were bound, and the parameter names that appear as units in s may be replaced in S by the coerced arguments to which they were bound. The defining scope of F is then exited, restoring the generic names and the parameter names to their previous bindings.
      If the type S′ is a cotype of the yield type Y⟨B⟩, then S is coerced to S⦃Y⟨B⟩⦄ and its type, a subtype of Y⟨B⟩. The generic form call then transforms to S⦃Y⟨B⟩⦄ and its type. This occurs with a generic form that is intended to return an expression or object which is computed by its body. However, if Y⟨B⟩ is the type void, and S′ is an execution type other than void, then the generic form call transforms to a subsequence (S ; skip), whose type is void. This occurs with a generic form that is intended only to perform side effects. It is an error if neither alternative is possible.

Example. The following equate binds the name ieia to a generic form that increments the elements of an integer array variable l by an integer r.

ieia :− 
i(gen (type inj a) 
i(ggen (type a b) 
i(ggform (var [] a l, b r) void: 
i(ggf(with a Δ :− r 
i(ggf(do (for int i in length(l) 
i(ggf(do (do l[i] += Δ)))

Inside ieia, the for clause acts as a counting loop that binds the name i to successive indexes of l. The with clause binds the name Δ so that the expression to which r transforms need not be repeatedly executed inside the loop. The assignment l[i] += Δ increments the ith element of l.
      Suppose that v evaluates to a variable of type var [10] int, and that k evaluates to an integer of type int. Then the call ieia(v, k) increments all ten elements of v by k. The generic form call that results from the assignment binds both generic names a and b to int. This is consistent with the generic prefixes, which assert that a must be a subtype of the joker type inj, and that b must be a subtype of a. The bindings of a and b can also be deduced by the following proof.

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type b ⊆ type a, b ⇒ b |
var [10] int ⊑ var [] a, int ⊑ b

  1

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type b ⊆ type a, b ⇒ b |
var [10] int ⊑ var [] a, int ⊆ b

  1

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type b ⊆ type a, b ⇒ b |
var [10] int ⊆ var [] a, int ⊆ b

  10

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type int ⊆ type a, b ⇒ int | var [10] int ⊆ var [] a

  18

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type int ⊆ type a, b ⇒ int | [10] int ⊆ [] a

  74

type a ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ a, type int ⊆ type a, b ⇒ int | int ⊆ a

  10

type int ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ int, type int ⊆ type int, b ⇒ int | true

  0

type int ⊆ type inj, a ⇒ int, b ⇒ int | true

  17

int ⊆ inj, a ⇒ int, b ⇒ int | true

  50

true, a ⇒ int, b ⇒ int | true

As expected, the binders at the end of the proof assert that both a and b are bound to int. As a result, the argument v is coerced to the parameter type var [] a, which is equivalent to var [] int because of a’s binding. The argument k is also coerced to the parameter type b, which is equivalent to int because of its binding. However, these coercions have no effect, because v and k already have the types to which they are coerced.
      The defining scope of ieia is then entered. The parameter name l is bound to the argument v, and the parameter name r is bound to the argument k. Next, the form’s body is transformed. The generic names a and b are replaced in the transformed body by the types to which they are bound, and the parameter names l and r are replaced by the arguments to which they are bound. The call to the form length transforms to the integer 10, the number of elements in the array v. The result of transformation is a new with clause that is equivalent to the following.

(with int Δ :− k 
(do (for int i in 10 
(do (do v[i] += Δ))

When ieia’s defining scope is exited, the generic names a and b, and the parameter names l and r are restored to their previous bindings. The transformed body shown above is also coerced to the yield type void. However, the with clause already has the type void, because of the for clause inside it, so the coercion has no effect. As a result, the call transforms to an expression that is equivalent to the one shown above, whose type is void.
      In a real Orson program, the type int transforms to a hook. The for clause transforms to a with clause that has a while clause inside it. The expression a[i] += u transforms to an expression that calls the index form "␣[]", and the increment form "+=". The form calls in turn transform to hook calls. All these were omitted to simplify the example.

5.10.2.9. If clauses.

An if clause first evaluates an expression b to an integer. Depending on that integer, it then evaluates either an expression t or an expression e. Each if clause looks like this.

(if b then t else e)

Transforming an if clause. An if clause is transformed in the following way. First, b is transformed to B, which must be an integer or an expression of some integer type. It usually has the type bool. If B is an integer, then there are two possibilities.

  • Suppose that B is an integer other than 0. Then t is transformed to a new expression or object T and its type T′, but e is not transformed. The if clause transforms to T and T′. The type T′ may be any type.

  • Suppose that B is the integer 0. Then e is transformed to a new expression or object E and its type E′, but t is not transformed. The if clause transforms to E and E′. The type E′ may be any type.

If B is an expression, then t is transformed to a new expression or object T and its type T′. Also, e is transformed to a new expression or object E and its type E′. Since either T or E might be executed later, both T′ and E′ must be execution types. However, one or both of T and E might not execute to instances if the last expression they execute is a call to the forms exit or throw. (Orson determines this during transformation in an unspecified way.) As a result, there are now four possibilities.

  • Suppose that neither T or E will execute to instances. Then the if clause transforms to (if B then T else E), whose type is void.

  • Suppose that T will execute to an instance, but E will not. Then the if clause transforms to (if B then T else E), whose type is T′.

  • Suppose that E will execute to an instance, but T will not. Then the if clause transforms to (if B then T else E), whose type is E′.

  • Suppose that both T and E will execute to instances. If T′ is a cotype of E′, then the if clause transforms to (if B then T⦃E′⦄ else E), whose type is E′. If E′ is a cotype of T′, then the if clause transforms to (if B then T else E⦃T′⦄), whose type is T′. Otherwise, the if clause transforms to (if B then T ; skip else E ; skip), whose type is void. The subsequences discard the instances returned by T and E, returning skip instead.

If clauses of type void are assumed to be executed only for their side effects.

Executing an if clause. A transformed if clause (if B then T else E) is executed in the following way. First B is executed to an integer. There are now two possibilities.

  • Suppose that B executes to an integer other than 0. Then T is executed, but E is not. The instance returned by T is then returned by the if clause. If T does not return an instance, then the if clause also does not return an instance.

  • Suppose that B executes to the integer 0. Then E is executed, but T is not. The instance returned by E is then returned by the if clause. If E does not return an instance, then the if clause also does not return an instance.

Abbreviations. If clauses may be abbreviated as shown in the following table. The else part of an if clause can be omitted, and an if clause that follows else can be written without surrounding parentheses.

Abbreviated

Unabbreviated

 (if b then t)  

 (if b then t else skip)  

 (if b1 then t1 else ... if b2 then t2) 

 (if b1 then t1 else ... (if b2 then t2 else skip)) 

 (if b1 then t1 else ... if b2 then t2 else e2) 

 (if b1 then t1 else ... (if b2 then t2 else e2)) 

There is no abbreviation for an if clause that follows then, because this would lead to the well-known ‘‘dangling else’’ ambiguity of the programming language Algol 60 [NAU 1963] and its many successors.

5.10.2.10. List clauses.

If the e’s are zero or more assignments separated by commas, then the following is a list clause.

(: e1, e2 ..., ek)

Each list clause transforms to a list whose elements are the expressions and objects that result from transforming the e’s. The list clause (:) transforms to an empty list with zero elements. There may be a limit on the number of elements in a list. Each list has the type list. Lists are pure transformation instances; their type list is a pure transformation type. A list clause is similar to the function list in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

5.10.2.11. Past clauses.

If n is a name, then (past n) is a past clause. It must appear in a prog or with clause that has an equate which binds n. The past clause transforms to the expression or object, and its type, to which n was bound in the scope outside that of the prog or with clause. It is an error if n is not bound in that scope.
      A prog or with clause that contains (past n) abbreviates a similar clause in which (past n) is replaced by n, and n is replaced by a unique name u that appears nowhere else. For example, the with clause on the left abbreviates the one on the right. If the method writeln displays its integer argument on an output device, then both clauses display first 1, then 2.

(with int n :− 1 
(do (with int n :− 2 
(do (do writeln((past n)) 
(do (do writeln(n)))

          

(with int n :− 1 
(do (with int u :− 2 
(do (do writeln(n) 
(do (do writeln(u)))

Past clauses are often used along with forms. For example, the standard prelude binds the quoted name "/" to an alternate form with a member that performs integer division, but does not check for division by 0. The following equate rebinds "/" to a similar alternate form that throws an exception if integer division by 0 is attempted.

inj "tried to divide by zero" :− except() 
i
"/" :− 
"(form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((with inj r :− (past r) 
"((do (if r = 0 
"((do (then throw("tried to divide by zero") 
"((do (else (past "/")(l, r))))

In the example, the past clause (past r) ensures that the argument which is bound to the parameter name r will be evaluated only once. The past clause (past "/") obtains the original form to which "/" was bound by the standard prelude. That form is called when r is not 0.

5.10.2.12. Proc clauses.

A proc clause evaluates to a procedure. A procedure itself is a method whose call evaluates to an execution instance other than a variable. Procedures are pure execution instances; their types are both transformation and execution types. Each proc clause looks like this. It consists of a procedure type, followed by a colon, followed in turn by an expression s called the body.

(proc (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y: s)

In the procedure type, there are zero or more t n pairs, called parameters. They describe the arguments with which the procedure can be called. Each t is a term that transforms to an execution type called a parameter type, and each n is a name called a parameter name. Any or all of the parameter names may be missing, and all the parameter names must be distinct from each other. A parameter with a missing name describes an unused argument. There may be a limit on the number of parameters in a procedure type. The term y transforms to an execution type, but not a variable type, called the yield type. It describes the object to which the call evaluates.

Evaluating a proc clause. When a proc clause is evaluated, it is first transformed and then executed. When it is transformed, each parameter type t transforms to a corresponding type T, and the yield type transforms to the type Y. A new scope is then entered. Each parameter name n is bound to itself and its corresponding parameter type T. The body s is transformed to a new expression S and its type S′. Since the parameter names were bound to themselves, if they appear as units in s, then they may also appear as units in S. After transformation, the new scope is exited, restoring the parameter names to their previous bindings.
      Next, the procedure’s body is constructed. If S′ is a cotype of the yield type Y, then the body is the expression S⦃Y⦄, in which S is coerced to Y. This occurs in a procedure that is intended to return an execution instance computed by its body. However, if Y is the type void, and S′ is an execution type other than void, then the procedure’s body is the subsequence (S ; skip), whose type is void. This occurs in a procedure that is intended only to perform side effects. It is an error if neither alternative is possible.
      Finally, the transformed proc clause executes to a new procedure that contains the transformed parameter types, the parameter names, the transformed yield type, and the transformed body. It also contains a copy of the current scope, called its defining scope, which is used when the procedure is called. The new procedure’s type is the procedure type on the left of the colon.

Procedure calls. Each procedure call looks like the following, where p is a unit that evaluates to a procedure P, and the a’s are assignments that evaluate to P’s arguments. The procedure and its arguments are evaluated in an unspecified order.

p(a1, a2 ..., ak)

Each argument a is evaluated to a corresponding execution instance A and its type A′. There must be as many arguments as P has parameters, so that each instance A and its type A′ correspond to a parameter T n. Each argument type A′ must be a cotype of its corresponding parameter type T, so that the instance A can be coerced to the parameter type T.
      After all the arguments are evaluated, P’s defining scope is entered. Each parameter name n is then bound to its corresponding coerced argument instance A⦃T⦄, whose type is T. If the parameter type T is a variable type, and A⦃T⦄ is a variable, then the parameter name n is bound to A⦃T⦄ itself. (For historical reasons, the argument is said to be passed by reference.) If the parameter type T is not a variable type, then the parameter name n is bound to a copy of A⦃T⦄ instead. (For historical reasons, the argument is said to be passed by value.)
      After all the parameter names are bound, P’s transformed body is executed to an instance I, whose type is the yield type Y. The procedure P’s defining scope is then exited, restoring its parameter names to their original bindings, and making its copied arguments undefined. The call finally evaluates to I.
      Now suppose that a parameter name is bound to a variable, and that the variable’s value is changed as a side effect of executing the procedure’s body. Then the variable will retain its changed value after the procedure call returns. This lets a procedure use variable arguments to communicate with its caller. Suppose instead that a parameter name is bound to an instance other than a variable. Then the instance is copied to prevent variables that may be parts of the instance from being unintentionally changed in this way.

5.10.2.13. Tuple clauses.

A tuple clause transforms to the type of a tuple. A tuple itself is a pure execution instance that contains zero or more other execution instances, possibly of different types. It is similar to a struct in the programming language C [KER 1988]. Tuple types are both transformation types and execution types. Each tuple clause looks like this.

(tuple t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk)

In the tuple clause, there are zero or more t n pairs called slots. They describe the execution instances that are part of the tuple. Each t is a term that transforms to the type of an execution instance, called a slot type, and each n is a name, called a slot name. Any or all of the slot names may be missing, and all the slot names must be distinct from each other. A slot with the missing name ⬚ describes an unused instance. There may be a limit on the number of slots in a tuple type.
      Rule 32 describes how a tuple type can be a subtype of another tuple type. In the rule, both tuple types have the same number of slots. Each slot type t on the left is a subtype of its corresponding slot type T on the right. Each slot name n on the left is a subname of its corresponding slot name N on the right.

(tuple t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) ⊆ (tuple T1 N1, T2 N2 ..., Tk Nk)

 32

t1 ⊆ T1, $n1 ⊆ $N1, t2 ⊆ T2, $n2 ⊆ $N2 ..., tk ⊆ Tk, $nk ⊆ $Nk

For example, the following proof demonstrates that the tuple type (tuple real re, real im) is a subtype of the tuple type (tuple real re, real), one of whose slot names is missing.

(tuple real re, real im) ⊆ (tuple real re, real ⬚)

  32

real ⊆ real, $re ⊆ $re, $im ⊆ $⬚

  33

real ⊆ real, $re ⊆ $re

  0

real ⊆ real

  0

true

In memory, a tuple’s slots are stored in the same order that they appear in its type. As a result, the size of a tuple type without jokers is at least the sum of the sizes of its slot types.

size((tuple t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk))  ≥  size(t1) + size(t2) ... + size(tk)

The size may be greater than the sum because Orson may add void slots with missing names to the tuple, satisfying the alignment requirements of some computers. As a result, the size of a tuple type might vary from one implementation of Orson to another.

5.10.2.14. While clauses.

Suppose that b is an expression with an integer type, and s is an expression with an execution type. Then (while b do s) is a while clause. It transforms to an expression that repeatedly executes s for its side effects as long as b does not execute to 0. The expression b usually has the type bool.
      The while clause abbreviates the following infinitely nested if clauses and subsequences, in which b is transformed exactly once, and s is transformed at most once. Orson can implement while clauses finitely using tests and jumps [PAT 2005].

(if b then s ; (if b then s ; (if b then s ; ... else skip) else skip) else skip)

Because of the abbreviation, if b transforms to 0, then s is never transformed. A while clause either executes forever, or else terminates and returns skip.
      The while clause (while b) is an abbreviation for (while b do skip). In particular, the while clause (while s ; b) transforms to an expression that repeatedly executes s one or more times, until b executes to 0. This is like the do statement of the programming language C [KER 1988].

5.10.2.15. With clauses.

A with clause binds zero or more names, evaluates an expression in which the names may appear as units, restores the names to their previous bindings, and finally returns the result of evaluating the expression. Each with clause looks like this.

(with t1 n1 :− e1 ; t2 n2 :− e2 ...; tj nj :− ej do s)

The expression s is called the body, and each triple t n :− e is called an equate, where t is a term, n is a name, and e is an assignment. Each equate binds the name n to the expression or object of type t that results from evaluating e. A with clause can have zero or more equates; there may be an upper limit on how many equates it can have. The n’s in the equates must be distinct from each other, and none of them may be missing. The symbol ‘:-’ may appear instead of the symbol ‘:−’. There may be an extra semicolon after the last equate.
      Like other expressions, with clauses are evaluated by transformation followed by execution. However, transforming a with clause is more complex than transforming other clauses. This is because equates can bind names in several different ways.

Transforming a with clause. When a with clause is transformed, a new scope is entered, and the n’s are made unbound in that scope. Its equates are then transformed, one at a time, in order of their appearance. Some equates vanish immediately after being transformed. Others transform to new equates that will be executed later.
      When an equate t n :− e is transformed, its term t must transform to a type T. Its assignment e also transforms to an expression or object E and its type E′. Orson now finishes transforming the equate in one of four possible ways, trying them in the following order, and choosing exactly one of them according to T, E, and E′. It is an error if Orson cannot transform the equate in any of these ways.

  • Orson first tries to bind n during transformation by extending an existing form. Suppose that E is a form, and that n was previously bound to another form F outside the with clause.
