Also suppose that E′ is a subtype of T. Then n is bound to a new alternate form (alt E, F) and its type. The new alternate form is said to inherit the members of F. Subsumed members are deleted without reporting errors. The equate finally vanishes.

  • Orson then tries to bind n to some other object during transformation. Suppose that E is a transformation object. Also suppose that its type E′ is a cotype of T. Then E is coerced to the type T, resulting in a new expression or object E⦃T⦄ whose type is a subtype of T. The name n is bound to E⦃T⦄ and its type, and the equate vanishes.

  • Orson next tries to transform the equate to one that binds n to a variable during execution. Suppose that T is a variable type var B without jokers. Also suppose that E′ is a cotype of B. Then E is coerced to B, resulting in a new expression or object E⦃B⦄ whose type is B. The name n is bound to itself and the type var B. The equate transforms to a new equate var B n :− (E⦃T⦄) that will be executed later.

  • Orson finally tries to transform the equate to one that binds n to some other instance during execution. Suppose that T is the type of an execution object, and that E is an expression or an object. Also suppose that E′ is a cotype of T. Then E is coerced to a new expression or object E⦃T⦄ whose type T′ is a subtype of T. The name n is bound to itself and the type T′. The equate also transforms to a new equate T′ n :− (E⦃T⦄) that will be executed later.

After the equates are transformed, the body s is transformed to an object or expression S, and its type S′. The scope that was entered at the beginning of transformation is exited, so that names bound by transforming the equates are restored to their previous bindings.
      If all equates vanished during transformation, then the original with clause transforms to S (which is not necessarily another with clause) and its type S′. The type S′ may be any type. However, if at least one equate did not vanish, then the original with clause transforms to a new with clause that will be executed later. It contains the equates that did not vanish, in order of their transformation, and the transformed body S. Its type is S′, which must be an execution type.

Executing a with clause. Suppose that the original with clause transforms to the following new with clause, with one or more equates. The T’s are execution types, the N’s are names, and the E’s are expressions.

(with T1 N1 :− (E1) ; T2 N2 :− (E2) ...; Tk Nk :− (Ek) do S)

When the new with clause is executed, a new scope is entered, and the N’s are made unbound in that scope. Its equates are then executed one at a time, in order of their appearance. Each equate T N :− (E) is executed in one of two ways, depending on its type T. If T is a variable type, then N is bound to a new variable of type T, whose initial value is a copy of the instance to which E executes. If T is not a variable type, then N is bound directly to a copy of that instance.
      After all the equates have been executed in this way, the expression S is executed. The new scope is then exited, restoring the names bound by the equates to their previous bindings. Also, all variables and other instances that were created by executing the equates become undefined. The with clause finally returns the object to which S executes, whose type is S′.

Abbreviations. The equate n :− e abbreviates obj n :− e. Since the joker obj describes any object, the equate binds n to the expression or object, and its type, that results from evaluating e. By convention, this abbreviation is used when e’s type is obvious from context, such as when e evaluates to a method or a type.
      If t transforms to a variable type var B, then the equate t n abbreviates t n :− ◌, where ◌ is used by this Report to mean an unspecified instance of type B. By convention, this abbreviation is used when the variable n will be initialized later in the with clause. It is an error to use this abbreviation if n’s value is a base pointer that will be visited by the refs iterator. This is because refs assumes that all base pointers reference tuples which reside in the heap.

Example. This nested with clause shows how an equate can bind a name to an alternate form that inherits members from another form. It uses two abbreviated equates without type terms.

(with 
(winc :− (form (int k) int: k + 1) 
(do (with 
(do (winc :− (form (int k, int Δ) int: k + Δ) 
(do (do inc))

The equates vanish after being transformed, so the with clause transforms to this alternate form.

(alt 
((form (int k, int Δ) int: k + Δ), 
((form (int k) int: k + 1))

The alternate form has two members, each of which increment an integer k. The first member adds Δ, and the second adds 1.

Example. This with clause computes the Fibonacci numbers f₀, f₁ ..., f₇ by using equates in various contrived ways, then returns f₇. The comments show the Fibonacci number that is computed by each equate.

(with

   

int0 f₀ :− 0

    !  

0

 

int1 f₁ :− 1

    !  

1

 

inj f₂ :− f₀ + f₁

    !  

1

 

f₃ :− f₁ + f₂

    !  

2

 

var int1 f₄ :− f₂ + f₃

    !  

3

 

var int2 f₅ :− f₃ + f₄

    !  

5

 

int2 f₆ :− f₄ + f₅

    !  

8

 

var int2 f₇

    !  

13

 do f₇ := f₅ + f₆ 
 do f₇)

When the with clause is transformed, its equates are transformed one at a time, in order of their appearance. The first equate is int0 f₀ :− 0. The integer 0 is a transformation object, so the equate binds f₀ during transformation. Its type int0 is the same as the equate’s type int0, so it need not be coerced. The equate simply binds f₀ to 0 and its type int0, then vanishes.
      The second equate is int1 f₁ :− 1. The integer 1 is a transformation object, so the equate binds f₁ during transformation. However, its type int0 is different from the equate’s type int1, so it is coerced to 1⦃int1⦄. The equate binds f₁ to 1⦃int1⦄ and its type int1, then vanishes.
      The third equate is inj f₂ :− f₀ + f₁. It transforms the sum f₀ + f₁ to 1 and its type int0, using the bindings of f₀ and f₁ from earlier equates. The integer 1 is a transformation object, so the equate binds f₂ during transformation. Its type int0 is a cotype of inj, the joker that describes all integers, so it need not be coerced. The equate binds f₂ to 1 and its type int0, then vanishes.
      The fourth equate is f₃ :− f₁ + f₂, which abbreviates obj f₃ :− f₁ + f₂. It transforms f₁ + f₂ to 2 and its type int0, using the bindings of f₁ and f₂ from earlier equates. The integer 2 is a transformation object, so the equate binds f₃ during transformation. Its type int0 is a cotype of obj, the joker that describes all objects, so it need not be coerced. The equate binds f₃ to 2 and its type int0, then vanishes.
      The fifth equate is var int1 f₄ :− f₂ + f₃. It binds f₄ to itself and the type var int1 during transformation. It also transforms to a new equate that will bind f₄ to a variable of type var int1 during execution. The equate transforms f₂ + f₃ to 3 and its type int0, using the bindings of f₂ and f₃ from earlier equates. Since 3 will be the variable’s initial value, it is coerced to the variable’s base type, resulting in 3⦃int1⦄. The new equate is therefore equivalent to var int1 f₄ :− 3⦃int1⦄.
      The sixth equate is var int2 f₅ :− f₃ + f₄. It binds f₅ to itself and the type var int2 during transformation. It also transforms to a new equate that will bind f₅ to a variable of type var int2 during execution. The equate transforms f₃ + f₄ to a new expression that is equivalent to 2 + f₄ and its type int1, using the bindings of f₃ and f₄ from earlier equates. Since this expression will execute to the variable’s initial value, it is coerced to the variable’s base type, resulting in (2 + f₄)⦃int2⦄. The new equate is therefore equivalent to var int2 f₅ :− (2 + f₄)⦃int1⦄.
      The seventh equate is int2 f₆ :− f₄ + f₅. It binds f₆ to itself and the type int2 during transformation. It also transforms to a new equate that will bind f₆ to an integer of type int2 during execution. Since f₄ and f₅ were bound to themselves by earlier equates, it transforms f₄ + f₅ to an expression that is equivalent to itself. Since this expression already has the type int2, it need not be coerced. The new equate is therefore equivalent to the original equate, int2 f₆ :− f₄ + f₅.
      The eighth equate is var int2 f₇, which abbreviates var int2 f₇ :− ◌, where ◌ is an unspecified integer of type int2. The equate binds f₇ to itself and the type var int2 during transformation. It also transforms to a new equate that is equivalent to the original unabbreviated equate, var int2 f₇ :− ◌.
      After the with clause’s equates are transformed, its body is also transformed. Since f₅, f₆, and f₇ were bound to themselves by equates, the body transforms to a new expression that is equivalent to the original body (f₇ := f₆ + f₅; f₇). The following is the transformed with clause. It contains the transformed equates that did not vanish, and the transformed body.

(with

    

var int1 f₄ :− 3⦃int1⦄

    !  

3

 

var int2 f₅ :− (2 + f₄)⦃int2⦄

    !  

5

 

int2 f₆ :− f₄ + f₅

    !  

8

 

var int2 f₇ :− ◌

    !  

13

 do f₇ := f₅ + f₆ 
 do f₇)

When this with clause is executed, its equates are executed one at a time, in order of their appearance. The first equate var int1 f₄ :− 3⦃int1⦄ binds f₄ to a new variable of type var int1, whose value is 3. The second equate var int2 f₅ :− (2 + f₄)⦃int2⦄ executes (2 + f₄)⦃int2⦄ to 5, using the binding of f₄ from the earlier equate. It binds f₅ to a new variable of type var int2, whose value is 5. The third equate int2 f₆ :− f₄ + f₅ executes f₄ + f₅ to 8 and its type int2, using the bindings of f₄ and f₅ from earlier equates. It binds f₆ to 8, an integer of type int2. The fourth equate var int2 f₇ :− ◌ binds f₇ to a new variable of type var int2, whose value is an unspecified integer of type int2.
      After the with clause’s equates are executed, its body is also executed. The body first executes f₅ + f₆ to 13, an integer of type int2, using the bindings of f₅ and f₆ from the equates. It then changes the value of the variable f₇ to 13, and finally returns that value.
      In a real Orson program, the types inj, int0, int1, and int2 transform to hooks. Expressions that use the addition form "+" and the assignment form ":=" transform to hook calls. Coercions transform to hook calls that implement casts. These were omitted to simplify the example.

5.10.3. Hooks.

If n is a plain name, then the unit ?n is a hook. A hook denotes a primitive mechanism provided by Orson. The name n suggests the mechanism’s purpose. Some hooks are types. For example, the hooks ?int0, ?int1, and ?int2 are integer types. Other hooks are instances. For example, the hook ?nil is the null pointer, and the hook ?skip is the void object. Still other hooks are called like methods. For example, the call ?intAdd(l, r) evaluates to the sum of its integer arguments l and r.
      Unlike other hooks, callable hooks are not objects, and do not have types. It is undefined to call a hook with arguments that are different from those it expects. A callable hook might accept a varying number of arguments, it might not evaluate all its arguments, and it might evaluate some of its arguments many times. As a result, clauses might abbreviate hook calls. For example, the while clause (while b do s) might abbreviate the call ?whileClause((b), (s)).
      Each implementation of Orson may provide a different set of hooks, so that programs which use hooks may not be portable. Hooks can therefore appear in libraries and preludes, but must not appear in other programs. This Report mentions hooks, but does not describe them. The hooks mentioned in this Report might not be provided by any implementation of Orson.

5.10.4. Literals.

Literals are units that transform to objects of certain types. There are four kinds of literals, called character literals, integer literals, real literals, and string literals. They are described in the next few sections of this Report.

5.10.4.1. Character literals.

A character literal is a character token. It transforms to a character, whose type is the smallest character type that describes it. For example, the character literal 'A' transforms to a character of type char0, and the character literal '∀' transforms to a character of type char1.
      Characters of other types can be obtained by casts. For example, the unit 'A'{char1} transforms to a character of type char1. A character with a negative code can be obtained by a unit that uses the minus operator ‘-’ or ‘−’. For example, the unit (−1){char0} transforms to the character of type char0 whose code is −1.

5.10.4.2. Integer literals.

An integer literal is an integer token. It transforms to a nonnegative integer, whose type is the smallest integer type that describes it. It is an error if no available integer type describes it. For example, the integer literal 100 transforms to an integer of type int0.
      Integers of other types can be obtained by casts. For example, the unit 100{int2} transforms to an integer of type int2. A negative integer can be obtained by a term that uses the minus operator ‘-’ or ‘−’. For example, the term −100 transforms to a negative integer of type int0, and the unit (−100){int2} transforms to a negative integer of type int2.

5.10.4.3. Real literals.

A real literal is a real token. It transforms to a nonnegative real number whose type is real. If the literal denotes a real number which can be exactly represented using the type real, then it transforms to that real number. If the literal denotes a real number that cannot be exactly represented using the type real, but is within the range of real numbers which can be represented in that way, then it transforms to the largest real number that is less than the literal, or to the smallest real number that is greater than the literal [KER 1988]. It is an error if the literal denotes a real number that is outside the range which can be represented using the type real.
      Real numbers of other types can be obtained by casts. For example, the unit 1.0{real0} transforms to a real number of type real0. A negative real number can be obtained by a term that uses the minus operator ‘-’ or ‘−’. For example, the term −1.0 transforms to a negative real number of type real, and the unit (−1.0){real0} transforms to a negative real number of type real0.

5.10.4.4. String literals.

A string literal is a string token. It transforms to a string whose type is string. Orson appends a null character to the end of each string literal, so it has one more character than is apparent, as in the programming language C [KER 1988]. For example, the string literal ''Ten␣chars'' really does have ten characters. The null character should not be confused with the type null.
      The number of characters in a string literal may be limited by the maximum number of characters on a line. A string that is too long to fit on a line may be created by concatenating two or more string literals with the ‘&’ operator.

5.10.5. Names.

A unit can be a name. The name can have a binding that determines how it is transformed and executed. A name’s binding is determined by the region of the expression or program in which it appears, called a scope. Scopes can be nested inside other scopes. Nested scopes can interact through inheritance, shadowing, capture, and closure, as described in the next few sections of this Report.

5.10.5.1. Bindings.

A name that has a binding is said to be bound. A name that has no binding is said to be unbound. These words are borrowed from the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007]. The missing name cannot have a binding. Attempting to give it a binding, as in a method call, is not an error, but simply has no effect.
      Binding a name should not be confused with assigning a value to a variable. Most programming languages do not clearly distinguish names from variables. In Orson, however, names are not variables. Instead, a name may be bound to a variable, whose value may be changed by assignment. Distinguishing names from variables helps Orson do computations during transformation.

Transformation bindings. During transformation, a name’s binding has two parts. The first part is an expression or a transformation object. The second part is a type that describes the expression or object. The name is said to be bound to the expression or object, and its type. A bound name transforms to the expression or object, and the type, in its binding. It is an error to transform an unbound name.

Execution bindings. During execution, a name’s binding has only one part, an execution instance. The name is said to be bound to that instance. A bound name executes to the instance in its binding. It is impossible to execute an unbound name, because the name would also be unbound during transformation. Transforming an unbound name causes an error that prevents the name’s later execution.

Rebinding. A name is said to be rebound when it is given a new binding, or when it is made unbound after being bound. Names can be rebound both during transformation and during execution. They can be rebound many times.

5.10.5.2. Scopes.

A scope is a textual region of an expression in which zero or more names are bound. The expression is said to establish the scope. Expressions that establish scopes include generic form types, form clauses, gen clauses, proc clauses, and with clauses. Although prog clauses are not expressions, they also establish scopes.
      Establishing a scope involves three steps. First, the scope is entered: the bindings (or lack of bindings) of its names are saved, and the names are rebound. Next, a computation is performed that involves the names and their bindings. Finally, the scope is exited: the names are rebound to their originally saved bindings (or lack of bindings). After the scope is exited, all names have the same bindings (or lack of bindings) that they did before the scope was entered.
      This Report also sometimes uses the word scope to mean the set of all names and their bindings that exist at some point in a program. A method is then said to record the scope in which it is created, called its defining scope. It is also said to be closed in its defining scope. When the method is called, its defining scope is entered; after the call, its defining scope is exited, leaving its bindings unchanged.

5.10.5.3. Nesting.

Suppose that there are two expressions which establish scopes, and that the second expression appears in the scope established by the first. Then the scope established by the first expression is called an outer scope, and the scope established by the second is called an inner scope. The inner scope is also said to be nested inside the outer one. There may be a limit on the number of scopes that can be nested in this way.

5.10.5.4. Inheritance.

Suppose that an outer scope binds a name, but an inner scope does not rebind the name. Then the name has the same binding in the inner scope as it did in the outer scope. The inner scope is said to inherit the name and its binding from the outer scope. For example, the first with clause establishes an outer scope in which the name j is bound to the integer 1. The second with clause establishes an inner scope that inherits j, and that binds the name k to the integer 2.

(with int j :− 1 
(do (with int k :− 2 
(do (do writeln(j + k)))

If the method "+" computes the sum of two integers, and the method writeln displays its argument on an output device, then the integer 3 will be displayed.

5.10.5.5. Shadowing.

Suppose that an outer scope binds a name, and an inner scope rebinds the same name. Then the binding of that name is not inherited, but has the binding given to it by the inner scope. The inner scope is said to shadow the name. For example, the first with clause establishes an outer scope in which the name k is bound to the integer 1. The second with clause then establishes an inner scope in which k is rebound to the integer 2, so that it shadows k.

(with int k :− 1 
(do writeln(k) 
(do (with int k :− 2 
(do (do writeln(k)) 
(do writeln(k))

If the method writeln displays its argument on an output device, then 1, 2, and 1 will be displayed.

5.10.5.6. Capture.

Suppose that an expression establishes a scope in which the name n is bound. Also suppose that another name m is inherited in the same scope. For example, the expression might be a with clause (with var int n :− 1 do m + n) that evaluates to m plus 1.
      Now suppose that m is bound to n, and that the with clause is transformed to a new with clause by a naive algorithm which simply replaces names by their bindings. Since the original with clause returned m plus 1, and m is replaced by n, the new with clause might be expected to return n plus 1. However, it does not: the new with clause is (with var int n :− 1 do n + n), which returns 2. This is because the n that replaced m during transformation is confused with the n that appeared in the original with clause.
      Confusing names in this way is called name capture [KOH 1986]. Orson avoids name capture by using an unspecified algorithm that is more sophisticated than the one in the example. This algorithm might replace confused names by new unique names that appear nowhere else. In the example, it might replace the n in the original with clause by a new unique name u before it replaces m. The result is the with clause (with var int u :− 1 do n + u) that returns n plus 1, as expected.

5.10.5.7. Closure.

Suppose that an outer scope binds a name and creates a method. Also suppose that the method’s body establishes an inner scope in which the name is inherited. Then, when the method is called, and its body is evaluated, the inherited name has the same binding as it did in the outer scope, where the method was created, even if the method is called in a scope that shadows the name. This is called closure, and the method is said to be closed. These words are borrowed from programming languages like Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

Closed methods. In the following example, a with clause establishes an outer scope in which the name v is bound to an integer variable that has the value 0. The name a is then bound to a form, and the name b is bound to a procedure, both of whose scopes inherit v. Finally, another with clause establishes an inner scope that inherits a, inherits b, and shadows v, rebinding v to another integer variable whose value is 1.

(with 
(wvar int v :− 0 
(wa :− (form () int: v) 
(wb :− (proc () int: v) 
(do (with var int v :− 1 
(do (do writeln(a()) 
(do (do writeln(b())))

The form a and the procedure b use the binding of v from the outer scope in which they were created. They do not use the binding of v from the inner scope in which they are called. If the method writeln displays its argument on an output device, then the integer 0 will be displayed twice.

Closure and execution instances. Closure has possibly unexpected consequences if names bound to pure execution instances are inherited from scopes that are later exited. This is shown by the following examples, both of which are incorrect.

(with 
(wa :− 
(wa(with var int v :− 0 
(wa(do (form () int: v)) 
(do writeln(a()))

          

(with 
(wb :− 
(wb(with var int v :− 0 
(wb(do (proc () int: v)) 
(do writeln(b()))

The example on the left is incorrect because a with clause whose equates create pure execution instances, like the variable v, must not return a pure transformation object, like a form. The call to a, which occurs during transformation, depends on the variable v, which is not created until execution. Transformation can affect execution, but not the reverse.
      The example on the right is also incorrect, even though a with clause whose equates create pure execution instances, like the variable v, can return another pure execution instance, like the procedure b. This is because v becomes undefined after the inner with clause terminates, so that calling b has undefined results.

Closure and transformation objects. However, it is always correct to inherit names that are bound to transformation objects, even after the scopes which bound them are exited. This is shown by the following examples.

(with 
(wa :− 
(wa(with int k :− 0 
(wa(do (form () int: k)) 
(do writeln(a()))

          

(with 
(wb :− 
(wb(with int k :− 0 
(wb(do (proc () int: k)) 
(do writeln(b()))

In both examples, k is bound to the integer 0, a transformation object. The left example binds a to a form that is equivalent to (form () int: 0). The right example binds b to a procedure that is equivalent to (proc () int: 0). Both examples display 0 on an output device.

5.10.6. Symbol types.

If n is a name, then the unit $n transforms to a symbol type. The unit $ denotes a symbol type $⬚ in which the missing name ⬚ is imagined to appear. Symbol types are pure transformation types. Like all types, each symbol type $n is a subtype of itself, as in rule 0. It is also a subtype of $⬚, as in rule 33. As a result, if l and r are names, then $l is a subtype of $r if and only if l is a subname of r.

$n ⊆ $⬚

 33

true

Symbol types do not describe objects, so no object has a symbol type as its type. Instead, symbol types stand for names without regard to the bindings of those names. They are types so they can be manipulated by the parameter mechanisms of plain and generic forms. For example, the generic form that defines the dot operator ‘.’ uses symbol types in this way to denote tuple slots. The form error uses symbol types in a different way to report errors in form calls and their arguments.

6. Programs.

And I take it we might make the progs feel a bit awkward.

[MIT 1935]

A program is a series of zero or more load clauses and prog clauses. Unlike other clauses, load and prog clauses are not units, so they can appear only as parts of programs, not as parts of expressions.

6.1. Prog clauses.

A prog clause binds zero or more names. Each prog clause looks like this.

(prog t1 n1 :− e1 ; t2 n2 :− e2 ... ; tj nj :− ej)

Each triple t n :− e is called an equate. In an equate, t is a term, n is a name, and e is an assignment. A prog clause may have zero or more equates, and there may be a limit on how many equates it can have. The n’s in the equates must be distinct from each other, and none of them may be missing. In any or all of the equates, the symbol ‘:-’ may appear instead of the symbol ‘:−’. There may be an extra semicolon after the last equate.
      Suppose that each ε is a series of zero or more equates. Then the following series of zero or more prog clauses, separated by semicolons, is a program. There may be an extra semicolon after the last prog clause. There may also be a limit on the number of prog clauses in a program.

(prog ε1) ; (prog ε2) ... ; (prog εk)

The program is equivalent to the following nested with clause, which returns skip. Because of this equivalence, the equates in a prog clause are evaluated in the same way as those in a with clause, and can be abbreviated in the same way as those in a with clause.

(with ε1 do (with ε2 do ... (with εk do skip) ... ))

Every prog clause in the program establishes a new scope. The first prog clause establishes an initial scope. Each later prog clause establishes a scope that is nested in the one established by its predecessor. As a result, if an equate in a prog clause binds a plain name or a quoted name in its scope, then that name can be inherited or shadowed by the scopes of later prog clauses.

6.1.1. Secret objects.

If a plain or quoted name appears in two or more prog clauses, then it is treated as the same name in each one. However, if a secret name appears in two or more prog clauses, then it is treated as a different name in each one. This lets each prog clause have its own secret names, different from those of other prog clauses.
      Orson might implement secret names in the following way. Each prog clause in a program is assigned a different number. The first might be assigned 1, the second might be assigned 2, etc. Whenever a secret name appears, the number of the current prog clause is made part of that name. For example, when the secret name A appears in prog clause number 1, it is treated as A¢1, but when it appears in prog clause number 2, it is treated as A¢2, etc. Here ‘¢’ is an unspecified character that can appear only in names created by Orson.
      Now suppose that an equate in a prog clause binds a secret name to an object. Also suppose that no other names are bound to the object, that no pointers reference it, that no calls return it, etc. Then the object is accessible inside the prog clause, but inaccessible outside it, because no other prog clause can even mention its name. Because of closure, however, the object can still be accessed by calling methods whose names are bound in the scope of the prog clause, and inherited by the scopes of later prog clauses.

6.1.2. Abstract data structures.

In an abstract data structure, some objects are hidden and manipulated only by calling trusted methods. A prog clause can implement an abstract data structure by binding secret names to the hidden objects, and by binding plain or quoted names to the methods that manipulate them. For example, the following prog clause implements a fixed length stack, the classic example of an abstract data structure [KNU 1975].

(prog 
(pinj "stack empty" :− except() 
(pinj "stack full" :− except() 
(
!  STACK. Return the type of a stack. 
!
! stack :− 
! s(alt 
! s((form (inj n, type mut b) type tup: 
! s(((if isInt(n) 
! s(((then (if n ≥ 0 
! s(((then (then (tuple 
! s(((then (then (tint Count, 
! s(((then (then (t[n] b Elements) 
! s(((then (else error($n, "non negative inj expression expected") 
! s(((then (else stack(0, b)) 
! s(((else error($n, "constant expected") 
! s(((else stack(0, b))), 
! s((form (type mut b) type tup: 
! s(((tuple 
! s(((tint Count, 
! s(((t[] b Elements))) 
!
!  ELEMENTS. Return an iterator that visits the elements of a stack s. 
!
! elements :− 
! e(gen (type mut b) 
! e(gform (stack(b) s) foj: 
! e(gf(form (form (b) obj body) obj: 
! e(gf((with stack(b) s :− (past s) 
! e(gf((do (for int j in s.Count 
! e(gf((do (do (with b e :− s.Elements[j] 
! e(gf((do (do (do body(e)))))) 
!
!  INIT. Initialize a stack s. 
!
! init :− 
! i(form (var stack(mut) s) void: 
! i(fs.Count := 0) 
!
!  ISEMPTY. Test if a stack s has no elements. 
!
! isEmpty :− 
! i(form (stack(mut) s) bool: 
! i(fs.Count = 0) 
!
!  ISFULL. Test if a stack s can have no more elements. 
!
! isFull :− 
! i(form (stack(mut) s) bool: 
! i(fs.Count = length(s.Elements)) 
!
!  PEEK. Return the top element of a nonempty stack s. 
!
! peek :− 
! p(gen (type mut b) 
! p(gform (var stack(b) s) b: 
! p(gf(if isEmpty(s) 
! p(gf(then throw("stack empty") 
! p(gf(else s.Elements[s.Count − 1])) 
!
!  POP. Delete the top element of a nonempty stack s and return it. 
!
! pop :− 
! p(gen (type mut b) 
! p(gform (var stack(b) s) b: 
! p(gf(if isEmpty(s) 
! p(gf(then throw("stack empty") 
! p(gf(else s.Count −= 1 
! p(gf(else s.Elements[s.Count])) 
!
!  PUSH. Add a new element n to the top of a nonfull stack s. 
!
! push :− 
! p(gen (type mut b) 
! p(ggen (type b e) 
! p(ggform (var stack(b) s, e n) void: 
! p(ggf(if isFull(s) 
! p(ggf(then throw("stack full") 
! p(ggf(else s.Elements[s.Count] := n 
! p(ggf(else s.Count += 1)) 
)

Each stack is represented as a tuple with two slots: the integer slot Count holds the number of elements in the stack, and the array slot Elements holds the elements themselves. Since these slots have secret names, they are inaccessible outside the prog clause. However, they can be accessed by calling methods that are defined inside the prog clause and inherited.
      The plain name stack is bound to a form whose call transforms to the type of a stack. Suppose that n transforms to a nonnegative integer, and that t transforms to the type of an execution instance, but not a variable type. Then the call stack(n, t) transforms to the type of a stack that can hold at most n elements of type t. The call stack(t) transforms to a type with jokers that describes any stack whose elements have the type t.
      The plain names elements, init, isEmpty, isFull, peek, pop, and push are bound to forms that implement stack operations. The name isEmpty is already bound to an alternate form by the standard prelude; here it acquires another member that operates on stacks. Since stack operations are implemented as forms, they work without the overhead of calling procedures. Since they check if a stack is empty or full before operating on it, they cannot make unsafe array accesses.
      Unfortunately, abstract data structures implemented in this way do not provide complete safety. For example, an enreferencer can obtain a pointer to the tuple that represents a stack. The tuple can then be accessed unsafely by casting and dereferencing the pointer. Orson makes it possible to write safe programs, but does not make it impossible to write unsafe ones.

6.2. Load clauses.

Load clauses let an Orson program reside on multiple files. Suppose that p is an expression which transforms to a portable pathname. Then (load p) is a load clause. It transforms to the series of prog clauses in the file specified by p. It is an error if the file does not exist or cannot be accessed. A load clause can appear anywhere that a prog clause can appear.
      When a file is loaded, both its load clauses and its prog clauses are transformed, so it can load other files. However, if a file has already been loaded, or is now being loaded, then any attempt to load it again is ignored. As a result, a file cannot load itself, either directly or indirectly.
      For example, the following program defines a procedure isBalanced that tests if the parentheses, braces, and brackets in the string s are balanced. These characters have the type char0, so they can be visited using simple pointer arithmetic. The procedure uses a stack whose methods are defined by loading a file whose pathname is the string ''stack''.

(load ''stack'') 
(prog 
(pinj n :− 100 
(
!  ISBALANCED. Test if the string s is balanced. 
!
! isBalanced :− 
! i(proc (string s) bool: 
! i((with 
! i((wvar bool g :− true 
! i((wvar stack(n, char) p 
! i((wvar string s :− (past s) 
!
!  OPEN. Push a character o on the stack p. 
!
!  OPEopen :− 
!  OPEo(proc (char o) void: 
!  OPEo(ppush(p, o)) 
!
!  CLOSE. Pop a character off the stack p and test if it is o. 
!
!  CLOclose :− 
!  CLOc(proc (char o) void: 
!  CLOc(pg := (o = pop(p))) 
!
!  This is ISBALANCED’s body. 
!
!  Thdo init(p) 
!  Thdo (case 
!  Thdo ((catch 
!  Thdo (((while g ∧ s↑ 
!  Thdo (((do (case s↑ 
!  Thdo (((do (of '(': open('(') 
!  Thdo (((do (of '[': open('[') 
!  Thdo (((do (of '{': open('{') 
!  Thdo (((do (of ')': close('(') 
!  Thdo (((do (of ']': close('[') 
!  Thdo (((do (of '}': close('{')) 
!  Thdo (((do s += 1)) 
!  Thdo (of "stack empty": false 
!  Thdo (of "stack full": rethrow() 
!  Thdo (of none: g ∧ isEmpty(p)))))

The procedure isBalanced creates an empty stack p and then visits characters from s. If it visits an opening character '(', '[', or '{', then it pushes that character on p. If p is full, so a character cannot be pushed, then isBalanced throws an exception. If isBalanced visits a closing character ')', ']', or '}', then it pops a character off p. If the popped character does not match the closing character, or if p is empty so a character cannot be popped, then isBalanced returns false. After visiting all characters from s, isBalanced returns true if the stack is empty, and false if it is not.
      It is intended that most Orson programs will be implemented using high-level abstract objects, like stacks. Low-level concrete objects, like arrays, pointers, and tuples, will be used primarily to implement these abstract objects. Implementations of commonly used abstract objects may be loaded from a library. Libraries are not described in this Report.

6.2.1. Pathnames.

Most modern operating systems store files in a tree [RIT 1974]. The tree’s internal nodes are directories, and its external nodes are files. Except for the directory at the root, each directory or file resides in the directory immediately above it in the tree. A pathname specifies a file by tracing a linear path through the tree, starting at the root, and ending at the file. Operating systems notate pathnames in various ways, so load clauses use portable pathnames that are independent of these notations.
      A portable pathname is a string of zero or more names, separated by dots. Each name is a series of one or more Roman letters and digits, in which upper and lower case letters are considered to be different. The first name may be a prefix that denotes the directory at the root of an important subtree. It is followed by zero or more names that denote the directories on a path between the root and the specified file. The last name denotes the specified file itself. It may be followed by an optional suffix that describes the file’s contents. There may be a limit on the number of characters in a portable pathname.

6.2.2. Prefixes.

The first name in a portable pathname may be a prefix that specifies where the path starts in the file system tree. There are at least three prefixes: lib, own, and top. Orson may also provide other prefixes that are not described in this Report.
      If the prefix is lib, then the path starts at an unspecified directory of library files. In the Unix operating system, this directory might be ‘/usr/lib/orson/’ [RIT 1974]. For example, the pathname ''lib.prelude'' specifies a file prelude in the library directory.
      If the prefix is own, then the path starts at the user’s private directory. In the Unix operating system, this directory is ‘ ~/ ’. For example, the pathname ''own.games.nurndy'' specifies a file nurndy in a directory games, which is in the user’s private directory.
      If the prefix is top, then the path starts at the root directory of the entire file system tree. In the Unix operating system, this directory is ‘ / ’. For example, the pathname ''top.usr.local.bin.orson'' specifies a file orson in a directory bin, which is in a directory local, which is in a directory usr, which is in the root directory.
      If there is no prefix, then the path starts at a default current directory. In the Unix operating system, this directory is ‘ ./ ’. For example, the pathname ''stack'' specifies a file stack in the current directory. Similarly, the pathname ''tests.stack'' specifies a file stack in the directory tests, which is in the current directory.

6.2.3. Suffixes.

In some operating systems, a file name can end with a suffix that describes the contents of the file. For example, the name of a file that contains text might end with the suffix txt. Suffixes are not described in this Report.
      A portable pathname can also optionally end in a suffix. The suffix is a colon followed by a series of one or more Roman letters and digits, in which upper and lower case letters are considered to be different. For example, the pathname ''own.note:txt'' specifies a file in the directory own, whose name is note, and whose suffix is txt.
      Files might represent Orson programs in many ways. A pathname’s suffix might state how a file represents a program, and how it should be loaded. For example, a suffix might state that a program is represented as a series of characters. A suffix might state that a program is represented as a series of machine instructions instead. A suffix might state that a program is a prelude, or is part of a library, so it is allowed to use hooks. A suffix might even state that a program is written in a language other than Orson.
      Suppose that pathnames can have several possible suffixes, and that these suffixes state how files should be loaded. Also suppose that a pathname without a suffix appears in a load clause. Then, when the load clause is transformed, Orson appends the first possible suffix to the end of the pathname, and tries to load the specified file. If the file does not exist, or cannot be read, then Orson does not report an error, but goes on to try the next possible suffix. Orson continues in this way, trying suffixes in an unspecified order, until it can load a file. It is an error if Orson cannot load a file after trying all possible suffixes.

7. Preludes.

We were all silent, for we knew instinctively that this was only a prelude.

[STO 2007]

A prelude is a prog clause that Orson loads automatically to initialize itself, so it is implicitly the first prog clause in every program. The prelude binds many names to commonly used objects. In particular, it binds the quoted names of operators to the forms that implement them.
      Orson may provide many preludes. If it provides more than one, then it also provides an unspecified way to select which one is loaded. At least one prelude is a standard prelude, an idea borrowed from the programming language Algol 68 [VWI 1977]. If no prelude is selected, then Orson loads a standard prelude by default.
      The following sections describe the equates that appear in a standard prelude. Most of these equates bind names to simple types, joker types, and forms. Within each section, equates appear in lexicographic order of the names they bind. However, in a real standard prelude, the equates appear in a different order, because some mention names that must be bound by earlier ones.

7.1. Standard simple types.

The standard prelude binds several plain names to simple types. These describe objects that are commonly provided by computers and their operating systems, including the Boolean type, the character types, the integer types, the list type, the null pointer type, the real types, the stream type, the string type, and the void type.

7.1.1. bool, false, and true.

The standard prelude binds the plain names bool, false, and true like this.

bool :− int0 
bool false :− 0 
bool true :− 1

Orson does not have a Boolean type, so it uses the integer type int0 to simulate one: the name bool is bound to the same type as the name int0. The integer 0 represents falsity, and any nonzero integer represents truth. As a result, the name false is bound to 0, and the name true is bound to 1. Booleans are both transformation instances and execution instances; their type bool is both a transformation type and an execution type.

7.1.2. char, char0, and char1.

The standard prelude binds the plain names char, char0, and char1 like this.

char0

 :− 

?char0

char1

 :− 

?char1

char

 :− 

char1

The names char0 and char1 are bound to hooks that denote the types of characters. The name char is bound to the same type as the name char1. Characters themselves are both transformation instances and execution instances; their types are both transformation types and execution types. Each character type describes a finite range of two’s-complement integer character codes. The size and range of codes for each character type appear in the following table.

  Type  

  Size  

Range

char0

1 byte

−128 to 127

char1

4 byte

 −2147483648 to 2147483647 

Negative codes do not represent characters. Codes from 0 (U+0000) to 127 (U+007F), represent characters from the 7-bit ASCII set. Codes from 0 (U+0000) to 1114111 (U+10FFFF) represent characters from the 21-bit Unicode set. Codes from 1114112 (U+110000) to 2147483647 (U+7FFFFFFF) represent unspecified characters.
      The character type char0 is a cotype of the character type char1 as in rule 34, and a cotype of the integer type int0 as in rule 35. The character type char1 is also a cotype of the integer type int2 as in the same rule.

char0 ⊑ T

 34

char1 ⊑ T

     

char0 ⊑ T

 35

int0 ⊑ T

     

char1 ⊑ T

 35

int2 ⊑ T

The result of coercing a character to an integer is the character’s integer code. After a character is coerced, the resulting character or integer can be coerced again.

7.1.3. int, int0, int1, and int2.

The standard prelude binds the plain names int, int0, int1, and int2 like this.

int0

 :− 

?int0

int1

 :− 

?int1

int2

 :− 

?int2

int

 :− 

int2

The names int0, int1, and int2 are bound to hooks that denote the types of integers. Integers themselves are both transformation instances and execution instances; their types are both transformation types and execution types. Each integer type intk describes the range of two’s-complement integers that can be represented in 2 to the power k bytes, as shown in the following table.

  Type  

  Size  

Range

int0

1 byte

−128 to 127

int1

2 byte

−32768 to 32767

int2

4 byte

−2147483648 to 2147483647

Orson may provide additional integer types that describe 8-byte integers, 16-byte integers, 32-byte integers, etc. If these are provided, then the standard prelude binds the names int3, int4, int5, etc., to them respectively. The standard prelude also binds the name int to an unspecified integer type whose range is at least that of int2. Each integer type is a cotype of the next larger integer type, as in rule 36.

int0 ⊑ T

 36

int1 ⊑ T

     

int1 ⊑ T

 36

int2 ⊑ T

     

int2 ⊑ T

 36  ⋯

int3 ⊑ T

After an integer is coerced, the resulting integer can be coerced again. Unlike most programming languages, Orson does not coerce integers to integers to real numbers.

7.1.4. list.

The standard prelude binds the plain name list like this.

list :− ?list

The name list is bound to a hook that denotes the type of a list. A list itself is an ordered, finite series of zero or more expressions and objects, called its elements. The elements may be of different types, and there may be a limit on the number of elements in a list. Each element’s type is stored invisibly along with it in the list, so an element obtained from a list has the type that was stored with it. Lists are pure transformation instances; their type list is a pure transformation type.
      The number of elements in a list is called its length. The empty list has no elements, so its length is 0. Each element of a nonempty list is uniquely identified by a nonnegative integer called its index, which is less than the list’s length. In a list of length n, the first element has index 0, the second has index 1, etc. The nth element has index n − 1. An empty list has no elements, and therefore no indexes.
      For historical reasons, the first element of a nonempty list is called its car, and the list of all elements except the first is called its cdr [STE 1990]. Also, a list of length n has n + 1 tails. The zeroth tail is the list itself, the first tail is the cdr of the list, the second is the cdr of the cdr of the list, etc. The nth tail is the empty list. The element at index k of a nonempty list is the car of its kth tail.

7.1.5. null and nil.

The standard prelude binds the plain names nil and null like this.

null :− ?null 
null nil :− ?nil

The name nil is bound to a hook that denotes a pointer. It references no instance, and it is equal only to itself. Any pointer that results from doing arithmetic on nil is unspecified, and dereferencing nil is an error. The pointer nil is both a transformation instance and an execution instance.
      The name null is bound to a hook that denotes the type of nil. The size of null is the same as that of all other pointer types; null is both a transformation type and an execution type. The type null is a subtype of all other pointer types, as in rules 37 and 38.

null ⊆ ref T

 37

true

     

null ⊆ row T

 38

true

The type null is also a subtype of all Skolem types that denote subtypes of ref and row types, as in rules 39 and 40.

null ⊆ ə(K, ref T)

 39

true

     

null ⊆ ə(K, row T)

 40

true

As a result of these rules, nil may be provided in most situations where a pointer is required. It is often used to indicate the end of a linked chain of tuples. However, nil must not appear where a pointer with a base type is required, because its type null has no base type. Also, nil is almost never used as a string, even though null is a subtype of the type string. This is because most methods that operate on strings expect pointers which reference char0’s.

7.1.6. real, real0, and real1.

The standard prelude binds the plain names real, real0, and real1 like this.

real0

 :− 

?real0

real1

 :− 

?real1

real

 :− 

real1

The names real0 and real1 are bound to hooks that denote the types of real numbers. Real numbers themselves are both transformation instances and execution instances; their types are both transformation types and execution types. Each real type describes a finite set of real numbers. The type real0 describes the set provided by the 32-bit IEEE 754 standard, and the type real1 describes the set provided by the 64-bit IEEE 754 standard [IEE 1987]. These have the sizes and ranges of absolute values shown in the following table.

  Type  

  Size  

Absolute Range

 real0 

 4 byte 

1.40239846 × 10−45 to 3.40282347 × 1038

 real1 

 8 byte 

 4.94065645841246544 × 10−324 to 1.79769313486231570 × 10308 

Orson may provide additional real types that describe sets of real numbers with unspecified larger ranges. If these are provided, then the standard prelude binds the names real3, real4, real5, etc., to them respectively. The standard prelude also binds the name real to an unspecified real type whose range is at least that of real1. Each real type is a cotype of the next larger real type, as in rule 41.

real0 ⊑ T

 41

real1 ⊑ T

     

real1 ⊑ T

 41

real2 ⊑ T

     

real2 ⊑ T

 41  ⋯

real3 ⊑ T

After a real number is coerced, the resulting real number can be coerced again. Unlike most programming languages, Orson does not coerce integers to real numbers.

7.1.7. stream and eos.

The standard prelude binds the plain names stream and eos like this.

int eos :− ?eos() 
stream :− ?stream

The name stream is bound to an unspecified type that describes a stream. Although it is shown in this Report as a hook, it may actually be a pointer type, a procedure type, a tuple type, etc. A stream itself is an ordered series of zero or more bytes, possibly of infinite length. Streams are pure execution instances; their type is both a transformation type and an execution type.
      The standard prelude provides no methods that operate on streams, but they may be obtained by loading a library program. Typically, a stream is first opened to associate it with a file. The stream can then be used to read bytes from the file, or to write bytes to the file. Each byte is represented as a nonnegative integer of type int. The stream is finally closed, severing the association made when it was opened.
      The name eos is bound to an unspecified negative integer of type int, shown in this Report as returned by a hook call. If an attempt is made to read a byte from a stream, but no more bytes remain, then eos is read instead. The result of writing eos to a stream is undefined.

7.1.8. string and ϵ.

The standard prelude binds the plain names string and ϵ like this.

string :− row char0 
string ϵ :− ''''

The name string is bound to the type of a string. A string itself is an ordered, finite series of one or more char1’s with nonnegative codes. The last char1 in a string is always the null character, as in the programming language C [KER 1988]. Each string is represented as a row pointer that references an array of one or more char0’s. Unlike all other row pointers, strings are both transformation instances and execution instances; their type string is both a transformation type and an execution type.
      Strings use the UTF-8 encoding for char1’s [UNI 2006]. Within the array referenced by the pointer, each char1 is encoded as a series of one to six char0’s, as shown in the following table. The char1’s are shown in radix 16, and the char0’s are shown in radix 2. The x’s denote the bits of each char1, from most to least significant.

char1

Series of char0’s

 00000000 to 0000007F 

 0xxxxxxx

00000080 to 000007FF

 110xxxxx 10xxxxxx

00000800 to 0000FFFF

 1110xxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx

00010000 to 001FFFFF

 11110xxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx

00200000 to 03FFFFFF

 111110xx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx

04000000 to 7FFFFFFF

 1111110x 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 

Each char1 is encoded as the shortest possible series of char0’s that can represent it. The first char0 of each series has a code greater than or equal to −64. Later char0’s in the series have codes less than −64. A series that encodes an ASCII character has exactly one char0, whose code is greater than or equal to 0. A series that encodes a non-ASCII character has from two to six char0’s, whose codes are less than 0.
      For example, the ASCII character 'R' (U+0052) has the code 1100010. According to the first row of the table, it is represented in a string as one char0. That char0 is obtained by prefixing 0 to the code, giving 01100010, or 82. The Unicode character 'Я' (U+042F) has the code 10000101111. According to the second row of the table, it is represented in a string as two char0’s. The first char0 is obtained by prefixing 110 to the first five bits of the code, giving 11010000, or −48. The second char0 is obtained by prefixing 10 to the last six bits of the code, giving 10101111, or −81.
      Algorithms based on simple pointer arithmetic can compare strings lexicographically, can count the char1’s in a string, and can compute the length of the array that a string references. More complex algorithms are needed to visit the char1’s in a string, since they may be represented by varying numbers of char0’s.
      The name ϵ is bound to an empty string whose length is 0 [HOP 2007]. It contains only the null character, and is lexicographically less than all nonempty strings. The name ϵ should not be confused with the name e, the name ε, or the comparison operator ‘∊’.

7.1.9. void and skip.

The standard prelude binds the plain names skip and void like this.

void :− ?void 
void skip :− ?skip

The name skip is bound to a dummy object, shown in this Report as a hook. The object skip is represented as a single unspecified byte; it is both a transformation instance and an execution instance. The name void is bound to a hook that denotes the type of skip; it is both a transformation type and an execution type. The size of void is 1.
      By convention, expressions that are evaluated only for their side effects have the type void, and return skip. Also, if transforming an expression causes an error, then Orson might recover by making the expression return skip.

7.2. Standard joker types.

The standard prelude binds several plain names to predefined jokers, shown in this Report as hooks. Each name is the first three letters of a word that suggests the objects which the joker describes. For example, the name of the joker that describes all tuples is tup. If this would conflict with another name used by Orson, then the joker’s name ends with the letter ‘ j ’. For example, the name of the joker that describes all integers is inj, to avoid conflict with the name int. Sometimes this convention is used when it is not necessary, to suggest analogies between jokers. For example, the name of the joker that describes all real numbers is rej, by analogy with inj.

7.2.1. alj.

The standard prelude binds the plain name alj like this.

alj :− ?alj

The joker alj describes alternate forms. All alternate form types are subtypes of alj, as in rule 42.

(alts t1, t2 ..., tk) ⊆ alj

 42

true

7.2.2. cha.

The standard prelude binds the plain name cha like this.

cha :− ?cha

The joker cha describes characters. The character types are subtypes of cha, as in rule 43.

char0 ⊆ cha

 43

true

     

char1 ⊆ cha

 43

true

7.2.3. exe.

The standard prelude binds the plain name exe like this.

exe :− ?exe

The joker exe describes execution instances. The mutable types are subtypes of exe, as in rule 44. The variable types are also subtypes of exe, as in rule 45.

t ⊆ exe

 44

t ⊆ mut

    

t ⊆ exe

 45

t ⊆ var mut

7.2.4. foj.

The standard prelude binds the plain name foj like this.

foj :− ?foj

The joker foj describes forms. The alternate form types, the generic form types, and the plain form types are subtypes of foj, as in rules 46, 47, and 48, respectively.

t ⊆ foj

 46

t ⊆ alj

     

t ⊆ foj

 47

t ⊆ gej

     

t ⊆ foj

 48

t ⊆ plj

All form types are also subtypes of (alts) by rule 30. However, (alts) is not a joker.

7.2.5. gej.

The standard prelude binds the plain name gej like this.

gej :− ?gej

The joker gej describes generic forms. All generic form types are subtypes of gej, as in rule 49.

gen (g1 n1, g2 n2 ..., gk nk) f ⊆ gej

 49

true

7.2.6. inj.

The standard prelude binds the plain name inj like this.

inj :− ?inj

The joker inj describes integers. All integer types are subtypes of inj, as in rule 50.

int0 ⊆ inj

 50

true

     

int1 ⊆ inj

 50

true

     

int2 ⊆ inj

 50  ⋯

true

7.2.7. met.

The standard prelude binds the plain name met like this.

met :− ?met

The joker met describes all methods: alternate forms, generic forms, plain forms, and procedures. The form types and procedure types are subtypes of met, as in rules 51 and 52.

t ⊆ met

 51

t ⊆ foj

     

t ⊆ met

 52

t ⊆ pro

Some hooks can be called as if they are methods. However, they are not methods, or even objects, so they are not described by met.

7.2.8. mut.

The standard prelude binds the plain name mut like this.

mut :− ?mut

The joker mut describes the execution instances that can be the values of variables. The procedure types, the scalar types, the structured types, and the void type are subtypes of mut, as in rules 53, 54, 55, and 56, respectively.

t ⊆ mut

 53

t ⊆ pro

     

t ⊆ mut

 54

t ⊆ sca

     

t ⊆ mut

 55

t ⊆ str

     

void ⊆ mut

 56

true

It is possible to create a void variable, but this is probably not useful. The name mut is meant to suggest mutable, meaning something that can be changed.

7.2.9. nom.

The standard prelude binds the plain name nom like this.

nom :− ?nom

The joker nom describes symbol types whose names are not missing. All such symbol types are subtypes of nom, as in rule 57. The joker nom is also a subtype of $⬚, as in rule 58.

t ⊆ nom

  57

t ⊆ $⬚, $⬚ ⊈ t

     

nom ⊆ $⬚

  58

true

The name nom is meant to suggest nōmen, the Latin word for name.

7.2.10. num.

The standard prelude binds the plain name num like this.

num :− ?num

The joker num describes numeric objects. The integer types and real types are subtypes of num, as in rules 59 and 60, respectively.

t ⊆ num

 59

t ⊆ inj

     

t ⊆ num

 60

t ⊆ rej

7.2.11. obj.

The standard prelude binds the plain name obj like this.

obj :− ?obj

The joker obj describes all objects. Any type is a subtype of obj, as in rule 61.

t ⊆ obj

 61

true

7.2.12. plj.

The standard prelude binds the plain name plj like this.

plj :− ?plj

The joker plj describes plain forms. All plain form types are subtypes of plj, as in rule 62.

form (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y ⊆ plj

 62

true

7.2.13. pro.

The standard prelude binds the plain name pro like this.

pro :− ?pro

The joker pro describes procedures. All procedure types are subtypes of pro, as in rule 63.

proc (t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) y ⊆ pro

 63

true

7.2.14. rej.

The standard prelude binds the plain name rej like this.

rej :− ?rej

The joker rej describes real numbers. All real types are subtypes of rej, as in rule 64.

real0 ⊆ rej

 64

true

     

real1 ⊆ rej

 64

true

     

real2 ⊆ rej

 64  ⋯

true

7.2.15. sca.

The standard prelude binds the plain name sca like this.

sca :− ?sca

The joker sca describes scalars. An execution instance is a scalar if the size of its type is a small nonnegative integer, and if it may be compared by ordering relations. The character types, the numeric types, the ref pointer types, and the row pointer types are subtypes of sca, as in rules 65, 66, 67, and 68, respectively.

t ⊆ sca

 65

t ⊆ cha

     

t ⊆ sca

 66

t ⊆ num

     

t ⊆ sca

 67

t ⊆ ref exe

     

t ⊆ sca

 68

t ⊆ row exe

7.2.16. str.

The standard prelude binds the plain name str like this.

str :− ?str

The joker str describes structures: all arrays and all tuples. The array types and the tuple types are subtypes of str, as in rules 69 and 70, respectively.

t ⊆ str

 69

t ⊆ [] exe

     

t ⊆ str

 70

t ⊆ tup

7.2.17. tup.

The standard prelude binds the plain name tup like this.

tup :− ?tup

The joker type tup describes tuples. The tuple types and the slot jokers are subtypes of tup, as in rules 71 and 72, respectively.

(tuple t1 n1, t2 n2 ..., tk nk) ⊆ tup

 71

true

     

 t ⊆ tup 

 72

t ⊆ slot(exe, $⬚)

7.3. Standard forms.

The standard prelude binds various names to commonly used forms. Many are the quoted names of operators. In this Report, the bodies of most such forms are shown as hook calls. If the body of a form is an expression other than a hook call, then the expression is intended to show how the form should behave, but not necessarily how it should be implemented for best efficiency.

Arithmetic conventions. Unless otherwise specified, all forms defined by the standard prelude obey the following conventions about character, integer, and real arithmetic. These conventions need not hold for forms in general.
      Suppose that the arguments in a form call all have character types, all have integer types, or all have real types. Then the arguments are coerced to the largest of those types. For example, in the sum l + r, if l has the type int0 and r has the type int1, then l is coerced to int1.
      Suppose that a form call performs an arithmetic operation, and that all its arguments have the same integer type or real type (possibly because of coercion). Also suppose that the call transforms to an expression that may be executed later. Then the expression has the same type as its arguments.
      If an integer operation overflows or underflows during transformation or execution, then the result is computed according to the rules for two’s-complement arithmetic. For example, suppose that v is a variable whose base type is int2, and whose value is −2147483648. Then the term − v evaluates to −2147483648.
      If a real operation overflows or underflows during transformation, then the result is an unspecified real number. If a real operation overflows or underflows during execution, then the result is undefined.

Object conventions. Unless otherwise specified, forms defined by the standard prelude obey the following conventions about expressions that transform to objects. These conventions also need not hold for forms in general.
      Suppose that all the arguments of a form call transform to characters, forms, integers, lists, real numbers, strings, types, or to a mixture of these. Then the call also transforms to an object, not an expression. A form call may also transform to an object even though all its arguments do not. For example, if one of the arguments in the product l × r transforms to 0, but the other does not, then l × r may transform to 0.
      Suppose that a form call transforms to a character, an integer, or a real number. Then the resulting object has the same type as if it had appeared as a literal. For example, the integer literals 1000000 and 999999 both have the type int2, but their difference 1000000 − 999999 transforms to 1, which has the type int0.

Name conventions. Some forms defined by the standard prelude have two names. For example, the form that multiplies integers or real numbers has the quoted names "⁎" and "×". This allows writing the product l ⁎ r using the ASCII character set, and the product l × r using the larger Unicode character set. However, there is no explicit connection between the two names, so that rebinding "⁎" does not affect "×", or vice versa.
      Some forms have related names. For example, the form that adds integers or real numbers has the quoted name "+", and the form that increments an integer or real variable has the quoted name "+=". There is no explicit connection between these names either, so that rebinding "+" does not affect "+=", or vice versa.
      Some forms are said to be defined in terms of the bindings of certain names. For example, the form isChar is said to return a Boolean, either true or false. There is no explicit connection between the form and these names, so that rebinding bool, true or false does not affect isChar.

7.3.1. "␣[]".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "␣[]" like this.

"␣[]" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type mut lBase) 
"((gform (var [] lBase l, inj r) var lBase: 
"((gf?varArrElem(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((gform ([] lBase l, inj r) lBase: 
"((gf?arrElem(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((gform (row lBase l, inj r) lBase: 
"((gf?rowElem(l, r)), 
"((form (list l, inj r) obj: 
"(((if isInt(r) 
"(((then (if 0 ≤ r < length(l) 
"(((then (ithen (with 
"(((then (ithen (windexing :− 
"(((then (ithen (wi(form (list l, inj r) obj: 
"(((then (ithen (wi((if r > 0 
"(((then (ithen (wi((then indexing(cdr(l), r − 1) 
"(((then (ithen (wi((else car(l))) 
"(((then (ithen (do indexing(l, r)) 
"(((then (ielse error($r, "out of range")) 
"(((telse error($r, "constant expected"))) 
"((form (list l, inj b, inj e) list: 
"(((if isInt(b) ∧ isInt(e) 
"(((then (if b ≥ 0 ∧ e ≥ 0 ∧ b ≤ e ≤ length(l) 
"(((then (then (with 
"(((then (then (wtailing :− 
"(((then (then (wt(form (list l, inj r) list: 
"(((then (then (wt((if r > 0 
"(((then (then (wt((then tailing(cdr(l), r − 1) 
"(((then (then (wt((else copying(l, e − b))) 
"(((then (then (wcopying :− 
"(((then (then (wc(form (list l, inj r) list: 
"(((then (then (wc((if r > 0 
"(((then (then (wc((then cons(car(l), copying(cdr(l), r − 1)) 
"(((then (then (wc((else (:))) 
"(((then (then (do tailing(l, e)) 
"(((then (else error($b, "out of range") 
"(((then (else error($e, "out of range") 
"(((then (else (:)) 
"(((else (if ¬ isInt(b) 
"(((else (then error($b, "constant expected")) 
"(((else (if ¬ isInt(e) 
"(((else (then error($e, "constant expected")) 
"(((else (:))))

Suppose that l evaluates to an array variable of type var [k] t, where t is not a variable type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then the unit l[r] evaluates to the element of l at the index r, whose type is var t. In other words, the element is treated as if it is a variable. It is an error if l has no element with index r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an array of type [k] t, where t may or may not be a variable type. Then l[r] evaluates to the element of l at index r, whose type is t. It is an error if l has no element with index r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a row pointer whose base type is t, which references an element of an array at index j. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then l[r] evaluates to the element of the array at index j + r, whose type is t. This lets a row pointer simulate an array whose length is unknown. It is undefined if the array has no element with index j + r. Contrary to convention, if l transforms to a string, and r transforms to an integer, then l[r] does not transform to a character.
      Suppose that l transforms to a list, and that r transforms to an integer. Then l[r] transforms to the element of l at index r, and its type. It is an error if r transforms to an expression, or if l has no element with index r.
      Suppose that l transforms to a list, and that both b and e transform to integers. Then l[b, e] transforms to a list of length e − b that starts with the element at index b of l, and ends with the element at index e − 1 of l. It is an error if b or e transform to expressions, if b or e are negative, if b is greater than e, or if e is greater than the length of l [STE 1990].

7.3.2. "␣{}".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "␣{}" like this.

"␣{}" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, type cha rType) cha: 
"((f?charCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (cha l, type inj rType) inj: 
"((f?charCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (inj l, type cha rType) cha: 
"((f?intCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (inj l, type num rType) num: 
"((f?intCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (row exe l, type ref exe rType) ref exe: 
"((f?rowCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (row exe l, type row exe rType) row exe: 
"((f?rowCast(l, rType)), 
"((form (rej l, type num rType) num: 
"((f?realCast(l, rType)))

The alternate form "␣{}" implements casts. Suppose that r transforms to a type. Then the unit l{r} evaluates to an instance that is like l, but of the type r. The unit l is said to be cast to the type r. It is an error if r is a joker, or has jokers as parts. Casts are similar to coercions, but casts are performed explicitly by a program, and coercions are performed implicitly by Orson. New casts can be defined by rebinding "␣{}", but new coercions cannot be defined.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a character, and that r transforms to a character type. Then l{r} evaluates to l, represented as a character of type r. If this is not possible, then l{r} evaluates to an unspecified character of type r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a character, and that r transforms to an integer type. Then l{r} evaluates to the code for l, represented as an integer of type r. If this is not possible, then l{r} evaluates to an unspecified integer of type r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an integer, and that r transforms to a character type. Then l{r} evaluates to the character with the code l, of type r. If this is not possible, then l{r} evaluates to an unspecified character of type r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an integer, and that r transforms to an integer type. Then l{r} evaluates to l, represented as an integer of type r. If this is not possible, then l{r} evaluates to an unspecified integer of type r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a real number, and that r transforms to an integer type. Then l{r} evaluates to the integer of type r that results from discarding l’s fractional part. If this is not possible, then l{r} evaluates to an unspecified integer of type r.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an integer or a real number, and that r transforms to a real type. Then l{r} evaluates to the result of converting l to a real number of type r. If l can be exactly represented as a real number of type r, then it is converted to that real number. If l cannot be exactly represented as a real number of type r, but is in the range of real numbers that can be represented in this way, then it is converted to the largest real number of type r which is less than l, or to the smallest which is greater than l. If l is outside the range of real numbers that can be represented by the type r, then it is converted to an unspecified real number of type r [KER 1988].
      Suppose that l evaluates to a ref or row pointer, and that r transforms to a ref or row pointer type. Then l{r} evaluates to l, represented as a pointer of type r. However, it is an error if r transforms to null.

7.3.3. "&".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "&" like this.

"&" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (char l, string r) string: 
"((f?strPre(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intAnd(l, r)), 
"((form (foj l, foj r) foj: 
"((f?formConc(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, char r) string: 
"((f?strPost(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) string: 
"((f?strConc(l, r)), 
"((form (type foj l, type foj r) type foj: 
"((f?typeAlts(l, r)), 
"((form (type tup l, type tup r) type tup: 
"((f?typeConc(l, r)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Then the product l & r evaluates to the integer bitwise AND of l and r.
      Suppose that l and r both transform to forms. Then l & r transforms to a new alternate form (alt l, r). If any member forms in the new alternate form are subsumed, then they are deleted without reporting errors.
      Suppose that l and r both transform to form types. Then l & r transforms to a new alternate form type (alts l, r). If any member types in the new alternate form type are subsumed, then they are deleted without reporting errors. It is an error if l or r is a joker type or a Skolem type. However, l and r can have joker types and Skolem types as parts.
      Suppose that l transforms to a character, and that r transforms to a string. Then l & r transforms to a string in which l is concatenated to the left end of r. It is an error if l or r transform to expressions.
      Suppose that l transforms to a string, and that r transforms to a character. Then l & r transforms to a string in which r is concatenated to the right end of l. It is an error if l or r transform to expressions.
      Suppose that l and r both transform to strings. Then l & r transforms to a string in which r is concatenated to the right end of l. It is an error if l or r transform to expressions.
      Suppose that l and r both transform to tuple types. Then l & r transforms to a tuple type that contains the slots of l, followed by the slots of r. It is an error if the slot names in l and r are not all distinct from each other. It is also an error if l or r is a joker type or a Skolem type. However, l and r can have joker types and Skolem types as parts.

7.3.4. "&=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "&=" like this.

"&=" :− 
"(gen (type inj lBase) 
"(ggen (type lBase rType) 
"(ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"(ggf?intAndSet(l, r))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignment l &= r changes the value of l to the integer bitwise AND of l and r. It evaluates to skip.

7.3.5. "⁎" and "×".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "⁎" and "×" like this.

"⁎" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intMul(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
"((f?realMul(l, r))) 
"
"×" :− "⁎"

If l and r both evaluate to integers, then the products l ⁎ r and l × r evaluate to the integer that results from multiplying l and r. If l and r both evaluate to real numbers, then l ⁎ r and l × r evaluate to the real number that results from multiplying l and r.

7.3.6. "⁎=" and "×=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "⁎=" and "×=" like this.

"⁎=" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type inj lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?intMulSet(l, r)), 
"((gen (type rej lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?realMulSet(l, r))) 
"
"×=" :− "⁎="

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignments l ⁎= r and l ×= r change the value of l to the integer that results from multiplying l and r. They both evaluate to skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is a real type. Also suppose that r evaluates to a real number of type t. Then l ⁎= r and l ×= r change the value of l to the real number that results from multiplying l and r. They both evaluate to skip.

7.3.7. "+".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "+" like this.

"+" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type num rType) 
"((gform (rType r) rType: 
"((gfr), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intAdd(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
"((f?realAdd(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((gform (row lBase l, inj r) row lBase: 
"((gf?rowAdd(l, r)))

If r has an integer or real type, then the term + r transforms to r. If l and r both evaluate to integers, then the sum l + r evaluates to the integer that results from adding l and r. If l and r both evaluate to real numbers, then l + r evaluates to the real number that results from adding l and r.

Pointer arithmetic. Suppose that l evaluates to a row pointer whose base type is t. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then l + r performs pointer arithmetic. First l is converted to a nonnegative integer, then r times the size of t is added to it. The result is converted back to a pointer of type row t and returned.
      For example, suppose there is an array whose base type is t. Also suppose that l is a row pointer whose base type is t, and that it references an element of the array at index k. Then l + r evaluates to a pointer of type row t that references an element of the array at index k + r. If the element does not exist, then l + r evaluates to an unspecified pointer of type row t. Contrary to convention, if l transforms to a string and r transforms to an integer, then l + r does not transform to a string.

7.3.8. "+=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "+=" like this.

"+=" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type inj lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?intAddSet(l, r)), 
"((gen (type rej lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?realAddSet(l, r)), 
"((form (var row exe l, inj r) void: 
"((f?rowAddSet(l, r)))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignment l += r changes the value of l to the integer that results from adding l and r. It evaluates to skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is a real type. Also suppose that r evaluates to a real number of type t. Then l += r changes the value of l to the real number that results from adding l and r. It evaluates to skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable whose base type is a row pointer, and that r evaluates to an integer. Then l += r changes the value of l to the row pointer that results from adding l and r by pointer arithmetic. It evaluates to skip.

7.3.9. "-" and "−".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "-" and "−" like this.

"-" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (inj r) inj: 
"((f?intNeg(r)), 
"((form (rej r) rej: 
"((f?realNeg(r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intSub(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
"((f?realSub(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((gform (row lBase l, inj r) row lBase: 
"((gf?rowSub(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rBase) 
"((ggform (row lBase l, row rBase r) inj: 
"((ggf?rowDist(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe rBase) 
"((ggen (type rBase lBase) 
"((ggform (row lBase l, row rBase r) inj: 
"((ggf?rowDist(l, r))) 
"
"−" :− "-"

If r evaluates to an integer or to a real number, then the terms - r and − r evaluate to r with the opposite of its original sign. If l and r both evaluate to integers, then the sums l - r and l − r evaluate to the integer that results when r is subtracted from l. If l and r both evaluate to real numbers, then l - r and l − r evaluate to the real number that results when r is subtracted from l.

Pointer arithmetic. Suppose that l evaluates to a row pointer whose base type is t. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then l - r and l − r perform pointer arithmetic. First l is converted to a nonnegative integer, then r times the size of t is subtracted from it. The result is converted back to a pointer of type row t and returned.
      For example, suppose there is an array whose base type is t. Also suppose that l is a row pointer whose base type is t, and that it references an element of the array at index k. Then l - r and l − r evaluate to a pointer of type row t that references an element of the array at index k − r. If the element does not exist, then they evaluate to an unspecified pointer of type row t. Contrary to convention, if l transforms to a string and r transforms to an integer, then l - r and l − r do not transform to strings.

Pointer distance. Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers. Also suppose that l’s base type is a subtype of r’s base type, or vice versa, so both base types have the same size.
