Then l - r and l − r evaluate to the integer distance between l and r. This is the number of execution instances, of either base type, that separate l and r in memory. First l and r are converted to nonnegative integers, then their difference is divided by the size of either base type, and the resulting integer (which may be negative) is returned. It is an error if the size of either base type is 0.
      For example, suppose there is an array whose base type is t, and that l and r are pointers whose base type is t. Also suppose that l references an element of the array at index j, and that r references an element at index k. Then l - r and l − r evaluate to j − k. Contrary to convention, if l and r transform to strings, then l - r and l − r do not transform to integers.

7.3.10. "-=" and "−=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "-=" and "−=" like this.

"-=" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type inj lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?intSubSet(l, r)), 
"((gen (type rej lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?realSubSet(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lBase) 
"((gform (var row lBase l, inj r) void: 
"((gf?rowSubSet(l, r))) 
"
"−=" :− "-="

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignments l -= r and l −= r change the value of l to the integer that results when r is subtracted from l. They both evaluate to skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is a real type. Also suppose that r evaluates to a real number of type t. Then the assignments l -= r and l −= r change the value of l to the real number that results from r is subtracted from l. They both evaluate to skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable whose base type is a row pointer type, and that r evaluates to an integer. Then l -= r and l −= r change the value of l to the row pointer that results when r is subtracted from l by pointer arithmetic. They both evaluate to skip.

7.3.11. ".".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "." like this.

"." :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type mut lType, type nom rSym) 
"((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
"((ggform (var slot(lType, lSym) l, type rSym r) var lType: 
"((ggf?varTupSlot(l, r)), 
"((gen (type exe lType, type nom rSym) 
"((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
"((ggform (slot(lType, lSym) l, type rSym r) lType: 
"((ggf?tupSlot(l, r)), 
"((gen (type mut lType, type nom rSym) 
"((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
"((ggform (type var slot(lType, lSym), type rSym) type var lType: 
"((ggfvar lType), 
"((gen (type mut lType, type nom rSym) 
"((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
"((ggform (type var slot(var lType, lSym), type rSym) type var lType: 
"((ggfvar lType), 
"((gen (type exe lType, type nom rSym) 
"((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
"((ggform (type slot(lType, lSym), type rSym) type lType: 
"((ggflType))

The alternate form "." retrieves slots in tuples and tuple types. It uses a symbol type $r to denote the name r of the slot to be retrieved. If l is a unit and r is a name, then the unit l . r abbreviates the call "."(l, $r). The name r must not be missing.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable whose base type is a tuple type with a slot t r, or with a slot var t r, where t is not a variable type. Then l . r evaluates to the instance in the slot of l whose name is r and whose type is var t. In other words, the retrieved instance is treated as a variable.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a tuple with a slot t r, where t may or may not be a variable type. Then l . r evaluates to the instance in the slot of l whose name is r and whose type is t.
      Suppose that l transforms to a variable type whose base type is a tuple type with a slot t r, or with a slot var t r, where t is not a variable type. Then l . r transforms to the type var t. In other words, the retrieved type is treated as a variable type.
      Suppose that l transforms to a tuple type with a slot t r, where t may or may not be a variable type. Then l . r transforms to the type t.

Virtual slots. The name "." may be rebound to make it appear that an object has a slot, even though it does not. Such a slot is called a virtual slot. For example, this equate adds a new member form to ".", making it appear that integers have a virtual slot called sign.

"." :− 
"(form (inj l, type $sign) bool: 
"(fl < 0)

Suppose that l evaluates to an integer. Then l.sign evaluates to true if l is negative, and it evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.12. "/".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "/" like this.

"/" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intDiv(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
"((f?realDiv(l, r)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Then the product l / r evaluates to the integer that is the result of dividing l by r. It is an error if r evaluates to 0.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to real numbers. Then l / r evaluates to the real number that is the result of dividing l by r. If r evaluates to 0.0, then l / r evaluates to an unspecified real number.

7.3.13. "/=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "/=" like this.

"/=" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type inj lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?intDivSet(l, r)), 
"((gen (type rej lBase) 
"((ggen (type lBase rType) 
"((ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"((ggf?realDivSet(l, r)))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignment l /= r changes the value of l to the integer that is the result of dividing l by r. It returns skip.
      Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is a real type. Also suppose that r evaluates to a real number of type t. Then the l /= r changes the value of l to the real number that is the result of dividing l by r. It returns skip.

7.3.14. ":=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name ":=" like this.

":=" :− 
"(gen (type mut lBase) 
"(ggen (type lBase rType) 
"(ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"(ggf?varSet(l, r))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t. Also suppose that r evaluates to an execution instance whose type is a subtype of t. Then the assignment l := r changes the value of l to r. It returns skip.

7.3.15. "<".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "<" like this.

"<" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charLt(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intLt(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realLt(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowLt(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowLt(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) < 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowLt(l, r)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparison l < r evaluates to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than r’s code. It evaluates to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l < r evaluates to true if l is less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l < r evaluates to true if l is lexicographically less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l < r evaluates to true if l is less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.16. "<␣<".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "<␣<" like this.

"<␣<" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charLt(l, m) ∧ ?charLt(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intLt(l, m) ∧ ?intLt(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realLt(l, m) ∧ ?realLt(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) < 0 ∧ comp(m, r) < 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))))

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparison l < m < r evaluates to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than m’s code, and m’s code is less than r’s code. It evaluates to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l < m < r evaluates to true if l is less than m, and m is less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l < m < r evaluates to true if l is lexicographically less than m, and m is lexicographically less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l < m < r evaluates to true if l is less than m, and m is less than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.17. "<␣<=" and "<␣≤".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<␣<=" and "<␣≤" like this.

"<␣<=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charLt(l, m) ∧ ?charLe(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intLt(l, m) ∧ ?intLe(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realLt(l, m) ∧ ?realLe(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) < 0 ∧ comp(m, r) ≤ 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLt(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r)))) 
"
"<␣≤" :− "<␣<="

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l < m <= r and l < m ≤ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than m’s code, and m’s code is less than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l < m <= r and l < m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than m, and m is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l < m <= r and l < m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically less than m, and m is lexicographically less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l < m <= r and l < m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than m, and m is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.18. "<<" and "←".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<<" and "←" like this.

"<<" :− 
"(gen (type inj lType) 
"(gform (lType l, inj r) lType: 
"(gf?intLsh(l, r)) 
"
"←" :− "<<"

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Contrary to convention, they are not coerced to the same type. If r is greater than or equal to 0, then l << r and l ← r evaluate to the integer that results from shifting l by r bits to the left, filling in 0-bits on the right. If r is less than 0, then l << r and l ← r evaluate to an unspecified integer. In either case, l << r and l ← r evaluate to an integer with the same type as l.

7.3.19. "<<=" and "←=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<<=" and "←=" like this.

"<<=" :− 
"(form (var inj l, inj r) void: 
"(f?intLshSet(l, r)) 
"
"←=" :− "<<="

Suppose that l evaluates to an integer variable, and that r evaluates to an integer. Then the assignments l <<= r and l ←= r change the value of l to the integer that results from shifting l by r bits to the left. They both evaluate to skip.

7.3.20. "<=" and "≤".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<=" and "≤" like this.

"<=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charLe(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intLe(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realLe(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowLe(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowLe(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) ≤ 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowLe(l, r))) 
"
"≤" :− "<="

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l <= r and l ≤ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l <= r and l ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l <= r and l ≤ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l <= r and l ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.21. "<=␣<" and "≤␣<".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<=␣<" and "≤␣<" like this.

"<=␣<" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charLe(l, m) ∧ ?charLt(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intLe(l, m) ∧ ?intLt(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realLe(l, m) ∧ ?realLt(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) ≤ 0 ∧ comp(m, r) < 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLt(m, r)))) 
"
"≤␣<" :− "<=␣<"

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l <= m < r and l ≤ m < r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than or equal to m’s code, and m’s code is less than r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l <= m < r and l ≤ m < r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to m, and m is less than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l <= m < r and l ≤ m < r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically less than or equal to m, and m is lexicographically less than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l <= m < r and l ≤ m < r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to m, and m is less than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.22. "<=␣<=" and "≤␣≤".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<=␣<=" and "≤␣≤" like this.

"<=␣<=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charLe(l, m) ∧ ?charLe(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intLe(l, m) ∧ ?intLe(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realLe(l, m) ∧ ?realLe(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) ≤ 0 ∧ comp(m, r) ≤ 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowLe(l, m) ∧ ?rowLe(m, r)))) 
"
"≤␣≤" :− "<=␣<="

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l <= m <= r and l ≤ m ≤ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is less than or equal to m’s code, and m’s code is less than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l <= m <= r and l ≤ m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to m, and m is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l <= m <= r and l ≤ m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically less than or equal to m, and m is lexicographically less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l <= m <= r and l ≤ m ≤ r evaluate to true if l is less than or equal to m, and m is less than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.23. "<>" and "≠".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "<>" and "≠" like this.

"<>" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charNe(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intNe(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realNe(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowNe(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowNe(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) ≠ 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowNe(l, r))) 
"
"≠" :− "<>"

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l <> r and l ≠ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is not equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l <> r and l ≠ r evaluate to true if l is not equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l <> r and l ≠ r evaluate to true if l is not lexicographically equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l <> r and l ≠ r evaluate to true if l is not equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.24. "=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "=" like this.

"=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charEq(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intEq(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realEq(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowEq(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowEq(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) = 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowEq(l, r)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparison l = r evaluates to the Boolean true if l’s code is equal to r’s code. It evaluates to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l = r evaluates to true if l is equal to r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l = r evaluates to true if l is lexicographically equal to r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l = r evaluates to true if l is equal to r. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.25. ">".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name ">" like this.

">" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charGt(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intGt(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realGt(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowGt(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowGt(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) > 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowGt(l, r)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparison l > r evaluates to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than r’s code. It evaluates to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l > r evaluates to true if l is greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l > r evaluates to true if l is lexicographically greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l > r evaluates to true if l is greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.26. ">␣>".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name ">␣>" like this.

">␣>" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charGt(l, m) ∧ ?charGt(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intGt(l, m) ∧ ?intGt(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realGt(l, m) ∧ ?realGt(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) > 0 ∧ comp(m, r) > 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))))

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparison l > m > r evaluates to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than m’s code, and m’s code is greater than r’s code. It evaluates to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l > m > r evaluates to true if l is greater than m, and m is greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l > m > r evaluates to true if l is lexicographically greater than m, and m is lexicographically greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l > m > r evaluates to true if l is greater than m, and m is greater than r. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.27. ">␣>=" and ">␣≥".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">␣>=" and ">␣≥" like this.

">␣>=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charGt(l, m) ∧ ?charGe(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intGt(l, m) ∧ ?intGe(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realGt(l, m) ∧ ?realGe(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) > 0 ∧ comp(m, r) ≥ 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGt(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r)))) 
"
">␣≥" :− ">␣>="

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l > m >= r and l > m ≥ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than m’s code, and m’s code is greater than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l > m >= r and l > m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than m, and m is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l > m >= r and l > m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically greater than m, and m is lexicographically greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l > m >= r and l > m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than m, and m is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.28. ">>" and "→".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">>" and "→" like this.

">>" :− 
"(gen (type inj lType) 
"(gform (lType l, inj r) lType: 
"(gf?intLsh(l, r)) 
"
"→" :− ">>"

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Contrary to convention, they are not coerced to the same type. If r is greater than or equal to 0, then l >> r and l → r evaluate to the integer that results from shifting l by r bits to the right, filling in copies of the leftmost bit on the left. If r is less than 0, then l >> r and l → r evaluate to an unspecified integer. In either case, l >> r and l → r evaluate to an integer with the same type as l.

7.3.29. ">>=" and "→=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">>=" and "→=" like this.

">>=" :− 
"(form (var inj l, inj r) void: 
"(f?intRshSet(l, r)) 
"
"→=" :− ">>="

Suppose that l evaluates to an integer variable. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then the assignments l >>= r and l →= r change the value of l to the integer that results from shifting l by r bits to the right. They both evaluate to skip.

7.3.30. ">=" and "≥".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">=" and "≥" like this.

">=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha r) bool: 
"((f?charGe(l, r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) bool: 
"((f?intGe(l, r)), 
"((form (rej l, rej r) bool: 
"((f?realGe(l, r)), 
"((form (null l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowGe(l, r)), 
"((form (row exe l, null r) bool: 
"((f?rowGe(l, r)), 
"((form (string l, string r) bool: 
"((fcomp(l, r) ≥ 0), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe r) bool: 
"((f?rowGe(l, r))) 
"
"≥" :− ">="

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l >= r and l ≥ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then l >= r and l ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings, neither of which have the type null. Then l >= r and l ≥ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l and r both evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not both strings. Then l >= r and l ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.31. ">=␣>" and "≥␣>".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">=␣>" and "≥␣>" like this.

">=␣>" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charGe(l, m) ∧ ?charGt(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intGe(l, m) ∧ ?intGt(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realGe(l, m) ∧ ?realGt(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) ≥ 0 ∧ comp(m, r) > 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGt(m, r)))) 
"
"≥␣>" :− ">=␣>"

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l >= m > r and l ≥ m > r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than or equal to m’s code, and m’s code is greater than r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l >= m > r and l ≥ m > r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to m, and m is greater than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l >= m > r and l ≥ m > r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically greater than or equal to m, and m is lexicographically greater than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l >= m > r and l ≥ m > r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to m, and m is greater than r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.32. ">=␣>=" and "≥␣≥".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names ">=␣>=" and "≥␣≥" like this.

">=␣>=" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (cha l, cha m, cha r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?charGe(l, m) ∧ ?charGe(m, r))), 
"((form (inj l, inj m, inj r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?intGe(l, m) ∧ ?intGe(m, r))), 
"((form (rej l, rej m, rej r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?realGe(l, m) ∧ ?realGe(m, r))), 
"((form (null l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, null m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, null r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r))), 
"((form (string l, string m, string r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do comp(l, m) ≥ 0 ∧ comp(m, r) ≥ 0)), 
"((form (row exe l, row exe m, row exe r) bool: 
"(((with m :− (past m) 
"(((do ?rowGe(l, m) ∧ ?rowGe(m, r)))) 
"
"≥␣≥" :− ">=␣>="

Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to characters. Then the comparisons l >= m >= r and l ≥ m ≥ r evaluate to the Boolean true if l’s code is greater than or equal to m’s code, and m’s code is greater than or equal to r’s code. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to integers or all evaluate to real numbers. Then l >= m >= r and l ≥ m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to m, and m is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to strings, none of which have the type null. Then l >= m >= r and l ≥ m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is lexicographically greater than or equal to m, and m is lexicographically greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.
      Suppose that l, m, and r all evaluate to row pointers, possibly of different types, but not all strings. Then l >= m >= r and l ≥ m ≥ r evaluate to true if l is greater than or equal to m, and m is greater than or equal to r. They evaluate to false otherwise.

7.3.33. "@" and "↓".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "@" and "↓" like this.

"@" :− 
"(alt 
"((gen (type mut lType) 
"((gform (var [] lType l) row var lType: 
"((gf?varArrToRow(l)), 
"((gen (type exe lType) 
"((gform ([] lType l) row lType: 
"((gf?arrToRow(l)), 
"((gen (type exe lType) 
"((gform (lType l) row lType: 
"((gf?toRow(l))) 
"
"↓" :− "@"

The units l@ and l↓ are called enreferencers, the opposite of dereferencers. If l evaluates to an execution instance, then both l@ and l↓ evaluate to a row pointer that references l.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an array variable of type var [k] t, where t is not a variable type. Then l@ and l↓ evaluate to a pointer of type row var t that references the element of the array at index 0. In other words, the element is treated as if it is a variable.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an array of type [k] t, where t may or may not be a variable type. Then l@ and l↓ evaluate to a pointer of type row t that references the element of the array at index 0.
      Suppose that l evaluates to an execution instance of type t, but not an array. Then l@ and l↓ evaluate to pointer of type row t that references the instance.

Copied objects. Suppose that l evaluates to an execution instance which is temporarily stored in a register, or in an area of memory reserved for temporary instances. Then l@ and l↓ evaluate to an unspecified pointer that references a copy of l. For example, if a procedure call p() returns an integer, then the unit p()↓ references a copy of that integer.

Named objects. Suppose that a name n is bound by an equate to an array, to an array variable, to a tuple, or to a tuple variable. Then the units n@ and n↓ reference the actual execution instance to which n is bound, not a copy.
      Suppose that the unit e evaluates to an execution instance which is part of n. Also suppose that e is composed only of calls to the addition form "+", the dereferencing form "^" or "↑", the subtraction form "-" or "−", the dot form ".", and the array element form "␣[]". Then the units e@ and e↓ reference the actual part of the instance, not a copy. For example, the unit n[k + 1]↑.s↓ references the actual instance of the slot named s in the tuple that is referenced by the k + 1st element of the array to which n is bound.

Undefined objects. Enreferencers can create pointers that reference undefined execution instances. For example, the with clause (with var int v :− 0 do v↓) creates a variable v, then returns a pointer to it. However, v becomes undefined after the with clause’s scope exits, so that any attempt to dereference the pointer is an error.

7.3.34. "[]␣".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "[]␣" like this.

"[]␣" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (type exe r) type exe: 
"((f?arrays(r)), 
"((form (inj l, type exe r) type exe: 
"((f?array(l, r)))

An array is a pure execution instance that represents an ordered, finite series of zero or more other execution instances, all of the same type. This type is called the array’s base type, and the instances are called the array’s elements. The number of elements in the array is a nonnegative integer called its length. There may be a limit on the array’s length. Array types are both transformation types and execution types.
      Each element of an array is uniquely identified by a nonnegative integer called its index. In an array of length n, the first element has index 0, the second element has index 1, etc. The nth element has index n − 1. An array of length 0 has no elements, and therefore no indexes.
      Suppose that l transforms to a nonnegative integer, and that r transforms to the type of an execution instance. Then the term [l] r transforms to the type of an array whose length is l, and whose base type is r. It is an error if l transforms to an expression.
      Suppose that r transforms to the type of an execution instance. Then [] r transforms to a joker that describes an array of any length, and whose base type is a subtype of r.
      Rule 73 describes how an array type can be a subtype of another array type with the same length, k. Rule 74 describes how an array type can be a subtype of an array joker. Rule 75 describes how an array joker can be a subtype of another array joker.

[k] t ⊆ [k] T

 73

t ⊆ T

     

[k] t ⊆ [] T

 74

t ⊆ T

     

[] t ⊆ [] T

 75

t ⊆ T

In memory, an array’s elements are stored in ascending order of their indexes, without gaps between them. This allows using simple pointer arithmetic to traverse the elements of an array. As a result, if an array type [k] t contains no jokers, then its size is size([k] t) = k size(t).

7.3.35. "^" and "↑".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "^" and "↑" like this.

"^" :− 
"(gen (type exe lType) 
"(gform (row lType l) exe: 
"(gf?rowTo(l)) 
"
"↑" :− "^"

The units l^ and l↑ are called dereferencers, the opposite of enreferencers. Suppose that l evaluates to a ref pointer of type ref t, or to a row pointer of type row t. Then l^ and l↑ evaluate to the execution instance of type t that is referenced by the pointer. It is an error if l evaluates to nil, or transforms to an expression of type null. It is also an error if l evaluates to a pointer that does not reference an instance, or that references an undefined instance. Contrary to convention, if l transforms to a string, then l^ and l↑ do not transform to a character.

7.3.36. "|".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "|" like this.

"|" :− 
"(form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"(f?intOr(l, r))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Then the sum l | r evaluates to the integer bitwise inclusive OR of l and r.

7.3.37. "|=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "|=" like this.

"|=" :− 
"(gen (type inj lBase) 
"(ggen (type lBase rType) 
"(ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"(ggf?intOrSet(l, r))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignment l |= r changes the value of l to the integer bitwise inclusive OR of l and r. It evaluates to skip.

7.3.38. "~".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "~" like this.

"~" :− 
"(alt 
"((form (inj r) inj: 
"((f?intNot(r)), 
"((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"((f?intXor(l, r)))

If r evaluates to an integer, then the term ~ r evaluates to the integer bitwise NOT of r. If l and r both evaluate to integers, then the sum l ~ r evaluates to the integer bitwise exclusive OR of l and r.

7.3.39. "~=".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "~=" like this.

"~=" :− 
"(gen (type inj lBase) 
"(ggen (type lBase rType) 
"(ggform (var lBase l, rType r) void: 
"(ggf?intXorSet(l, r))

Suppose that l evaluates to a variable of type var t, where t is an integer type. Also suppose that r evaluates to an integer of type t. Then the assignment l ~= r changes the value of l to the integer bitwise exclusive OR of l and r. It evaluates to skip.

7.3.40. "catch".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "catch" to a form that is discussed along with catch clauses.

7.3.41. "for".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "for" to a form that is discussed along with for clauses.

7.3.42. "mod".

The standard prelude binds the quoted name "mod" like this.

"mod" :− 
"(form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
"(f?intMod(l, r))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers. Then the product l mod r evaluates to the integer remainder after dividing l by r. If l is greater than or equal to 0, and r is greater than 0, then l mod r is less than r. If l is less than 0, or r is less than 0, then the absolute value of l mod r is less than the absolute value of r [KER 1988]. It is an error if r evaluates to 0.

7.3.43. "not" and "¬".

The standard prelude binds the quoted names "not" and "¬" like this.

"not" :− 
"(form (inj r) bool: 
"(fr = 0) 
"
"¬" :− "not"

Suppose that r evaluates to an integer. If r equals 0, then the terms not r and ¬ r evaluate to the Boolean true. They evaluate to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.44. abs.

The standard prelude binds the plain name abs like this.

abs :− 
a(alt 
a((form (inj r) inj: 
a(((with r :− (past r) 
a(((do (if r < 0 
a(((do (then − r 
a(((do (else r))), 
a((form (rej r) rej: 
a(((with r :− (past r) 
a(((do (if r < 0.0 
a(((do (then − r 
a(((do (else r) + 0.0)))

If r evaluates to an integer, then the call abs(r) evaluates to the absolute value of r. If r evaluates to a real number, then abs(r) evaluates to the absolute value of r.

7.3.45. align.

The standard prelude binds the plain name align like this.

align :− 
a(alt 
a((form (type exe r) inj: 
a((f?typeAlign(r)), 
a((form (exe r) inj: 
a((falign(type r)), 
a((form (obj) inj: 
a((f−1))

Each execution type has an alignment, which is a small positive integer. Suppose that an instance of an execution type t resides in memory. Then the instance’s address is said to be aligned if it is a multiple of t’s alignment [PAT 2005].
      If r transforms to an execution type, then the call align(r) transforms to r’s alignment. Some computers require all addresses to be aligned. On these computers, align(r) transforms to the required alignment of r. Others do not require addresses to be aligned, but can run more efficiently if they are. On these, align(r) transforms to the alignment of r that is suggested for best efficiency. Still others have neither required nor suggested alignments. On these, align(r) transforms to 1.
      If r transforms to a pure transformation type, then align(r) transforms to −1. If r transforms to a Skolem type, then align(r) transforms to the alignment of r’s base type. If r transforms to an expression, then align(r) transforms to the alignment of the expression’s type.

7.3.46. argc and argv.

The standard prelude binds the plain names argc and argv like this.

argc :− 
a(form () int: 
a(f?argc()) 
a
argv :− 
a(form () row string: 
a(f?argv())

In some operating systems, an Orson program is initiated by issuing a command to an interpreter, called a shell [RIT 1974]. The command is a string, with zero or more additional strings as its arguments. The forms argv and argc let a program examine the command and arguments that initiated it. They are suggested by similar mechanisms in the programming language C [KER 1988].
      Suppose that a program runs under an operating system which uses such a shell. Then the call argv() evaluates to a row pointer that references an array whose elements are one or more strings. The element at index 0 of the array is the command, or an empty string if the command is not available. The remaining elements, except the last, are the command’s arguments. The last element is nil. The call argc() evaluates to an integer that is the length of the array minus 1.
      Suppose that a program runs under an operating system which does not use a shell, or under an operating system which does not use string commands, or does not run under an operating system at all. Then argv() evaluates to a row pointer that references an array with one element, nil, and argc() evaluates to 0.

7.3.47. arity.

The standard prelude binds the plain name arity like this.

arity :− 
a(alt 
a((form (type met r) inj: 
a((f?typeArity(r)), 
a((form (met r) inj: 
a((f?typeArity(type r)))

Suppose that r transforms to a generic form type, a plain form type, or a procedure type. Then the call arity(r) transforms to a nonnegative integer that is the number of parameters in that type.
      Suppose that r transforms to an alternate form type. If all its members have the same number of parameters, then arity(r) transforms to a nonnegative integer that is the number of parameters in each member. If it has no members, or if its members have different numbers of parameters, then arity(r) transforms to −1.
      Suppose that r transforms to a joker type that describes methods, such as alj, foj, gej, met, plj, or pro. Then arity(r) also transforms to −1.
      Suppose that r transforms to an alternate form, a generic form, a plain form, or a procedure. Then arity(r) transforms to the number of parameters in the form or procedure’s type.

7.3.48. base.

The standard prelude binds the plain name base like this.

base :− 
b(alt 
b((gen (type exe rBase) 
b((gform (type [] rBase) type rBase: 
b((gfrBase), 
b((form (type plj r) type obj: 
b((f?metBase(r)), 
b((form (type pro r) type mut: 
b((f?metBase(r)), 
b((gen (type exe rBase) 
b((gform (type ref rBase) type rBase: 
b((gfrBase), 
b((gen (type exe rBase) 
b((gform (type row rBase) type rBase: 
b((gfrBase), 
b((gen (type obj rBase) 
b((gform (type type rBase) type rBase: 
b((gfrBase), 
b((gen (type mut rBase) 
b((gform (type var rBase) type rBase: 
b((gfrBase))

Suppose that r transforms to a type which has a base type. Then the call base(r) transforms to r’s base type. If r transforms to an array type [k] t or to an array joker type [] t, then base(r) transforms to t. If r transforms to a plain form type or to a procedure type, then base(r) transforms to r’s yield type. If r transforms to a pointer type ref t, to a pointer type row t, to a type type type t, or to a variable type var t, then base(r) transforms to the type t. It is an error to call base with any other type.

7.3.49. car.

The standard prelude binds the plain name car like this.

car :− 
c(form (list r) obj: 
c(f?listCar(r))

Suppose that r transforms to a nonempty list. Then the call car(r) transforms to r’s first element and its type. It is an error if r transforms to an empty list. The form car is similar to the function of the same name in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

7.3.50. cdr.

The standard prelude binds the plain name cdr like this.

cdr :− 
c(form (list r) list: 
c(f?listCdr(r))

Suppose that r transforms to a nonempty list. Then the call cdr(r) transforms to the list r without its first element. It is an error if r transforms to an empty list. The form cdr is similar to the function of the same name in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

7.3.51. comp.

The standard prelude binds the plain name comp like this.

comp :− 
c(form (string l, string r) inj: 
c((if isString(l) ∧ isString(r) 
c((then ?strComp(l, r) 
c((else (with 
c((else (wvar string l :− (past l) 
c((else (wvar string r :− (past r) 
c((else (do (while l↑ ∧ r↑ ∧ l↑ = r↑ 
c((else (do (do l += 1 
c((else (do (do r += 1) 
c((else (do #FF & l↑ − #FF & r↑)))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to strings. Then the call comp(l, r) compares l and r lexicographically. It evaluates to an unspecified negative integer if l is less than r, it evaluates to zero if l is equal to r, and it evaluates to an unspecified positive integer if l is greater than r. The form comp is similar to the function strcmp in the programming language C [KER 1988].

7.3.52. conc.

The standard prelude binds the plain name conc like this.

conc :− 
c(form (list l, list r) list: 
c((with 
c((wconcing :− 
c((wc(form (list l) list: 
c((wc((if isEmpty(l) 
c((wc((then r 
c((wc((else cons(car(l), concing(cdr(l))))) 
c((do (if isEmpty(r) 
c((do (then l 
c((do (else concing(l))))

Suppose that l and r both transform to lists. Then the call conc(l, r) transforms to a list whose elements are those of l, followed by those of r. The form conc is similar to the function append in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

7.3.53. cons.

The standard prelude binds the plain name cons like this.

cons :− 
c(form (obj l, list r) list: 
c(f?listCons(l, r))

Suppose that l transforms to an expression or object, and that r transforms to a list. Then the call cons(l, r) transforms to a new list whose car is l and whose cdr is r. The form cons is similar to the function of the same name in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].

7.3.54. count.

The standard prelude binds the plain name count like this.

count :− 
c(form (string r) inj: 
c((if isString(r) 
c((then ?strCount(r) 
c((else (with 
c((else (wvar int c :− 0 
c((else (wvar string r :− (past r) 
c((else (do (while r↑ 
c((else (do (do c += (r↑ ≥ −64) 
c((else (do (do r += 1) 
c((else (do c)))

Suppose that r evaluates to a string. Then the call count(r) evaluates to a nonnegative integer that is the number of char1’s encoded in r, ignoring the null character at the end. This is not necessarily the same as the number of char0’s in r, which is obtained by calling length.

7.3.55. devar.

The standard prelude binds the plain name devar like this.

devar :− 
d(alt 
d((form (type mut r) type mut: 
d((fr), 
d((gen (type mut r) 
d((gform (type var r) type mut: 
d((gfr))

If r transforms to a variable type var t, then the call devar(r) transforms to the type t. If r transforms to the type of an execution instance, but not a variable type, then devar(r) transforms to r instead.

7.3.56. enum.

The standard prelude binds the plain name enum like this.

enum :− 
e(alt 
e((form () foj: 
e(((form () inj: 
e(((f?enum(0, high(int), 1))), 
e((form (inj e) foj: 
e(((form () inj: 
e(((f?enum(0, e − 1, 1))), 
e((form (inj b, inj e) foj: 
e(((form () inj: 
e(((f?enum(b, e, 1))), 
e((form (inj b, inj e, inj s) foj: 
e(((form () inj: 
e(((f?enum(b, e, s))))

The higher-order form enum simulates the enumerated types of programming languages like C [KER 1988] and Pascal [JEN 1974]. Suppose that b, e, and s all transform to integers. Then the call enum(b, e, s) transforms to a new form with no parameters. Each call to the new form transforms to the next integer in a series. The first time it is called, it transforms to b. The second time, it transforms to b + s, and the third time, it transforms to b + s + s, etc. For example, the following equates bind the plain names sunday through saturday to 0 through 6, respectively.

makeDay

 :− 

enum(0, 6, 1)

sunday

 :− 

makeDay()

monday

 :− 

makeDay()

tuesday

 :− 

makeDay()

wednesday 

 :− 

makeDay()

thursday

 :− 

makeDay()

friday

 :− 

makeDay()

saturday

 :− 

makeDay()

It is an error if b, e, or s transform to expressions. It is also an error if a call to the new form would transform to an integer that is less than b, or is greater than e.
      The call enum() specifies a series of integers whose lower bound is 0, whose upper bound is the most positive integer that can be represented as an int, and whose increment is 1. The call enum(e) specifies a series whose lower bound is 0, whose upper bound is e − 1, and whose increment is 1. (These are the indexes of an array or list whose length is e.) The call enum(b, e) specifies a series whose lower bound is b, whose upper bound is e, and whose increment is 1. As a result, the call to enum in the example could also have been written as enum(), as enum(7), or as enum(0, 6).

7.3.57. error.

The standard prelude binds the plain name error like this.

error :− 
e(alt 
e((form (list l, inj r) void: 
e((f?listErr(l, r)), 
e((form (type $⬚ l, inj r) void: 
e((f?symErr(l, r)))

The form error reports errors that occur while transforming a program. It can report errors in the arguments of a form that is being called, or in the call itself. Errors are reported in an unspecified way. Reporting an error means that the program is incorrect, and always prevents its later execution. As a result, error cannot report warnings about doubtful parts of a correct program. It also cannot report errors that occur while executing a transformed program.

Error numbers. Errors are represented as unspecified nonnegative integers. The standard prelude binds the following quoted names to such integers, shown in this Report as being returned by hook calls.

"assertion failed"

 :− 

?intErr()

"cannot close"

 :− 

?intErr()

"cannot open"

 :− 

?intErr()

"cannot report error"

 :− 

?intErr()

"constant expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"division by zero"

 :− 

?intErr()

"error number expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"exe expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"expression has unexpected type"

 :− 

?intErr()

"foj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"internal error"

 :− 

?intErr()

"internal limit exceeded"

 :− 

?intErr()

"joker type expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"met expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"method has unexpected type"

 :− 

?intErr()

"mut expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"negative inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non joker type expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non negative inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non nil pointer expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non null pointer type expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non positive inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"non zero inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"no such form parameter name"

 :− 

?intErr()

"out of range"

 :− 

?intErr()

"positive inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"subsumed form"

 :− 

?intErr()

"too few elements"

 :− 

?intErr()

"too many elements"

 :− 

?intErr()

"transformation halted"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type exe expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type has no base type"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type mut expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type obj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type size too large"

 :− 

?intErr()

"type type obj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

"unexpected call"

 :− 

?intErr()

"unexpected element"

 :− 

?intErr()

"unexpected object"

 :− 

?intErr()

"version does not match"

 :− 

?intErr()

"zero inj expression expected"

 :− 

?intErr()

Other than being nonnegative, nothing should be assumed about these integers or their types. Integers that represent errors are not related to integers that represent exceptions. Although an integer that represents an error might be equal to one that represents an exception, this is only a coincidence, and correct Orson programs should not rely on it. The form isError tests if an integer represents an error.

Errors in form arguments. Suppose that a plain or generic form has a parameter name n, but not the missing name ⬚. Also suppose that when the form is called, a scope is established in which n is bound to the result of transforming its corresponding argument a. Then within that scope, the unit $n transforms to a new symbol type that invisibly records a, and can be used to report errors in a. Now suppose that the form detects an error in its argument a, and that e is the integer which represents the error. Then the call error($n, e) reports the error e for a, and returns skip. It is itself an error if e does not represent an error.
      For example, the form sqrt uses Newton’s method [WAR 2003] to compute the square root of a nonnegative real number x with accuracy ε. (An equate that binds ε to a small positive real number is not shown.) If the argument corresponding to x transforms to a real expression, then sqrt reports the error "constant expected" for that argument. If the argument transforms to a negative real number, then sqrt reports the error "out of range" for it instead.

sqrt :− 
s(form (real x) real: 
s((with 
s((wsqrting :− 
s((ws(form (real g, real h) real: 
s((ws((if abs(g − h) < ε 
s((ws((then g 
s((ws((else (with 
s((ws((else (wreal g' :− (g + h) / 2.0 
s((ws((else (wreal h' :− x / g' 
s((ws((else (do sqrting(g', h')))) 
s((do (if isReal(x) 
s((do (then (if x ≥ 0.0 
s((do (then (then sqrting(1.0, x) 
s((do (then (else error($x, "out of range") 
s((do (then (else 0.0) 
s((do (else error($x, "constant expected") 
s((do (else 0.0)))

The call to sqrt recovers from both errors by transforming to 0.0. Whenever possible, forms should recover from errors so that transformation can continue.
      If a symbol type records an argument in a form call, then it still records that argument outside the scope established by the call. This lets a form report errors in the arguments of another form. For example, the form sqrt could call a form like isSqrtable to report errors in its argument x.

sqrt :− 
s(form (real x) 
s((with 
s((wsqrting :− 
s((ws(form (real g, real h) real: 
s((ws((if abs(g − h) < ε 
s((ws((then g 
s((ws((else (with 
s((ws((else (wreal g' :− (g + h) / 2.0 
s((ws((else (wreal h' :− x / g' 
s((ws((else (do sqrting(g', h')))) 
s((do (if isSqrtable($x, x) 
s((do (then sqrting(1.0, x) 
s((do (else 0.0))) 
s
isSqrtable :− 
i(form (type nom g, real y) bool: 
i((if isReal(y) 
i((then (if y ≥ 0.0 
i((then (then true 
i((then (else error(g, "out of range") 
i((then (else false) 
i((else error(g, "constant expected") 
i((else false))

Suppose that a unit $n is transformed to a new symbol type in a scope where n is not a form parameter name. Then the symbol type does not record an argument, so using it to report an error is itself an error. The form isGoat tests if a symbol type can be used to report an error.

Errors in form calls. Now suppose that the unit $⬚, whose name is missing, appears in a scope which is established during a form call. Then $⬚ transforms to a new symbol type that invisibly records that call. This symbol type can be used to report an error in the entire call, even if the call’s arguments have no errors. For example, the form never reports the error "unexpected call" and returns skip. Calling never might indicate part of a program that must not be transformed if the rest of the program is correct.

never :− 
n(form () void: 
n(ferror($⬚, "unexpected call"))

Suppose that the unit $⬚ is transformed to a new symbol type in a scope which is not established by a form call. Then using that symbol type to report an error is itself an error. The form isGoat also tests if such a symbol type can be used to report an error.
      Each appearance of the unit $⬚ or $n transforms to a new symbol type that is different from every other symbol type. It can therefore record an argument that is different from that recorded by any other symbol type. As a result, forms can use symbol types to report errors without interfering with each other.

Errors in list elements. A form also may be given arguments as elements of a list. Suppose that l is a nonempty list, and that e is an integer that represents an error. Then the call error(l, e) reports an error e for the first element of l, and returns skip. Errors can be reported for elements of any nonempty list, even if its elements are not form arguments. It is itself an error if l is an empty list, or if e does not represent an error.
      For example, the form sum is given a list of integers k and returns their sum. Each time it encounters an element of k that is not an integer, it reports the error "unexpected element" for that element. It then recovers from the error by skipping the element, and computing the sum of the other elements.

sum :− 
s(form (list k) inj: 
s((if isEmpty(k) 
s((then 0 
s((else if isInt(car(k)) 
s((else then car(k) + sum(cdr(k)) 
s((else else error(k, "unexpected element") 
s((else else sum(cdr(k))))

The form cdr may be used with error to report errors in any element of a list. For example, error(cdr(l), e) reports that the error e occurs in the second element of l, and error(cdr(cdr(l)), e) reports that it occurs in the third element.

7.3.58. except.

The standard prelude binds the plain name except like this.

except :− enum(1, high(int))

The form except is created by calling the higher-order form enum. Each call to except transforms to the next integer in a series. The first time it is called, it transforms to 1. The next time, it transforms to 2, then 3, etc., ending with the largest integer that can be represented as an int. It is an error to call except after the series has ended.
      The form except should be used to create the integers that are arguments to the form throw. These integers are informally called exceptions. Each exception represents a reason for the unusual termination of a catch clause. Exceptions are not related to the integers that the form error uses to report transformation errors. Although an exception might be equal to an integer that represents an error, this is only a coincidence, and correct Orson programs should not rely on it.

7.3.59. exit.

The standard prelude binds the plain name exit like this.

exit :− 
e(alt 
e((form () void: 
e((fexit(0)), 
e((form (int r) void: 
e((f?exit(r)))

Suppose that r evaluates to an integer. Then the call exit(r) terminates the execution of the entire Orson program. It also sends r to the operating system, which handles it in an unspecified way. If the program does not run under an operating system, then calling exit is undefined. Calling a similar form halt terminates the transformation of the program.
      In the Unix operating system, sending 0 to the operating system indicates that the program terminated normally; a nonzero integer indicates why it terminated abnormally [RIT 1974]. The call exit() is equivalent to exit(0).
      During transformation, exit(r) is treated as if it will evaluate to skip. However, it actually evaluates to no object, because it terminates the execution of the expression in which it appears.

7.3.60. flatten.

The standard prelude binds the plain name flatten like this.

flatten :− 
f(form (list r) list: 
f((with 
f((wflattening :− 
f((wf(alt 
f((wf((form (list r) list: 
f((wf(((if isEmpty(r) 
f((wf(((then (:) 
f((wf(((else conc(flattening(car(r)), flattening(cdr(r))))), 
f((wf((form (obj r) list: 
f((wf(((: r))) 
f((do flattening(r)))

Suppose that r transforms to a list. Then the call flatten(r) transforms to a flattened version of r, obtained by deleting each inner ‘(:’ and its matching ’)’ from among r’s elements. For example, flattening the list (: (: 1, 2), (:), (: (: 3), 4)) results in a new list (: 1, 2, 3, 4).

7.3.61. halt.

The standard prelude binds the plain name halt like this.

halt :− 
h(form () void: 
h(f?halt())

The call halt() terminates the transformation of the entire Orson program, preventing its later execution. It then passes control to the operating system. If the program does not run under an operating system, then calling halt is undefined. Calling a similar form exit terminates the execution of the program.
      A call to halt is treated as if it transforms to skip. However, the call actually transforms to no object, because it always terminates the program in which it appears.

7.3.62. high.

The standard prelude binds the plain name high like this.

high :− 
h(alt 
h((form (type cha r) cha: 
h((f?typeHigh(r)), 
h((form (type num r) num: 
h((f?typeHigh(r)), 
h((form (type type cha r) type cha: 
h((f?typeHigh(r)), 
h((form (type type inj r) type inj: 
h((f?typeHigh(r)), 
h((form (type type rej r) type rej: 
h((f?typeHigh(r)))

Calls to the form high transform to the maximum objects of certain types. Calls to a similar form low transform to the minimum objects.
      If r transforms to a character type, then the call high(r) transforms to the character of type r with the most positive code. If r transforms to the joker type cha, then high(r) transforms to '\#7FFFFFFF', the character of type char1 with the most positive code.
      If r transforms to an integer type, then high(r) transforms to the most positive integer of type r. If r transforms to the joker type inj, then high(r) transforms to the most positive integer of the largest available integer type.
      If r transforms to a real type, then high(r) transforms to the real number of type r with the largest absolute value. If r transforms to the joker type rej, then high(r) transforms to the real number of the largest available real type with the largest absolute value.
      If r transforms to the type type cha, then high(r) transforms to the type char1, the largest character type. If r transforms to the type type inj, then high(r) transforms to the largest available integer type. If r transforms to the type type rej, then high(r) transforms to the largest available real type.

7.3.63. isChar.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isChar like this.

isChar :− 
i(form (obj r) bool: 
i(f?charCon(r))

If r transforms to a character, then the call isChar(r) transforms to the Boolean true. If r transforms to another object, or to an expression, then isChar(r) transforms to the Boolean false.

7.3.64. isCotype and "⊑".

The standard prelude binds the plain name isCotype and the quoted name "⊑" like this.

isCotype :− 
i(form (type obj l, type obj r) bool: 
i(f?typeCotype(l, r)) 
i
"⊑" :− isCotype

Suppose that l and r both transform to types. If l is a cotype of r, then the call isCotype(l, r) and the comparison l ⊑ r transform to the Boolean true. They transform to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.65. isEmpty.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isEmpty like this.

isEmpty :− 
i(alt 
i((form (list r) bool: 
i((f?listEmpty(r)), 
i((form (string r) bool: 
i(((if isString(r) 
i(((then r = ϵ 
i(((else r↑ = '\0')))

Suppose that r transforms to a list. If r is an empty list, then the call isEmpty(r) transforms to the Boolean true. It transforms to the Boolean false otherwise. This is similar to the function null in the programming language Common Lisp [STE 1990] and the function null? in the programming language Scheme [SPE 2007].
      Suppose that r evaluates to a string. If r is lexicographically equal to the empty string ϵ, then isEmpty(r) evaluates to true. It evaluates to false otherwise.

7.3.66. isError.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isError like this.

isError :− 
i(form (inj r) bool: 
i(f?intErr(r))

Suppose that r transforms to an integer. Then the call isError(r) transforms to the Boolean true if r represents a transformation error. It transforms to the Boolean false otherwise. It is an error if r transforms to an expression.

7.3.67. isGoat.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isGoat like this.

isGoat :− 
i(form (type $⬚ r) bool: 
i(f?symGoat(r))

Suppose that r transforms to a symbol type, possibly with the missing name. Then the call isGoat(r) transforms to the Boolean true if r can be used to report errors in a form call, or in an argument to a form call. It transforms to the Boolean false otherwise. The name isGoat comes from the word scapegoat, meaning something that is to be blamed [AHD 1973].

7.3.68. isInt.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isInt like this.

isInt :− 
i(form (obj r) bool: 
i(f?intCon(r))

If r transforms to an integer, then the call isInt(r) transforms to the Boolean true. If r transforms to another object, or to an expression, then isInt(r) transforms to the Boolean false.

7.3.69. isJoked.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isJoked like this.

isJoked :− 
i(form (type obj r) bool: 
i(f?typeJoked(r))

Suppose that r transforms to a type. If r is a joker, or contains one or more jokers as parts, then the call isJoked(r) transforms to the Boolean true. It transforms to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.70. isNull.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isNull like this.

isNull :− 
i(form (obj r) bool: 
i(f?nullCon(r))

If r transforms to the null pointer nil, then the call isNull(r) transforms to the Boolean true. If r transforms to another object, or to an expression, then isNull(r) transforms to the Boolean false.

7.3.71. isReal.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isReal like this.

isReal :− 
i(form (obj r) bool: 
i(f?realCon(r))

If r transforms to a real number, then the call isReal(r) transforms to the Boolean true. If r transforms to another object, or to an expression, then isReal(r) transforms to the Boolean false.

7.3.72. isSkolem.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isSkolem like this.

isSkolem :− 
i(form (type obj r) bool: 
i(f?typeSko(r))

Suppose that r transforms to a type. If r is a Skolem type, then the call isSkolem(r) transforms to the Boolean true. It transforms to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.73. isString.

The standard prelude binds the plain name isString like this.

isString :− 
i(form (obj r) bool: 
i(f?strCon(r))

If r transforms to a string, then the call isString(r) transforms to the Boolean true. If r transforms to another object, or to an expression, then isString(r) transforms to the Boolean false.

7.3.74. isSubsumed and "≼".

The standard prelude binds the plain name isSubsumed and the quoted name "≼" like this.

isSubsumed :− 
i(form (type foj l, type foj r) bool: 
i(f?typeSubsume(l, r)) 
i
"≼" :− isSubsumed

Suppose that l and r both transform to form types. Then the call isSubsumed(l, r) and the comparison l ≼ r transform to the Boolean true if a form of type l is subsumed by a form of type r. They transform to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.75. isSubtype and "⊆".

The standard prelude binds the plain name isSubtype and the quoted name "⊆" like this.

isSubtype :− 
i(form (type obj l, type obj r) bool: 
i(f?typeSubtype(l, r)) 
i
"⊆" :− isSubtype

Suppose that l and r both transform to types. Then the call isSubtype(l, r) and the comparison l ⊆ r transform to the Boolean true if l is a subtype of r. They transform to the Boolean false otherwise.

7.3.76. length.

The standard prelude binds the plain name length like this.

length :− 
l(alt 
l((form (type [] exe r) inj: 
l((f?typeLen(r)), 
l((gen (type [] exe r) 
l((gform (type var r) inj: 
l((gf?typeLen(r)), 
l((form ([] exe r) inj: 
l((flength(type r)), 
l((form (list r) inj: 
l(((if isEmpty(r) 
l(((then 0 
l(((else length(cdr(r)) + 1)), 
l((form (string r) inj: 
l(((if isString(r) 
l(((then ?strLength(r) 
l(((else (with 
l(((else (wvar int l :− 0 
l(((else (wvar string r :− (past r) 
l(((else (do (while r↑ 
l(((else (do (do l += 1 
l(((else (do (do r += 1) 
l(((else (do l))))

Suppose that r transforms to an array type [k] t or to an array variable type var [k] t. Then the call length(r) transforms to the nonnegative integer k, the length of the array described by the type.
      Suppose that r transforms to an expression of an array type. Then length(r) transforms to the length of that type.
      Suppose that r transforms to a list. Then length(r) transforms to a nonnegative integer that is the number of elements in r. This is similar to the function length in the programming languages Common Lisp [STE 1990] and Scheme [SPE 2007].
      Suppose that r evaluates to a string. Then length(r) evaluates to a nonnegative integer that is the number of char0’s in r, ignoring the null character at the end. This is not necessarily the same as the number of char1’s encoded in r, which is obtained by calling count. It is similar to the function strlen in the programming language C [KER 1988].

7.3.77. low.

The standard prelude binds the plain name low like this.

low :− 
l(alt 
l((form (type cha r) cha: 
l((f?typeLow(r)), 
l((form (type num r) num: 
l((f?typeLow(r)), 
l((form (type type cha r) type cha: 
l((f?typeLow(r)), 
l((form (type type inj r) type inj: 
l((f?typeLow(r)), 
l((form (type type rej r) type rej: 
l((f?typeLow(r)))

Calls to the form low transform to the minimum objects of certain types. Calls to a similar form high transform to the maximum objects.
      If r transforms to a character type, or to the joker type cha, then the call low(r) transforms to the null character of type char0. This is the character with the least positive code.
      If r transforms to an integer type, then low(r) transforms to the most negative integer of type r. If r transforms to the joker type inj, then low(r) transforms to the most negative integer of the largest available integer type.
      If r transforms to a real type, then low(r) transforms to the real number of type r with the smallest absolute value. If r transforms to the joker type rej, then low(r) transforms to the real number of the largest available real type with the smallest absolute value.
      If r transforms to the type type cha, then low(r) transforms to char0, the smallest character type. If r transforms to the type type inj, then low(r) transforms to int0, the smallest integer type. If r transforms to the type type rej, then low(r) transforms to real0, the smallest real type.

7.3.78. max.

The standard prelude binds the plain name max like this.

max :− 
m(alt 
m((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
m(((with 
m(((winj l :− (past l) 
m(((winj r :− (past r) 
m(((do (if l > r 
m(((do (then l 
m(((do (else r))), 
m((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
m(((with 
m(((wrej l :− (past l) 
m(((wrej r :− (past r) 
m(((do (if l > r 
m(((do (then l 
m(((do (else r))))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then the call max(l, r) evaluates to either l or r, whichever is greater.

7.3.79. min.

The standard prelude binds the plain name min like this.

min :− 
m(alt 
m((form (inj l, inj r) inj: 
m(((with 
m(((winj l :− (past l) 
m(((winj r :− (past r) 
m(((do (if l < r 
m(((do (then l 
m(((do (else r))), 
m((form (rej l, rej r) rej: 
m(((with 
m(((wrej l :− (past l) 
m(((wrej r :− (past r) 
m(((do (if l < r 
m(((do (then l 
m(((do (else r))))

Suppose that l and r both evaluate to integers or both evaluate to real numbers. Then the call min(l, r) evaluates to either l or r, whichever is lesser.

7.3.80. offset.

The standard prelude binds the plain name offset like this.

offset :− 
o(alt 
o((gen (type nom rSym) 
o((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
o((ggform (type slot(exe, lSym) l, type rSym r) inj: 
o((ggf?typeOffset(l, r)), 
o((gen (type nom rSym) 
o((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
o((ggform (type var slot(exe, lSym) l, type rSym r) inj: 
o((ggfoffset(base(l), r)), 
o((gen (type nom rSym) 
o((ggen (type rSym lSym) 
o((ggform (slot(exe, lSym) l, type rSym r) inj: 
o((ggfoffset(type l, r)))

Suppose that a tuple resides at an address a in memory. Also suppose that the tuple’s type has a slot named n, but not the missing name. Then that slot resides at the address a + ñ, where ñ is a nonnegative integer called the offset of n.
      Suppose that l transforms to a tuple type with a slot named n, but not the missing name. Also suppose that r transforms to a symbol type $n. Then the call offset(l, r) transforms to ñ, the offset of the slot named n in a tuple whose type is l.
      Suppose that l transforms to a variable type whose base type is a tuple type with a slot named n, but not the missing name. Also suppose that r transforms to a symbol type $n. Then offset(l, r) transforms to ñ, the offset of the slot named n in a tuple whose type is the base type.
      Suppose that l transforms to an expression whose type is a tuple type with a slot named n, but not the missing name. Also suppose that r transforms to a symbol type $n. Then offset(l, r) transforms to ñ, the offset of the slot named n in the tuple l.

7.3.81. refs.

The standard prelude binds the plain name refs like this.

refs :− 
r(gen (type tup t) 
r(ggen (type t b) 
r(ggform (type t, type b) foj: 
r(ggf(form (form (row b) obj body) void: 
r(ggf(f?refs(body, t, b)))

Some Orson programs call an allocator form to request tuples from a pool of available memory called the heap. Each call takes a tuple type without jokers as its argument. It obtains a tuple of this type from the heap, then returns a pointer that references the tuple. After the program is finished with the tuple, it calls a deallocator method on the pointer. This call sends the memory used by the tuple back to the heap, so it can be reused by later calls to the allocator form.
      Other Orson programs use a garbage collector [JON 1997] instead of a deallocator method. The garbage collector periodically visits each tuple that was allocated from the heap. If it visits a tuple that is no longer referenced by any pointer (other than the pointers used internally by the garbage collector itself), then it automatically deallocates the tuple.
      Using a garbage collector may be safer than using a deallocator method, because it never mistakenly deallocates a tuple while a program still references it. However, a garbage collector may require a loop that visits each tuple which will survive garbage collection without being deallocated. The form refs returns an iterator that helps implement such a loop.

Base pointers. A tuple can survive garbage collection in two ways: it can be referenced by a pointer that is part of a tuple which has already survived garbage collection, or it can be referenced by a base pointer. A ref pointer p is a base pointer if one or more of the following are true.

  • An executing expression uses a register or temporary memory location to store p.

  • An executing procedure binds a parameter name to p.

  • An executing procedure binds a parameter name to a variable whose value is p.

  • An equate in an executing with clause binds a name to p.

  • An equate in an executing with clause binds a name to a variable whose value is p.

  • An equate in an executing prog clause binds a name to p.

  • An equate in an executing prog clause binds a name to a variable whose value is p.

Pointers and pointer variables that are elements of arrays, or slots of tuples, are not base pointers. Also, only ref pointers can be base pointers. A null pointer cannot be a base pointer because it cannot reference a tuple. A row pointer cannot be a base pointer because it might have been obtained by an enreferencer, or by pointer arithmetic, so it might not reference a tuple from the heap. As a result, row pointers can reference tuples that should not be visited by the garbage collector.

Visiting tuples. The iterator returned by the form refs visits all base pointers of a given type. Suppose that t transforms to a tuple type, which may contain jokers. Also suppose that b transforms to a tuple type, which must not contain jokers, but is a subtype of t. Then the call refs(t, b) transforms to an iterator that is used in a for clause like this.

(for row b q in refs(t, b) do s)

The iterator starts by visiting the first base pointer of type ref t. It casts that pointer to the type row b, binds the name q to the result, and executes the expression to which s transforms. The pointer q is assumed to reference a tuple in a network of tuples that are linked by their pointer slots. The expression s traverses this network, visiting each of its tuples, starting with the one referenced by q.
      The iterator goes on to visit the next base pointer of type ref t in the same way, and the next one after that, etc. It visits base pointers in an unspecified order, and it may visit the same base pointer many times. After it has visited each base pointer at least once, the iterator terminates and returns skip. The expression s has then visited all tuples that will survive garbage collection.

Restrictions. After refs(t, b) is transformed, Orson might change how it represents base pointers internally. To simplify the change, Orson restricts how refs can be called. If refs is called more than once in a program, then the type t must be the same in every call. (The type b may differ between calls.) As a result, Orson need not change its representation of base pointers more than once in a program.
      Orson also restricts which base pointers refs will visit. Suppose that π is the first prog clause in which a call to refs is transformed. Then refs will visit only base pointers created during the evaluation of prog clauses that follow π. It will not visit those created during the evaluation of prog clauses that precede π, nor will it visit those created during the evaluation of π itself. As a result, Orson need not change its representation of base pointers midway through a prog clause.
      This second restriction affects methods defined by π, and by the prog clauses that precede it. When these methods are called, any base pointers they create will not be visited by refs. This is because methods use the representation for base pointers that was in effect when they were defined.

7.3.82. rethrow.

The standard prelude binds the plain name rethrow to a form that is discussed along with catch clauses.

7.3.83. size.

The standard prelude binds the plain name size like this.

size :− 
s(alt 
s((form (type exe r) inj: 
s((f?typeSize(r)), 
s((form (exe r) inj: 
s((fsize(type r)), 
s((form (obj) inj: 
s((f−1))
